Save Can I change my campus or program? [LINK: /students/faqs/detail/24/can-i-change-my-campus-or-prog] First semester (level 1) students are not permitted to change programs. If you are eligible for a program change, you can view program availability under "Open Programs" on the College College Full-time Programs website here. Campus changes are not permitted during your first year of studies. Save

Campus changes are not permitted during your first year of studies. Save Can I engage in studies while on my regularly scheduled academic break and still work full time? [LINK: /students/faqs/detail/15/can-i-engage-in-studies-while-] Students who are enrolled full-time during the academic sessions before and after a regularly scheduled break and who decide to undertake a full-time or part-time course load during their scheduled program break are eligible to work off campus on a full-time basis. If a program of study does not provide a scheduled program break and a student... Save What is considered to be a regularly scheduled break for an international student? [LINK: /students/faqs/detail/14/what-is-considered-to-be-regul] According to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), a regularly scheduled break must be part of the designated learning institution's (DLI) academic calendar. Each regularly scheduled break should be no longer than 150 days in duration. Save

Each regularly scheduled break should be no longer than 150 days in duration. Save What is considered "full-time" work for international students? [LINK: /students/faqs/detail/13/what-is-considered-full-time-w] There is no set number of hours per week that counts as ‘full-time’ work for international students. You are free to work overtime or work two part-time jobs that add up to a greater than usual number of hours. However, your employer(s) must follow all provincial laws on overtime pay and time between shifts. Save How many hours I am permitted to work as an international student? Academic Integrity Having academic integrity means acting fairly and honestly when engaging in academic activities. Cheating, plagiarizing and inappropriate copying of textbooks are examples of types of academic incidents. [LINK: https://library.collegec.on.ca/academic-integrity/i-am-a-student/accused-of-misconduct#types-of-misconduct] To learn more: Book a consultation Test your knowledge via the online self-assessment tool [LINK: https://h5pstudio.ecampusontario.ca/content/73552] Complete the academic integrity modules [LINK: https://college.desire2learn.com/d2l/home/230614] in eCollege Review College's Academic Integrity Policies and Procedures [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/about/corporate-information/policies?gclid=CjwKCAjw3K2XBhAzEiwAmmgrAkAVNsJyh0byAnFsEbFK3mRCmI-KiBIq73zhbsN6Hzc7mQo7VIi9khoCzK4QAvD_BwE] Review FAQ Document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/286]

Academic Integrity Policies and Procedures [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/about/corporate-information/policies?gclid=CjwKCAjw3K2XBhAzEiwAmmgrAkAVNsJyh0byAnFsEbFK3mRCmI-KiBIq73zhbsN6Hzc7mQo7VIi9khoCzK4QAvD_BwE] Review FAQ Document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/286] Book an academic integrity consultation [LINK: /s/academic-integrity/appointments] You can book an appointment with us to learn how to practice academic integrity and avoid future incidents. We can also help you understand the Academic Integrity policies and procedures. Come prepared with details about your academic integrity question or offence. Arrive on time. We will only wait 10 minutes, after which you forfeit your appointment. We recommend students with multiple incidents to book an appointment with us. If no appointments are available, email AcademicIntegrity@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:AcademicIntegrity@collegec.on.ca] with the subject "Need a consultation appointment".

AcademicIntegrity@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:AcademicIntegrity@collegec.on.ca] with the subject "Need a consultation appointment". Include your full name, student number, and your preferred meeting time and we will try to accommodate your request. Please be advised that our staff are only available Monday to Friday, 8:30 am - 4:00 pm ET. Please note you will only see appointments if you are a student eligible for service. 14 appointments still available. Book an appointment [LINK: /s/academic-integrity/appointments] ​How does the Academic Integrity Office work? Our office is an educational resource for students. We seek to promote a culture of integrity and academic excellence through educating students of the academic integrity policies, procedures and expectations. The Academic Integrity Office is a neutral party concerning all academic incident cases and is neither an advocate for students or faculty, nor a decision-maker in the investigation process. Our staff can:

The Academic Integrity Office is a neutral party concerning all academic incident cases and is neither an advocate for students or faculty, nor a decision-maker in the investigation process. Our staff can: Help you understand types of academic incidents. Recommend next steps, resources and other services like writing and learning skills available for further support. Answer questions you have related to citing and referencing (e.g. APA@College). Academic integrity consultation guidelines Appointments are 30 minutes and available on a first-come, first-served basis. Appointments are based on staff availability and are not guaranteed. Appointments must be made at least two days in advance and not more than two weeks in advance. You can access up to one appointment per week. Please ensure you cancel or reschedule your appointments with 24 hours or more notice. If you fail to do so it will be marked as a missed appointment.

Please ensure you cancel or reschedule your appointments with 24 hours or more notice. If you fail to do so it will be marked as a missed appointment. Frequently missed appointments may impact your ability to self-book service appointments in the future. If you do not arrive within the first 10 minutes of your appointment, your appointment will be marked as missed. Looking for more information? [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/academic-integrity/about] Visit our website [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/academic-integrity/about] for more information about academic integrity and its procedures, penalties and supports.

Accessible Learning & Testing Services College College provides support and academic accommodation for students with all types of disabilities in keeping with the Ontario Human Rights Code. We work with you to understand the impact of your disability in the college environment and develop a plan that considers your goals and the options available to support your full participation in the learning environment. If you are not already registered with Accessible Learning and are looking to discuss possible academic accommodations, please fill out the Intake Form [LINK: https://collegec-accommodate.symplicity.com/public_accommodation/] and check out New to Accessible Learning. [LINK: https://studentsuccess.collegec.on.ca/myLearning/NewToAccessibleLearning] If you are already registered with Accessible Learning, request an appointment with your Accessibility Advisor to: Change or renew academic accommodations

If you are already registered with Accessible Learning, request an appointment with your Accessibility Advisor to: Change or renew academic accommodations Address a concern about your academic accommodations being met/support with advocacy Discuss bursaries Accommodations Academic accommodations are managed through the Accommodate [LINK: https://collegec-accommodate.symplicity.com/] system. In Accommodate, students can access accommodation letters, request appointments, and more. If you have questions about Accommodate, view the how-to videos below or contact us: accessibility@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:accessibility@collegec.on.ca] Read more about the Accommodation Process [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/faqs/detail/93/disability-related-accommodati] . Accommodate: Overview and Logging in Alternate formats of this video: Accommodate overview and logging in - Screen Navigation [LINK: https://youtu.be/5X8EFddOcjg?si=vil7Kgp1i9wwhHrp]

Alternate formats of this video: Accommodate overview and logging in - Screen Navigation [LINK: https://youtu.be/5X8EFddOcjg?si=vil7Kgp1i9wwhHrp] Accommodate overview and logging in - ASL [LINK: https://youtu.be/Nc5bPkHpYvg?si=IgNz6vTMitncDO_8] Accommodate: Requesting an Appointment Alternate formats of this video: Requesting an appointment - Screen Navigation [LINK: https://youtu.be/xPFv7IxmuKc?si=UiL6_MYORAryXplI] Requesting an appointment - ASL [LINK: https://youtu.be/9f75Qic0pWk?si=psu-T7hDCAR9dEJ2] Accommodation Letter After your intake appointment with your Accessibility Advisor and accommodations have been put in place, you will receive an accommodation letter. A copy of this letter will also be delivered to your faculty. If you aren’t sure if you have accommodations in place, please check the expiry date on your most recent accommodation letter (in Accommodate, under ‘Accessibility Emails’).

A copy of this letter will also be delivered to your faculty. If you aren’t sure if you have accommodations in place, please check the expiry date on your most recent accommodation letter (in Accommodate, under ‘Accessibility Emails’). If you are in a co-op work term and registered in a course starting with COOP, your accommodation letter will not be issued. You will receive emails when faculty have viewed and acknowledged your accommodation letter. If you experience a change in course instructors, please let your Advisor know, as the system will not pick up this change. Please also let us know if you do not receive your accommodation letter or emails that faculty have received it. Assistive Technology Book a consultation to explore technology that helps you read, write, study and learn more effectively. Here are some examples of learning technology software: Text-to-speech: speaks everything on a computer screen Voice recognition: allows the user to say commands and to enter text using their voice Mind-mapping: organizes your ideas through web diagrams and creates visual concept links Assistive Technology and supports Students with referrals from Accessible Learning [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/accessiblelearning] can access alternate format services and assistive device trial loans. more effectively Providing one-on-one training and support on various assistive and learning technologies [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/assistive-technology/at-overview] that help with reading, writing, note-taking and more. Providing access to alternate formats [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/assistive-technology/alternate-formats] for students with documented print disabilities. Please ensure you cancel or reschedule your appointments with 24 hours or more notice. If you fail to do so, it will be marked as a missed appointment. Frequently missed appointments may impact your ability to self-book service appointments in the future.

If you fail to do so, it will be marked as a missed appointment. Frequently missed appointments may impact your ability to self-book service appointments in the future. CARE Team The College College CARE Team helps to ensure that the students that are most in need of elevated levels of support are identified early. We aim to provide students with the appropriate opportunities and interventions to aid them in achieving their academic and personal goals, while supporting a safe and welcoming learning environment for all community members. Reasons for a Referral You can refer a student when: A student tells me they are depressed A student shares that they are thinking about or have attempted suicide A student tells me they are or were in the hospital due to mental health and/or illness A student threatens to harm others or themselves CARE Referral As a member of the College community, you can share concerns for students by using the Public CARE Referral Form [LINK: https://collegec-advocate.symplicity.com/care_report/index.php/pid832994?] . Only members of the CARE Team review the information you provide.

. Only members of the CARE Team review the information you provide. If you have concerns about confidentiality, please write your concern in the referral form. A member of the CARE Team will review your referral within 1-2 business days and will contact you by email to confirm the information provided, ask any additional questions, and plan next steps. Who is the CARE Team? The CARE Team includes College staff members from across the college who have experience in student support, wellness and community safety. This includes staff from Student Health & Wellness, International Office, Residence Operations, Student Rights and Responsibilities, Security Services, and the Dean of Students Office. Other Resources Do you have questions about your courses or program? Book an appointment with a Student Success Advisor. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-success-advising] Do you have questions about your visa/post-graduate work permits? Book an appointment with

Do you have questions about your visa/post-graduate work permits? Book an appointment with International Student Immigration Advising. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/internationalstudentimmigrationadvising] Do you have questions about your tuition payment or fees? Email studentfees@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:%20studentfees@collegec.on.ca] Sexual and Gender-Based Violence Prevention and Support: Information on our website [LINK: https://studentsuccess.collegec.on.ca/health-and-wellness] Are you in Crisis and need urgent support ? Please contact Security and/or the following resources: Suicide Crisis Helpline (all of Canada): 988 HERE 24/7 (Kitchener, Waterloo, Cambridge, Guelph):1-844-437-3247 Good 2 Talk (Post-secondary student helpline): 1-866-925-5454 or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868 Crisis Support Peel (Mississauga, Brampton, Peel areas): 1-888-811-2222 FAQs Q: What happens after I submit a CARE Referral Form? A:

What happens after I submit a CARE Referral Form? A: A member of the CARE Team will review your referral within 1-2 business days and will contact you by email to confirm the information provided, ask any additional questions, and plan next steps. Q: Will a CARE Referral impact my immigration status or academic status? A: No. We are here to help students navigate concerning behaviours and to make sure they are connected to the appropriate resources. Q: Can I be anonymous when submitting a CARE Referral Form? A: Please include your contact information in the referral form so that the CARE Team can follow up with you. If you choose to be anonymous, it is not guaranteed that CARE Team can follow up with the student of concern. Q: Will I get in trouble if I submit a CARE Referral Form about my friend? A: The CARE Team is here to help students. When our team hears from you about a concern, we review it carefully and help find the right ways to support.

The CARE Team is here to help students. When our team hears from you about a concern, we review it carefully and help find the right ways to support. Q: I am stressed about a lot of things happening in my life but don’t know where to get help. Can I submit a CARE Referral Form? A: Review the Other Resources in the section above. If none of these resources help with your concerns, fill out a CARE Referral Form.

Student Ask for Help - Advising Contact Instructions : Please tell us generally about how we can help. Note : Form submissions will be visible to the student and employees supporting student success. Personal information unrelated to the request or of a sensitive nature should not be included on the form . Typical response time: 3 - 7 business days To book an appointment with your Student Success Advisor (SSA) and view their drop-in schedule, visit the SSA Appointments page [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/appointments/app/topic/83?siteId=1] . For concerns about well-being, mental health or behavioural issues, please submit a Care Team referral [LINK: https://studentsuccess.collegec.on.ca/faculty/careteam] . (required) Academic Concerns Please indicate the general concerns by selecting from the following list, then specify the scope of the issue in the textbox below. Absences Academic Integrity College not meeting my expectations Co-op, field placement, or hands on learning Deadlines / tests Failing, withdrawing or discontinued Further education after this Interactions with peers in my classes Learning strategies and skills Scheduling issues Understanding college in Canada Registration concerns Other Personal Concerns Your form submission will be reviewed by a member of the Student Success Advising team. When it comes to personal matters, we can assist you with finding the right support to meet your needs. In some cases, that might be general assistance by a member of our team, and in others we may help you connect with a specialist in another department who can go into more detail. If mental health is central to your current situation, please consider a Care Team referral linked above.

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

College College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way.

Discontinuance and Reapplying Save Send Feedback The college will discontinue students who have a Term Weighted Average of less than 49.99% (for most programs) or have failed to clear probation after two consecutive terms. However, students should refer to their Academic Handbook Progression Requirements Guide [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide#appendices] for program specific requirements. Discontinued students are ineligible to register in their original Program of Studies for a minimum of one term. They can apply to another college program, if it doesn’t share a common platform to the program they were discontinued from. If a student wants to return to their original program after the discontinuance period, they must apply for re-admission. Please see the Discontinuance Procedure [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/policies/discontinuance-procedure] and Readmission Procedure [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/policies/readmission-procedure]

and Readmission Procedure [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/policies/readmission-procedure] for more information. Read&Write - Chrome Browser Extension [LINK: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/readwrite-for-google-chro/inoeonmfapjbbkmdafoankkfajkcphgd] Read&Write - Edge Browser Extension [LINK: https://microsoftedge.microsoft.com/addons/detail/readwrite-for-microsoft-/bjglhpoliipklkfjcahfefdlfpifcinb] Choose the Microsoft Account option when logging in and use your College email and password. Read&Write is a literacy toolbar with text-to-speech as well as learning tools to support reading, writing, studying and research within common computer applications. The full version of Read&Write is available for all current College students and employees to download using the links above. For Read&Write for Chromebooks, iPad, or Android tablets, please email us [LINK: mailto:at@collegec.on.ca] . . Please reach out to AT@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:AT@collegec.on.ca] or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Magnifier/Reader enlarges and enhances everything on your computer screen, echoes your typing and essential program activity, and automatically reads documents, web pages, and email. Quick links: Get Started using ZoomText with these user guides [LINK: https://zoomtext.zendesk.com/hc/en-us?_ga=2.264405452.2125255696.1531494935-161026172.1531494935] Video - Introducing ZoomText 11 [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fhLV6ydGqWg] JAWS JAWS (Job Access With Speech) is a screen reader that allows students who are blind or visually impaired to navigate the Internet and most Windows-based applications with a text-to-speech output or by a Refreshable Braille display. JAWS (Job Access With Speech) is a screen reader that allows students who are blind or visually impaired to navigate the Internet and most Windows-based applications with a text-to-speech output or by a Refreshable Braille display. Quick links: Get started using JAWS with these user guides [LINK: https://www.freedomscientific.com/products/blindness/jawsdocumentation] Video - Navigating Websites with JAWS [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3MUEyYoKwx0] Genio Notes Genio Notes is a recording and notetaking tool. Features: Record your lectures in class and online Add labels and notes Transcribe Compatibility: Chrome browser, Android, and iOS mobile devices Access to Genio Notes is available to students registered with Accessible Learning Services. Please reach out AT@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:AT@collegec.on.ca] or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Built-in Accessibility Features

or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Built-in Accessibility Features Most devices have powerful accessibility features already built into their operating systems. Our staff can help provide you with support to use your devices more effectively. Mac OS-X and iOS Accessibility Features On an Apple product, go to the "Accessibility" icon under the Settings icon to access the following tools: VoiceOver: screen reader Zoom: magnifier Display Accommodations like Dark mode Assistive Touch Text to Speech Quick links: Learn more about Mac OS-X and iOS Accessibility Features [LINK: https://www.apple.com/ca/accessibility/mac/] Video Playlist - Apple Accessibility [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLIl2EzNYri0cLtSlZowttih25VnSvWITu] Windows Accessibility Features On a Microsoft product, go to the "Ease of Access Center" in the computer's control panel. The Ease of Access Center provides access to the following tools: Magnifier Narrator: screen reader

Magnifier Narrator: screen reader Windows Speech Recognition On- Screen Keyboard Quick links: Learn more about Windows Accessibility Features [LINK: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/products/windows-accessibility?os=windows-10] Video - How to Customize Ease of Access Settings in Windows 10 [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xQMCMPbqeq8lity?os=windows-10] Featured Link Correlation and Regression [LINK: /students/Links/detail/29/correlation-and-regression] An explanation of calculating the correlation coefficient, the regression equation, exercises. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Repeating Courses Save Send Feedback Students may attempt a course 2 times. A student wishing to register for a third time must have approval from the Academic Administrator with academic responsibility for the program. Please see Part 4: “Repeated Courses” in the Academic Advancement and Achievement Policy for more information. Learning Plan and Learning Contract Save Send Feedback A Learning Plan is a document developed between a student on Probation 1 [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts#:~:text=first%20probation%20(p1)] and a Student Success Advisor and is used to plan strategies that will support a student’s success. A Learning Contract is a formal agreement between the College and a student on Probation 2 [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts#:~:text=second%20probation%20(p2)] outlining specific achievement requirements for the student. Learning Contracts are required when students are on probation for a second time. Students on probation will receive an email from the Office of the Registrar to initiate the Learning Plan or Learning Contract process. From the Events & Activities page, use the search term “CCR” or click here [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events?descending=false&endorsementIds=3195436&page=1&sortBy=Start&studentSiteId=17] for a list of opportunities eligible for recognition on your Co-Curricular Record. How does the CCR support my student experience and my career trajectory?

All full-time students also receive the Get Involved Guide each week in their College inbox with some highlighted opportunities for the upcoming week. How does the CCR support my student experience and my career trajectory? It demonstrates that you are invested in your personal and professional growth. It shows the ways you seek out opportunities for meaningful involvement in the College community. Helps you develop competencies that will support your personal and professional growth. Helps you write your resume and articulate your learning experiences when applying to jobs, co-op positions, volunteer roles, scholarships, additional post-secondary programs, or any other instances when you may need to demonstrate skills and knowledge gained outside of your academic program. Disability-Related Accommodation Process Save Send Feedback The academic accommodation process is a collaborative effort between students and Accessible Learning. The goal is to reach agreement on appropriate accommodations, ensuring students have equitable access to their education. Faculty may be involved in this process as experts in academic requirements. While we do not share students’ health information with faculty, there are some accommodations where we may need to provide context about the barriers a student encounters in the academic environment to support the process. If students disagree with a decision, they have the right to appeal: As a first step, students should discuss their concerns with their Accessibility Advisor. If a student believes a decision was made in error, they may appeal to the Manager of Accessible Learning. Appeals are reviewed by a person not directly involved in the original decision to ensure fairness.

If a student believes a decision was made in error, they may appeal to the Manager of Accessible Learning. Appeals are reviewed by a person not directly involved in the original decision to ensure fairness. Depending on the situation, appeals may be addressed to the Director of Advising, Accessibility & Testing, or the Dean of Students. If the decision was made by a faculty member, concerns should first be brought to the Program Chair, and if necessary, to the Dean. Students are also encouraged to review the Academic Dispute Resolution and Appeals policy, which outlines additional options for addressing academic concerns. More details can be found on the college’s policies webpage [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fabout%2Fcorporate-information%2Fpolicies%3FMcasTsid%3D20893&McasCSRF=353cc7976f18d7f0a333128d997b2481c56271842b28b8d52bccf1221645da51] .

Before Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      should arrive 15-minutes before their test start time to secure personal      items and complete check-in. Testing      appointments may be cancelled if students arrive more than 20-minutes late      from the indicated start time. Present      a non-expired physical photo ID (OneCard or government-issued      ID). Only      items required for the assessment will be permitted in the testing      room. All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre.

All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre. To      maintain a quiet and controlled testing environment for all test takers,      children are not permitted within the Test Centre and cannot be left      unattended while any student is writing. All      computer-based tests at the Test Centre will be conducted on assigned      desktop computers. Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test.

Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test. Please      note the Test Centres may not have power outlets for laptops. To      ensure a comfortable and healthy environment for everyone, Test Centres      are a designated scent-free zone. We kindly request that all individuals      refrain from wearing or using scented products. Only      water is permitted in the testing room (approved accommodations      excepted). After Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Test      Centre staff will submit all completed papers to your faculty. Any      concerns regarding the outcome of an assessment should be discussed with      the student’s faculty. If      applicable, return the locker key to the designated area after gathering your      belongings. During Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      are expected to follow direction of Test Centre staff. Students      can only communicate with Testing Centre staff. Staff cannot give any      guidance or answer questions regarding test/exam content. Faculty      will not be present in the Test Centre; however, students can request that      Test Centre staff to attempt to contact their faculty for clarifying      questions. Students      can request the use of blank scrap paper from Test Centre staff. All      testing materials must be returned to Test Centre staff at the end of the      test. It      is recommended that students use the washroom before their assessment. Washroom breaks during assessments will only be permitted if a Test Centre      staff member is available (approved accommodations excepted). In      case of emergency (fire alarm, lockdown), students are to follow the      instructions of the Test Centre staff.

Washroom breaks during assessments will only be permitted if a Test Centre      staff member is available (approved accommodations excepted). In      case of emergency (fire alarm, lockdown), students are to follow the      instructions of the Test Centre staff. The      Test Centre staff will adhere to the guidelines established by the Academic      Integrity [LINK: https://library.collegec.on.ca/academic-integrity] department in the event of an academic integrity      breach. Student Rights & Responsibilities FAQs Save Send Feedback Who do I contact if I have an emergency or safety concern? If you feel unsafe or need immediate attention on-campus, contact Safety and Security [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/safety-and-security/contact] . If you are off campus, contact emergency services by calling 911. If you are in crisis and need urgent mental health support, the following resources can help: Suicide Crisis Helpline (all of Canada): 988 HERE 24/7 (Kitchener, Waterloo, Cambridge, Guelph):1-844-437-3247 Good 2 Talk (Post-secondary student helpline): 1-866-925-5454 or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868 Crisis Support Peel (Mississauga, Brampton, Peel areas): 1-888-811-2222 Who can report a Student Rights and Responsibilities Violation? College students, employees, faculty, and members of the public may submit reports or reach out to our email. Can I make a report anonymously? Yes, we accept anonymous reports. Note that this can limit our responses available.

Yes, we accept anonymous reports. Note that this can limit our responses available. If we do not know who you are, we will be unable to follow-up with any updates or next steps on our process. To submit an anonymous report, complete the report form leaving the reporter name and contact information blank. If you would like some follow-up, you can provide an anonymous email address for us to contact. In some cases, we can keep reporters anonymous to other parties involved. If at any point in our process you choose to be anonymous after contacting our office, let us know. We will provide guidance on what that will look like moving forward. What are my options when making a report? The options we will provide you will depend on what the report or concerns are about. We will provide you with the most appropriate information and policies related to your concerns. In some cases, we may connect you with other departments better suited to support you. How do I schedule a meeting with you?

In some cases, we may connect you with other departments better suited to support you. How do I schedule a meeting with you? We ask that you first reach out to us via email or the report form with additional information on your concerns. This helps us better determine if we are the most appropriate resource for your inquiry. If we can provide further support, we will then share arrange a meeting with a member of our team via email. I’ve received an email from SRR about an incident, what happens next? Follow the instructions outlined in the emails from our office; there may be action items for you to follow. We recommend that you address it as soon as possible. Respond to the email with any questions or concerns you may have. If you received an email with a request to meet, its because we want to hear from you to gather your perspective. A meeting with our office is your opportunity to share your side of events and work on finding a resolution. How do I prepare for a meeting?

A meeting with our office is your opportunity to share your side of events and work on finding a resolution. How do I prepare for a meeting? We understand that connecting with our office can be overwhelming. Here’s some tips to help you feel ready: Review our policies and procedures so you know what to expect. Collect any important documentation like emails, text messages, screen captures, etc. You can send these to us before the meeting or bring them with you. If applicable, write down the names and contact information of any witnesses or other people involved. Make a timeline of events pr notes to help you remember details during the meeting. Consider if you want to bring a support person such as a family member, peer, or advisor. They can take notes and help be there as a moral support. Prepare any questions you have about the policies, procedures, outcome, etc. How do I challenge a decision made by SRR? The challenge process is outlined on page 6 of the

How do I challenge a decision made by SRR? The challenge process is outlined on page 6 of the Student Rights and Responsibilities Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-rights-and-responsibilities-procedure.pdf] If you want to challenge a decision that does not affect your academic status, email srr@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:srr@collegec.on.ca] and outline your grounds for appeal. The Director of Student Rights and Responsibilities will review it. Appropriate grounds for submitting a challenge are personal bias, unfair treatment or new information. Attach any documents any supporting documentation. If the decision does affect your academic status, submit a formal appeal form as outlined in Step 4 of the Academic Dispute and Appeal Resolution Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] (pdf).

Academic Dispute and Appeal Resolution Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] (pdf). You can find the form on the student portal under the Services tab, then click "Forms" in the Students in Full-time Programs section. Complete the Student Appeals Form on Laserfiche. Are my conversations with the SRRO confidential? Your conversations with the SRRO are private unless we believe you or someone else is at risk of harm. We won't act on your concerns without your permission unless there's an immediate risk. If we contact you because of a report, we may share some information with involved parties. All records are kept secure according to privacy laws. Exceptions [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/document/freedom-information-and-protection-privacy-manual/chapter-5-exemptions-and-exclusions] are records under statutes that expressly state that they prevail over FIPPA.

Exceptions [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/document/freedom-information-and-protection-privacy-manual/chapter-5-exemptions-and-exclusions] are records under statutes that expressly state that they prevail over FIPPA. Will SRR violations be visible on my permanent academic record? SRRO decisions and sanctions do not form part of a student's academic record except in cases of long-term suspension or discontinuance from the college. How long does it take to resolve an issue? We typically respond within 2 business days. Time to resolve an issue will depend on the concern, but we will try to move as quickly as possible and will keep you updated on timelines. Winter 2025: Interim Semester for Discontinued Students Save Send Feedback Join the General Arts and Science (GAS) Interim Semester (0791), which allows you to maintain full-time status (on probation). Courses available during the Interim Semester: COMM 2210 (or 1085 if you were not successful in this course) MDIA1070 – Information, Data and Current Events (GenEd) SOC1140 Canada in the Future (GenEd) Two Program Electives that can be selected from your original program or the GAS electives list. After the Interim Semester If you clear probation, you can register for your original program using an Advanced Standing application for any level beyond Level 1. If you need to start in Level 1, you must reapply through OCAS. If you are unsuccessful in the interim semester, you will be discontinued and must apply for another program. The Interim Semester is not an option for two consecutive terms. Important Notes

The Interim Semester is not an option for two consecutive terms. Important Notes The interim semester does not replace or override the "discontinuance requirement" from your current program. Students must still meet the waiting period for discontinuance as indicated in the notice from your academic area before being able to continue in your original program. Not all elective courses taken in the interim semester will work towards your desired program of study. Please speak with your Student Success Advisor or Program Coordinator when choosing electives. International Students must remain in compliance with requirements set out by Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) to be eligible for a post-graduate work permit (PGWP). Please speak with an International Student Immigration Advisor (ISIA) for clarification about these rules. Here are some questions you might ask them:

Please speak with an International Student Immigration Advisor (ISIA) for clarification about these rules. Here are some questions you might ask them: "Since I started my studies at College College before the changes to IRCC policy, am I able to change my two-year diploma program to a 1-year certificate and still be eligible for a PGWP?" "Can I combine two different 1-year certificates to be eligible for a PGWP that will be up to 3 years long?" "How will taking a whole term of online courses through the interim semester affect my eligibility for PGWP?" Students receiving OSAP funding for their program will need to check with their funding agency to confirm that their tuition can be applied towards the interim semester. Please contact the Registrar's Office for questions about tuition and fees. Continuing Education courses are not a part of the GAS Interim Semester and are subject to additional fees. Next Steps Please

Next Steps Please see your SSA [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-success-advising] to explore whether the interim semester is right for you, and for assistance with the process of getting registered. Retaking a Course Save Send Feedback To retake a course (when it is offered), log into the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] , go to the "My Courses" tab, and add the course you wish to retake. Alternatively, you can submit a Course Change Request Form under the "Services" tab. After your request is approved, you will need to make payment within 72 hours (about 3 days) to finalize your enrollment. Contact your Program Coordinator (contact information in the Academic Handbooks [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] ) or the Registrar's Office [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/] for additional information. Note: beginning in 2024-25, students may attempt a course twice. For a third attempt, special permission may be required. Students who fail a course three times will not be allowed to repeat it, and if it is a program requirement, will not be eligible to complete the program.

For a third attempt, special permission may be required. Students who fail a course three times will not be allowed to repeat it, and if it is a program requirement, will not be eligible to complete the program. In such cases, you may consider changing to a different program. ​Terminology: Grade Point Averages Save Send Feedback College commonly uses two types of Grade Point Averages (GPAs): Term Weighted Average (TWA): Represents your average grade for a specific term (or semester). Program Weighted Average (PWA): Reflects your cumulative average across your entire program. Definitions of these GPAs and details on how they are calculated are available on the Registrar’s Grading and Transcripts [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts] webpage. Below, you will find a general overview as well as an explanation of older terminology that is gradually being phased out. Term Weighted Average The TWA represents the average grade achieved across all courses in a specific term (commonly referred to as a “semester”). This metric is used to assess your academic standing and progression in your program at the end of each term. There are three possible outcomes based on your TWA: Promotion with Good Academic Standing:

There are three possible outcomes based on your TWA: Promotion with Good Academic Standing: Your TWA meets or exceeds the minimum average to graduate from your program. Note that this is often higher than the minimum grade required to earn a credit in a specific course. For example, the minimum grade to pass a course might be 55% but you could be required to have an average of at least 60% to graduate. Promotion on Probation: Your TWA is below the minimum average required to graduate from your program. Typically, the range is within 5%, though it is important to confirm this by reviewing the academic handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] for your school. Important: If you are on probation for two consecutive terms (excluding scheduled breaks), you will be discontinued from the program. Program Discontinuance: You may need to pause your studies for at least one term. During this time, you can explore part-time courses or other program options.

You may need to pause your studies for at least one term. During this time, you can explore part-time courses or other program options. When to Use Term Weighted Average The TWA is particularly useful at the end of one term and the start of the next, as it helps determine your academic standing and next steps. Where to Find It You can view your TWA once all final grades are posted to your record by accessing your Achievement Report through the Grades tab in your Student Portal. Program Weighted Average The PWA represents the average of all your course grades throughout your entire program. Sometimes it is also called a “Cohort Weighted Average”. It plays a critical role in determining your eligibility to graduate. Meeting the graduation requirements involves more than simply passing your courses; you must also achieve a minimum overall average: Certificates and Diplomas: Typically, a minimum PWA of 60% is required. Degree Programs: Generally, a minimum PWA of 65% is needed.

Certificates and Diplomas: Typically, a minimum PWA of 60% is required. Degree Programs: Generally, a minimum PWA of 65% is needed. Specialized Programs: Some programs may have higher requirements to comply with external accreditation standards. Progression Requirements Guides for each school are available here: College College Academic Handbooks [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook] . When to Use Program Weighted Average The PWA is particularly useful if you are struggling in one or more courses. Mid-semester, it is important to evaluate how your current grades will impact your overall average and your ability to graduate in the future. Where to Find It Your PWA can be found in the “Achievement Report” section of the Student Portal. Older Terminology To improve clarity and usability, we have updated some key terms, and you will see this reflected in College policies: "Term Weighted Average" (TWA) replaces the older "Session Weighted Average"

(TWA) replaces the older "Session Weighted Average" when referring to your average grade for a specific term (or semester). "Program Weighted Average" (PWA) is now used instead of "Cohort Weighted Average" to describe the average grade across your entire program. These updates aim to make the terminology more intuitive and reflective of their specific purposes. Leaves & Absences: International Students Save Send Feedback Short-Term Leave If the time you will be away from your studies is not more than two academic weeks (10 days), you will not need to fill out any additional forms to proceed with the break. To start the leave process, your first step is to set up a meeting with your International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/internationalstudentimmigrationadvising] (ISIA). This meeting is very important to ensure the break you want aligns with the rules of your study permit. Before you go, you must also email your program coordinator, and each of your professors to let them know the days you will be absent ahead of time. Please note that you are responsible for keeping up with your studies and assignments during this time. If you miss any assignments, tests, or exams during a short-term leave, you may not be eligible to submit your missed work.

Please note that you are responsible for keeping up with your studies and assignments during this time. If you miss any assignments, tests, or exams during a short-term leave, you may not be eligible to submit your missed work. That decision lies with your professors, who must follow college policies. Reviewing your Academic Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] for more information. Emergency Absence If you need to leave Canada due to an emergency, and it will be longer than two weeks, you should first review the refund and withdrawal policies and decide whether to withdraw from your program temporarily. You will need to submit a "Withdrawal Form" through the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] and consult with your International Student Immigration Advisor (link above) regarding the impact on your study permit and re-entry into Canada. Authorized Leave

and consult with your International Student Immigration Advisor (link above) regarding the impact on your study permit and re-entry into Canada. Authorized Leave For longer absences, International students can take an "authorized leave" from their studies for up to 150 days with the College's approval. Reasons for a leave may include medical, personal, or academic reasons. Authorization by the college is required to remain compliant with your study permit conditions. You will need to discuss your leave with program staff and your International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/internationalstudentimmigrationadvising] (ISIA) and complete a 'Return to Studies Plan.' Credit Transfer Save Send Feedback The credit transfer process begins once you have confirmed your acceptance into a College program. If you believe you have completed equivalent courses elsewhere, you can request individual credit transfers. You may also be interested in this resource information [LINK: https://stucollegecon.sharepoint.com.mcas.ms/sites/registrar/SitePages/Student-Resources.aspx] from the Registrar's Office. Here is an overview of the process: Transfers within College: Courses with matching codes and names will transfer over if you're moving to a new program within College. After enrollment, you can view the transferred courses on your Student Portal's Progress Report. Requesting Credit Transfers: Visit the

Requesting Credit Transfers: Visit the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx?_gl=1*djzb5y*_gcl_aw*R0NMLjE2OTU4MzAwNTEuQ2owS0NRandwYy1vQmhDR0FSSXNBSDZvdGU5clNHTnlGT0dSMnk2bDluNEpVeVN4NmxFTnBSWU9wZjlKcWpTMnpVNFJ1NlNHM3gzOVhBZ2FBcnFIRUFMd193Y0I.*_gcl_au*MTMzMzQ1NzY1OS4xNjkwOTA4OTQ3] > My Courses > My Credit Transfer. Follow the instructions to submit your credit transfer request. Upload course outlines for the relevant completed courses. Outlines should include course title, number/code, description, learning objectives, topics covered, textbooks, assignments, and evaluation scheme. They should correspond to the term you successfully completed the course. Note: You may find course outlines at ontransfer.ca [LINK: http://ontransfer.ca/] . Transcript Submission: Provide official transcripts from previous post-secondary institutions. Electronic transcripts are accepted if directly sent by the source institution via email to

Provide official transcripts from previous post-secondary institutions. Electronic transcripts are accepted if directly sent by the source institution via email to credittransfer@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:credittransfer@collegec.on.ca] , through MyCreds [LINK: https://mycreds.ca/] , or with your Ontario Colleges application. Physical transcripts must be in sealed envelopes from the source institution. Copies, prints, scans, or opened envelopes won't be accepted. International transcripts require assessment by ICAS or WES. Official assessment reports should be sent electronically or in sealed envelopes. Additional Information: Monitor your credit transfer request's progress on the Student Portal. Requests should ideally be submitted before the start of a term to avoid delays. Credit transfers may impact your OSAP funding or international student status. Full-time student fees are unaffected unless you switch to part-time status.

Credit transfers may impact your OSAP funding or international student status. Full-time student fees are unaffected unless you switch to part-time status. Timely requests are necessary for possible tuition refunds, subject to refund deadlines. If you have significant life/work experience, explore the Prior Learning Assessment and Recognition (PLAR) process for earning credits. To understand all the details, please review the Credit Transfer Policy [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/about/corporate-information/policies#academicadministration] . Contact and Support: If you require assistance or need guidance, please watch the " Credit Transfer Request - Instructions [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WFrwtfz2ZZw] " video. Additionally, you can reach out to the Credit Transfer Office at credittransfer@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:credittransfer@collegec.on.ca] . For submitting physical transcripts, mail them to: Attn: Credit Transfer Office College College ITAL

Attn: Credit Transfer Office College College ITAL Office of the Registrar 299 Doon Valley Drive Kitchener, ON N2G 4M4 Featured Link Type 1 and Type 2 Errors [LINK: /students/Links/detail/27/type-1-and-type-2-errors] Distinguish between type 1 and type 2 errors in hypothesis testing. Request a Letter: Accepted, Enrolled, Graduated Save Send Feedback Do you need a letter stating that you have been accepted, enrolled or that you have graduated? Do you need a verification of enrolment letter for your Registered Education Savings Plan (RESP)? Do you need a special or customized letter for an employer, day care or insurance company? Do you have a document that requires an official College seal or stamp? Read the information below to access the letter you need and the process and fee associated with it. Online (Free of Charge) To generate a letter free of charge, log on to the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx] and select the ‘Services’ tab then select “Print A Letter’. You will be presented with a drop down box with the four letter types: Accepted and Confirmed Letter program title, start/end date, and session start/end date. Currently Enrolled Letter

program title, start/end date, and session start/end date. Currently Enrolled Letter program title, start date, full time status, program start/end date, session start/end date Proof of Program Completion Letter program title, program start date/completion date RESP – Verification of Enrolment program title, start date, co-op program, current start date, full-time status, program length, level entering and credential type Do not submit this letter to College, it must be submitted to the institution (e.g. bank) administering your RESP. NOTE: Online standard letters above cannot be modified to include additional or different information. Important Note Regarding Canada Pension Plan Canada Pension Plan (CPP) will accept the ‘Currently Enrolled’ letter. The letter must be dated after the start of the academic year. You must: Generate the letter after the start of the academic year/semester. Write “see attached" in Section B of the Declaration of Attendance at School or University.

Generate the letter after the start of the academic year/semester. Write “see attached" in Section B of the Declaration of Attendance at School or University. The ‘Currently Enrolled Letter” replaces the signature required on the form. Submit both the form and the online letter to the government. Specialized or Custom Letter (Charges Apply) If the online letter service does not suffice, you may request a special or customized letter by completing and submitting the Completion of Letter Form with payment to the Registrar’s Office. You may request to have the letter mailed to you or pick it up in person. Please allow a minimum 24-48 hours for processing and be prepared to provide photo identification for your request. In Person or by Fax (Charges Apply) You may request a letter by completing and submitting the Completion of Letter Form with payment to the Registrar’s Office in person or send by fax to (519) 895-1097.

In Person or by Fax (Charges Apply) You may request a letter by completing and submitting the Completion of Letter Form with payment to the Registrar’s Office in person or send by fax to (519) 895-1097. Please allow a minimum 24-48 hours for processing and be prepared to provide photo identification for your request. Letter and Documentation Verification Request Form If you require a letter or form to be verified with the College stamp or seal, you must bring the document(s) to the Registrar’s Office in person for verification and for the stamp or seal to be affixed. Please allow a minimum 24-48 hours for processing and be prepared to provide photo identification for your request. Attention International Students: Select the ‘Currently Enrolled’ letter for applications related to study permit extensions, Temporary Resident Visa’s, U.S. Visas etc. Once you have downloaded the letter, please email internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca]

Once you have downloaded the letter, please email internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca] with your student number to request instructions related to Citizenship and Immigration Canada applications. Adding a Course Save Send Feedback Below are the steps for adding a course to your timetable. Log in to the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx] with your Student Network Login ID and password. Go to the "Browse Continuing Education" tab Type the course code or course name into the search bar and click "Search" Select the desired course from the search bar "View Availability" to ensure the course is available and open. Select the "Section" you wish to add by clicking the check box mark beside the section and clicking "add to cart." If you cannot click the box, it typically means that the section is full. Choose "Add to Cart." Find the course in your cart and click "Checkout and Enroll." Confirm the address and then select 'Save' at the bottom of the Contact Information page. Provide payment Confirm registration. Please verify that you are enrolled in the course under "My Courses" on the Student Portal.

Confirm registration. Please verify that you are enrolled in the course under "My Courses" on the Student Portal. You can check your registration status in the course list. If you cannot register for the course(s) through the "Browsing Continuing Education" tab, you must complete a Part-time Course Registration Form. The Form opens for submission on December 30, 2024. How to Use the Part-Time Day Studies Registration Form in Laserfiche: This is how you can register for courses that will be taken while your student status is part-time. You may be a part-time student on a scheduled break in your program or to make up failed or missed courses after your last scheduled level. To complete the form: Go to your Student Portal Select the 'Services' tab Select the second 'My Forms' tab (for part-time students) Select the 'Part-time Studies Course Registration Form' Complete the form in full and submit Download your confirmation or email it to yourself for your records

Complete the form in full and submit Download your confirmation or email it to yourself for your records Once complete, the request will be sent to your Program Coordinator for approval How to Pay for Your Part-Time Day Studies Course: Once your form is approved and you are enrolled in the course, you will receive an email notification requesting payment. To make the payment: Log onto your Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx?ReturnUrl=%2fStudentPortal%2f] Select ‘Financial Tab’ Select the ‘Payment for Held Courses’ sub-tab (right below the 'My Courses' tab) Complete payment IMPORTANT: Course enrolment will be canceled after 72 hours if payment is not received. Electives (Part-Time) Save Send Feedback To enroll in part-time degree electives, visit the Degree Electives Course List. You must register through the Part-time Studies Course Registration Form, which opens on the first day of classes. Submit your form early to secure a spot on your desired course, as availability is limited. There are two ways to add courses through the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] : Option A: Under the 'My Courses' tab Click ‘Browse Continuing Education’ tab. Search for the course you would like to add. Click ‘Details’ Click on white box of the section you would like to enter Click ‘Add to Cart’ On the left side of the screen, click ‘Checkout and Enroll’ Click ‘Confirm Address’ Scroll to the bottom of the page and click ‘Save’ Click ‘Online Payment’ Follow the payment instructions to pay Option B: Add course(s) under the My Forms tab (Laserfiche): Click ‘Services’ tab > My Forms

Add course(s) under the My Forms tab (Laserfiche): Click ‘Services’ tab > My Forms Log into Laserfiche (Using eCollege login info) Complete the Laserfiche digital Part-time Course Registration Form in full. Notes You can only add up to 3 courses per form. If you have more than 3 courses submit multiple forms. Click Submit and save/email yourself a copy of the confirmation form. Be patient and watch your College email address for updates. Payment is expected within 72 hours (about 3 days) to finalize your registration, or you will lose your seat in the course. Please carefully follow instructions sent to you via your College email address to make payment. You may also be interested in this

Please carefully follow instructions sent to you via your College email address to make payment. Electives (Full-Time) Save Send Feedback To add an elective course to your timetable, log onto the Student Portal, navigate to ‘My Courses,’ and select the elective you wish to add. Ensure the course does not conflict with your other courses. If you take an elective and your full course load, additional fees may apply. For more information, refer to the college's electives website [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/electives] . Link to the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] Registration Hold: Cannot Add Elective If you cannot add an elective due to a "not ready for registration" status, it is likely due to unpaid fees. To resolve this, pay any outstanding fees or set up a payment schedule through the Student Portal. If you have already completed these tasks, contact Student Records [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts] for further assistance. Step-by-Step Guide Option 1:

Step-by-Step Guide Option 1: Once registration has opened, register through the Student Portal under the "My Courses" tab. Then follow these steps: Log onto the Student Portal Click the ‘My Courses’ tab Click the ‘Add Course’ button and scroll down to view Select the course View availability to ensure the course is available and open Select ‘Add to Cart’ Find the course in your cart and select ‘Checkout and Enroll’ Confirm your address. Select ‘Save’ at the bottom of the Contact Information page Confirm registration Option 2: Once registration has opened, add course(s) under the My Forms tab (Laserfiche): Log onto the Student Portal. Click the ‘Services’ tab > ‘My Forms’ > use the ‘Course Change Request Form’ Log into Laserfiche using your eCollege login details. Select course(s) Note: you can only add 3 courses per form – for more than 3 courses, submit multiple forms. Complete the form in its entirety Click submit. SAVE A COPY for your records

Click submit. SAVE A COPY for your records Be patient and watch your College email address for updates. Important: SSA/College Staff cannot provide status updates. The form goes to your Program Coordinator for approval and then to the Registrar’s Office for processing. Due to the high volume of requests, please allow up to 14 business days for processing. Changing Academic Block (Timetable) Save Send Feedback A change to a student's schedule is sometimes also referred to as changing "blocks", "sections", or "timetable". Administratively, each of these have slightly different meanings, but from a student's perspective, the implication is the same - you want to switch the days or times of the courses you are taking to different options. Certain programs allow students to switch academic blocks if there is space available. By switching to another academic block, you are agreeing to completely change your timetable. Requests to change or modify a timetable are not permitted in the following schools: Business, Human Services, and Applied Computer Science & IT. In other programs, it may be permitted. Here are the steps involved: Login to the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] Select the ‘My Courses’ tab Select the ‘Change Academic Block’ button View the block schedules

Select the ‘Change Academic Block’ button View the block schedules Note: blocks will only be displayed if a seat is available. Select your preferred academic block Select ‘Change to Block’ If the ‘Change Academic Block’ button is unavailable and you would like to make a change, submit a Course Change Request Form on the Student Portal under the ‘Services’ tab > ‘My Forms’. Your request will be reviewed for approval. There is no guarantee that your request will be approved. You might also be interested in this tutorial from the Registrar's Office [LINK: https://stucollegecon.sharepoint.com.mcas.ms/sites/registrar/Shared%20Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2Fregistrar%2FShared%20Documents%2FCommunications%2FTimetables%20%26%20Enrolment%2FTimetable%20and%20Enrolment%20Resources%2FChanging%20an%20Academic%20Block%20%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2Fregistrar%2FShared%20Documents%2FCommunications%2FTimetables%20%26%20Enrolment%2FTimetable%20and%20Enrolment%20Resources&p=true&ga=1] .

Academic Integrity Violation Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4750611] If you have been accused of an academic integrity [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/academic-integrity?_gl=1*ld4duw*_gcl_au*MTE1MjgwODA1NS4xNzIxMjIyNDM4*_ga*MTg5MTk2Nzk2Ni4xNzE4MTI0ODc1*_ga_RN8C0HR85Y*MTcyMzY0NzE0OC4xLjEuMTcyMzY1Mjg4OC41MC4wLjE1NDU0ODk5NDQ.] violation, it is important to understand the seriousness of this situation. Academic integrity is about doing your schoolwork honestly and fairly. Additionally, you may discuss with your professor to better understand what is considered an academic integrity violation. You may also book an appointment with an Academic Integrity Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/academic-integrity] or seek support from a Peer Tutor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/tutoring] or Writing Consultant [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/writing] .

Writing Consultant [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/writing] . If you believe the violation was incorrectly applied, you may be eligible to submit an appeal [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts] . Assistance with appeals is available from the CSI Student Advocates [LINK: https://www.collegestudents.com/representation/academicappeals/] . Academic Discontinuance Save Send Feedback If you are discontinued, this means you will be de-registered from your program and cannot continue your studies for a defined period of time. Academic discontinuance decisions are made when students fail to meet their program's academic standards as published in the Academic Advancement and Achievement Policy [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-advancement-and-achievement-policy.pdf] or in your Academic School Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/index] . Continuing as a College Student If you are interested in continuing your studies in the same program, you can apply for readmission after your discontinuance period has concluded or apply for a new program. The terms of your discontinuance, including the length of time, in the original discontinuance email you received from your Program Coordinator. For more information, please review the

The terms of your discontinuance, including the length of time, in the original discontinuance email you received from your Program Coordinator. For more information, please review the Readmission Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/readmission-procedure.pdf] . Selecting a New Program For help with which programs are available, the application process, or admission requirements, use one of these contacts: International Students: InternationalAdmissions@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:InternationalAdmissions@collegec.on.ca] Domestic Students: admissions@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:admissions@collegec.on.ca] For help with career goals, use one of these contacts: International Students: CareerServices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:CareerServices@collegec.on.ca] Domestic Students: SRA@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:SRA@collegec.on.ca] Appeal Options

SRA@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:SRA@collegec.on.ca] Appeal Options If a policy has been applied incorrectly, or if you had a significant medical event, then it may be possible to request an appeal. There are specific criteria that must be met and your appeal must usually be received within five business days of when you received the notification from your Program Coordinator. Please see the College's Academic Dispute Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] for more information. You may also wish to learn more about support from the CSI Student Advocates [LINK: https://www.collegestudents.com/representation/academicappeals/] . Academic Probation Save Send Feedback There are two levels of probation: Probation 1 (P1) and Probation 2 (P2). Students are placed on probation if they have a Term Weighted Average between 55 - 59.99% (unless otherwise stated in the Academic School Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/index] ). Students on P1 are encouraged (not required) to meet with an SSA or their Program Coordinator to develop a learning plan. A learning plan is a document designed to support your academic achievement. Students who have a term weighted average in the same range for a second consecutive term will be placed on P2. Note: a scheduled break is ignored when determining consecutive semesters. When on P2, students are required to connect with an SSA or their program coordinator to develop a learning contract. This is a formal agreement that outlines the requirement for academic achievement.

When on P2, students are required to connect with an SSA or their program coordinator to develop a learning contract. This is a formal agreement that outlines the requirement for academic achievement. If a student's term weighted average remains in the same range after being on P2, they will be discontinued from their program. Important Notes Term Weighted Average is calculated using the grades for each course and adjusted for the number of credits associated with the course in which it was received. If a student is registered through part-time studies their course performance will be reflected in their cumulative weighted average. There is no term weighted average calculation for part-time studies unless they are registered in a program cohort. All students can attempt a course 2 times. For any subsequent attempts, the student must get approval from an academic administrator in the program in which they are registered.

All students can attempt a course 2 times. For any subsequent attempts, the student must get approval from an academic administrator in the program in which they are registered. Failed courses before September 1, 2024 will not be counted towards the maximum number of attempts. 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence Save Send Feedback 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence is an international campaign that runs every year from November 25 to December 10. Let's unite as a community to support survivors and advocate for a world free from violence. If you are looking for support, aren't sure what to do, or need someone to speak to, please reach out to College's Sexual & Gender-Based Violence Prevention & Support Office [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/sgbv] by emailing sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca] . Get involved throughout the 16 days. Below are actions you can take, events you can attend, and important resources you can use in our shared vision of living in a world free from harm. What traits make a relationship healthy? Changing Programs Save Send Feedback You must first identify a new program that is 'open’ to students by reviewing the list on the Open Programs [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/fulltime/open-programs] webpage. If you need help deciding which program is the best match for your career goal, you can book an appointment with a Career Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/career] or email careerservices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:CareerServices@collegec.on.ca] . Once you have confirmed the new program you would like to apply to, you must withdraw from your current program. You can find the Withdrawal Form on the student portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] click: SERVICES > MY FORMS > WITHDRAWAL FORM. Please be aware that you may choose to withdraw from your studies immediately or you may select the option to withdraw at the end of the current term. International Students

Please be aware that you may choose to withdraw from your studies immediately or you may select the option to withdraw at the end of the current term. International Students For international students, once you withdraw, you may not be eligible to work until you receive a new offer letter. International students are strongly encouraged to discuss any program changes with their International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/immigration-information/book-an-appointment] (ISIA) first . To apply to a new program, you will use the OCAS application portal and follow the steps you followed when you initially applied to college. You can have your original account re-opened by emailing the International Admissions team at internationaladmissions@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:internationaladmissions@collegec.on.ca] . After a successful acceptance into the new program, any balance in your student account will be applied to your new program.

. After a successful acceptance into the new program, any balance in your student account will be applied to your new program. Already Completed Courses If you wish to change your program after completing some courses, you must first withdraw from your current program (see above) and apply to the new one through an Advanced Standing Application Form (see the Registrar [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/student-forms] for more information). A $35 processing fee is charged during the submission. Ensure all required information is accurately completed to avoid delays. If you are an international student, consult your ISIA to understand how the change may affect your study permit. Supplemental Assessment Save Send Feedback To be eligible for a supplemental assessment, you must meet specific criteria, such as completing all term work, having no academic integrity violations, and being within 3% of the passing grade. You are also limited to one supplemental assessment per term. If you meet these criteria, contact your Program Coordinator or Faculty to proceed. You can find information about your Program Coordinator in the Academic Handbooks [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] . Accessing Your Timetable Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1341425] Your timetable is located on your Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] under Calendar > My Timetable. To be able to view your timetable, you must complete all the steps required for registration. See the Registration Help [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/current-students/returning-students] webpage for more information about timetables. Registration information for international students [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/apply-to-college/complete-your-registration] includes detailed instructions on completing all required steps. Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] , navigate to the "My Courses" tab, and select the course you wish to drop.
