Appealing a Course Grade Save Send Feedback Course grade appeals should be based on procedural errors, technical issues, or medical/compassionate grounds, not on dissatisfaction with the grade itself. For more details, review the Academic Dispute Resolution and Appeal Procedure under "Academic Administration" on the policies webpage [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/about/corporate-information/policies] . To appeal a course grade, you must email the faculty with the subject labeled ‘Course Appeal.’ In the email, you must describe the issues, including copies of emails, proof of work completed, and any other pertinent details. You must wait five business days for the faculty to respond to your email. If the faculty does not change their decision or respond, complete these steps in the Academic Appeal Request found on the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] under ‘My Services’ > ‘My Forms’. The

under ‘My Services’ > ‘My Forms’. The CSI also provides assistance [LINK: https://www.collegestudents.com/representation/academicappeals/] to students who are seeking an academic appeal. Course Grade Appeal Procedure Does your concern meet the scope and criteria for an appeal? Consult the Academic Dispute Resolution and Appeal Procedure (see the policies link above). If your concern does not meet the scope or criteria identified in the procedure, you cannot submit an appeal. Step 1: Faculty Contact your professor or program coordinator to discuss your issue. If your concerns are not addressed or resolved within 5 days, move to step 2. *Please note, the deadline to begin Step 1 is within five working days of receipt of the grade or academic decision. Step 2: Submit Appeal Form (Appeal to Chair) Submit an appeal form and attach supporting documentation from Step 1. Your Chair will review the appeal request and make a decision within 5 working days.

Submit an appeal form and attach supporting documentation from Step 1. Your Chair will review the appeal request and make a decision within 5 working days. To submit an appeal form, sign onto the Student Portal, select the ‘Service’ tab, click the ‘My Forms’ button. Step 3: Continue Appeal Form (Appeal to Dean) The appeal form will provide the option to continue to Step 3 if your Step 2 appeal is denied. Your Dean will review the appeal request and make a decision within 5 working days. Step 4: Continue Appeal Form (Appeal to Registrar) The appeal form will provide the option to continue to Step 4 if your Step 3 appeal is denied. The Registrar will review the appeal request and make a decision within 10 working days. Payment Plans for Tuition & Fees Save Send Feedback College College does not offer traditional installment plans or payment extensions. However, eligible students in Level 2 or higher can opt into a Payment Schedule, which allows for 50% of the fees to be paid by the due date, with the remaining 50% due three days before classes start. A fee applies for opting into this schedule. To set up the Payment Schedule, confirm your invoice on the Student Portal and pay 50% of the due amount. Ontario Student Assistance Program (OSAP) Save Send Feedback OSAP is designed to assist eligible students in Ontario with funding their postsecondary education. To be eligible for OSAP, you must meet the following criteria: Citizenship or Residency: You must be a Canadian citizen, Permanent Resident, or Protected Person Ontario Residency: You need to be an Ontario resident and have lived in Ontario for at least 12 months prior to the start of your post-secondary education. This is the process for applying for OSAP: Application: To apply for OSAP, visit the official OSAP website [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/page/osap-ontario-student-assistance-program] and complete the application form. Please ensure that all required information is accurately provided. Processing Time: After submitting your OSAP application, the processing time is typically 6 to 8 weeks. However, please be aware that this timeframe may vary if additional information or documents are requested. Check Status:

However, please be aware that this timeframe may vary if additional information or documents are requested. Check Status: You can keep track of your application’s status by using the ‘Check Status’ link on your OSAP account. This will also allow you to view updates, communications, and any required documents. Disbursement of OSAP Funding Once you have paid your tuition deposit, completed your OSAP application, and received an OSAP assessment, your student account will be updated to reflect your OSAP payment. The Ministry of Colleges and Universities will confirm your enrollment approximately 10 days before classes commence. After this confirmation, your OSAP funding will be released within 7 to 10 business days. A portion of your funding intended for tuition will be directed to the college, and any remaining funds (if applicable) will be deposited into the bank account you have specified with the

After this confirmation, your OSAP funding will be released within 7 to 10 business days. A portion of your funding intended for tuition will be directed to the college, and any remaining funds (if applicable) will be deposited into the bank account you have specified with the National Student Loans Service Centre [LINK: https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method] (NSLSC). If you have any questions or require further assistance regarding your OSAP application or financial matters, please feel free to contact our Financial Aid Office: osap@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:osap@collegec.on.ca] . Is Counselling for Me? Save Send Feedback Many students find they struggle to cope with various pressures they experience at times. It can be hard to live on your own for the first time or adjust to living in a new country. You may be worried about your academic performance or have test-taking anxiety. You may be simply overwhelmed with having to juggle so many demands such as work, relationships and school. In life, we can also face unexpected events such as a death, loss of a relationship, or a traumatic event that can affect us significantly. Counselling is a safe space where you will not be judged for what you are thinking, feeling or doing. Meeting with a counsellor can help reduce your feelings of stress and help you develop new perspectives and strategies for moving forward. Counselling Myths Seeing a counsellor means I’m "crazy," "weak," or "mentally ill." My problems aren’t severe enough for counselling. I don’t have time to meet with a counsellor for many weeks.

My problems aren’t severe enough for counselling. I don’t have time to meet with a counsellor for many weeks. When we are in physical pain, we know it is okay to reach out to a doctor for help. It is equally okay to reach out to a counsellor when you are experiencing emotional pain. Counsellors can support students who struggle with anxiety, depression, suicidal thoughts and self-harm behaviour. Counselling is also a great preventive resource to help deal with worries, lack of motivation, feeling lonely and relationship challenges. Counselling is not intended to eliminate all your problems or "fix" you. You are not broken! Once you start seeing a counsellor, it does not mean you need to keep seeing the counsellor for a long time - many students are surprised by the positive impact of just one session. What to Expect When you reach out to schedule your first appointment, you get to decide if you would like to meet with the counsellor in person, over the telephone or virtually.

What to Expect When you reach out to schedule your first appointment, you get to decide if you would like to meet with the counsellor in person, over the telephone or virtually. You can also indicate if you prefer to meet with a male or female counsellor. During the appointment, you can expect a conversation where you and the counsellor discuss what has prompted you to reach out at this time. The counsellor will ask questions about your strengths, things that you have tried in the past, what you hope will change, or what needs to change to reduce your current stress level. The counsellor will help you set realistic goals for change and then work with you on how to make those changes happen. When I am on a co-op term or completing my field placement, can I still work on or/and off-campus as an international student? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1970521] If a student with a Co-op Work Permit has full-time status during the “work experience” portion of their program (co-op or field placement), and if the student continues to comply with the eligibility requirements, the student may be eligible to work on and/or off-campus, in addition to their co-op/field placement work hours. If you have questions about your work eligibility, please book an appointment with your assigned International Student Immigration Advisor or email internationaladvisor@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaladvisor@collegec.on.ca] Find your ISIA by using our online tool [LINK: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=OjndTYrpBESEH8S-zdklpVu6V3IGYbRBjOsR_roF2JVURDNPVDZKVllJQzVEVVdTU0NMOURCV1Y2RSQlQCN0PWcu] before booking an appointment.

Who can I speak to for help with questions about study permit extensions, co-op work permit, and post-graduation work permit applications? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4060856] International Student Immigration Advisors (ISIA) assist students by providing information and resources related to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) including study permits, co-op work permits and post-graduation work permit applications. International students are assigned an ISIA based on their program. You can book an appointment with your assigned ISIA on the Student Success Portal. You can find the ISIA associated with your program by using this helpful online tool [LINK: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=OjndTYrpBESEH8S-zdklpVu6V3IGYbRBjOsR_roF2JVURDNPVDZKVllJQzVEVVdTU0NMOURCV1Y2RSQlQCN0PWcu] . I want to work while I’m studying at College – how can I find a job? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4086179] When looking for work, it is important to find something that will allow you to prioritize your studies. Even if you can work full-time hours (35+ hours per week) you should apply to part-time jobs as these types of jobs usually have flexible schedules. Please be mindful of the hours that you work; succeeding in your studies should be your top priority. Watch our video series on tips for part-time job searching [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LKbOtK4ljs8&list=PLG_bXxTyZqB3J6-0V9dDL20kQgAqfZ-Dz] . Visit the Career Services page [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/career] for resources (sample resumes, tip sheets, and more) and to register for workshops about part-time job searching. How do I apply for a second program at College? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4064385] Second program applications can be submitted while you are studying in your current program or after you have completed your first program at College. As programs fill quickly, you are encouraged to submit your application as early as possible. The International Office manages all second program applications for existing students. The admissions team creates the new application internally and ensures access to OCAS is given so you can access your acceptance once it is issued. To apply Complete the second program application form [LINK: https://forms.office.com/r/8pii9iV5qP] . Once your form has been submitted, please allow up to 14 business days to process your request. An application fee is not required for most second program applications, however, some exceptions apply.

Once your form has been submitted, please allow up to 14 business days to process your request. An application fee is not required for most second program applications, however, some exceptions apply. Important: Program and campus changes are not permitted once an acceptance letter has been issued. Ensure your personal information, including your local Canadian address, is up-to-date in the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx] . Applications will be evaluated on a first-come, first-served basis. Applications must be received no later than three weeks prior to the start of the term. International Admissions does not maintain waitlists for programs. If your program of interest is closed, there is no guarantee that your request can be accommodated. What Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP) am I eligible for if my program is a two-year program completed in sixteen months? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4064375] For a two-year program completed in sixteen months, the program length is considered to be two years and, therefore, you should be eligible for a three-year PGWP. You can find your program length on the program webpage [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/programs-and-courses] or on your Letter of Acceptance (LOA). As an international student, is it mandatory to submit my travel information via the iCent app? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4060147] All newly arriving international students are required to submit their travel information to College College through the iCent app. Follow these instructions to begin using the iCent app: Download the iCent app from Google Play or the App Store. Enter "Canada: as your destination country and "College College" as your institution name. Enter your College Credentials (College student email address). A security PIN will be sent to your student email address for verification. Use this PIN to log into the iCent app and follow the instructions on the Mandatory Start Questionnaire. If you are having difficulty accessing the iCent app, contact the iCent support team at support@icent.app [LINK: mailto:support@icent.app] Featured Link Wolfram Alpha [LINK: /students/Links/detail/47/wolfram-alpha]

Can I change my campus or program? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4064370] First semester (level 1) students are not permitted to change programs. If you are eligible for a program change, you can view program availability under "Open Programs" on the College College Full-time Programs website here [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/fulltime/open-programs] . Campus changes are not permitted during your first year of studies. Can I engage in studies while on my regularly scheduled academic break and still work full time? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1970508] Students who are enrolled full-time during the academic sessions before and after a regularly scheduled break and who decide to undertake a full-time or part-time course load during their scheduled program break are eligible to work off campus on a full-time basis. If a program of study does not provide a scheduled program break and a student chooses to take their own break from the program, it is considered a leave from studies and it is not a scheduled program break. Students who take a leave from studies are not eligible to work on or off-campus during that break. What is considered to be a regularly scheduled break for an international student? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1970505] According to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), a regularly scheduled break must be part of the designated learning institution's (DLI) academic calendar. Each regularly scheduled break should be no longer than 150 days in duration. What is considered "full-time" work for international students? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1970503] There is no set number of hours per week that counts as ‘full-time’ work for international students. You are free to work overtime or work two part-time jobs that add up to a greater than usual number of hours. However, your employer(s) must follow all provincial laws on overtime pay and time between shifts. Understanding Math Anxiety Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1470053] Understanding math anxiety Math anxiety is more than just disliking math. Sometimes you may feel: Fear of making mistakes, lack of confidence in math. Fast heart beating, sweatiness, nausea when anticipating or engaging in math tasks. Wanting to quit when confused or making mistakes in math. Stress before evaluations such as tests, quizzes and exams. Nervous before math class. Procrastination of math homework or assignments. Unable to concentrate on a math task. Does math anxiety affect math ability? The video below explains more about what math anxiety is and does to your brain when you're experiencing it. Math anxiety and working memory Our working memory is a system in our brain responsible for temporarily storing and manipulating information and is essential when solving most math problems. Our working memory can store very limited amounts of information.

Our working memory is a system in our brain responsible for temporarily storing and manipulating information and is essential when solving most math problems. Our working memory can store very limited amounts of information. The amount of information our working memory can store at one time is sometimes referred to a s cognitive load. When our cognitive load has reached its maximum capacity, we stop processing information. Elevated levels of anxiety can affect working memory, decreasing its efficiency. This is not permanent and only occurs for the duration of time that the anxiety lasts. Since math requires working memory, trying to do math under high levels of anxiety can at times feel impossible. So what does this mean? Anxiety can affect math performance no matter how good someone is at math. Our math skills may be just fine and we need to tackle the anxiety!

Anxiety can affect math performance no matter how good someone is at math. Our math skills may be just fine and we need to tackle the anxiety! When we learn to reduce the anxiety we feel when doing or anticipating math tasks, our working memory can process information much more easily and efficiently, making things seem more manageable. Myths about math Math comes with its stereotypes. Here are three things that are not true about math: People of different race and sex have varying innate math ability There is a best way to solve a math problem You have to have a 'math brain' to understand math Debunking math stereotypes can shed some positive light on the subject and our ability to improve our math skills. The next time you hear someone say any of the things above, remember they are not true! Strategies for overcoming and managing math anxiety The following strategies are things you can start doing today to help manage and overcome math anxiety.

Strategies for overcoming and managing math anxiety The following strategies are things you can start doing today to help manage and overcome math anxiety. This list is not exhaustive and some things may work better for some people than others. There is no particular order in which you have to follow the strategies. Try whichever ones resonate best with you! Strengthen foundational math knowledge Math builds on itself. Imagine trying to calculate 5+7−4 without knowing how addition or subtractions works. This would be extremely difficult and could lead to things like lack of confidence, defeat, and frustration. Having strong foundational knowledge of the prerequisite skills needed for the math you are required to do will make things easier. When you attempt to solve a math problem without the required foundational knowledge, your working memory can become overloaded. Cognitive load is the amount of information that can be stored in working memory at one time.

When you attempt to solve a math problem without the required foundational knowledge, your working memory can become overloaded. Cognitive load is the amount of information that can be stored in working memory at one time. The weaker your foundational math knowledge is, the more resources are taken up in working memory when solving a math problem, increasing cognitive load and leaving fewer brain resources for the steps required to solve the problem at hand. With a stronger math foundation, more working memory resources can be allocated to solving the problem at hand, and less on trying to understand the basics at the same time. The stronger our basics, the more math confidence you can build. Not sure what foundational knowledge you need to strengthen? Check out this list of foundational math skills. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/9] Find math learning strategies that work for you On the

Find math learning strategies that work for you On the math learning page [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/9] you can find a list of math learning strategies you can try. You can keep track of the strategies you have used in a Strategies Checklist Chart [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/157] . Not all math learning strategies will work for everyone. It is important that you find the ones that work for you. Implementing a math learning strategy will improve understanding, help to develop skills and increase confidence. More learning and study strategies can be found on the Learning & Study Skills page. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/learningstudyskills] Regular math practice Practicing math by solving math problems is essential to gaining stronger math understanding.

Regular math practice Practicing math by solving math problems is essential to gaining stronger math understanding. Studies [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fuweb.cas.usf.edu.mcas.ms%2F~drohrer%2Fpdfs%2FHartwig_et_al_2022JEPA.pdf%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] show that spacing out math practice over a period of time rather than completing it all-at-once helps knowledge retention. Diaphragm breathing Diaphragm breathing is a breathing technique that engages the diaphragm (a muscle at the base of our lungs and heart). This breathing technique can help to calm us by lowering heartbeat and stabilizing blood pressure (Learning Diaphragmatic Breathing, 2016) The video below is a demonstration of how to breath with your diaphragm: More math anxiety resources:

The video below is a demonstration of how to breath with your diaphragm: More math anxiety resources: Embracing failure [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fsuccessportal.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fstudents%2Fvideos%2Fdetail%2F20%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] to benefit your academic and personal growth. Download this document [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fsuccessportal.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fstudents%2Fdocs%2FDetail%2F94%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] on embracing failure.

Emergency Room Information Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/3400236] You should only go to an emergency room if you have a life-threatening medical emergency. There may be longer wait times, especially if your concern is not a life-threatening medical emergency. When you go to an emergency department, you need to bring your College International Health Insurance Plan card (for international students) or your OHIP card (for Ontario residents). If you live in Waterloo, Kitchener, Cambridge or Guelph, here is a list of the local emergency departments. 1. Grand River Hospital Emergency Room [LINK: https://www.grhosp.on.ca/care/services-departments/emergency/current-emergency-wait] 835 King St. W Kitchener, ON 2. St. Mary’s General Hospital: Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.smgh.ca/patients-visitors/emergency-department-wait-times] 911 Queen’s Blvd Kitchener, ON 3.

Kitchener, ON 3. Cambridge Memorial Hospital: Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.cmh.org/programs/department-emergency-medicine] 700 Coronation Blvd Cambridge, ON 4. Guelph General Hospital Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.gghorg.ca/emergency-department/] 115 Delhi St Guelph, ON 5. Halton Healthcare [LINK: https://www.haltonhealthcare.on.ca/services_/28763/t28425-emergency-department] Emergency care is available at all three hospitals located in Oakville, Milton and Georgetown If you live outside of these cities, you can find your nearest emergency department by searching “emergency department near me” on your preferred internet browser. Walk-in Clinics Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/3461120] Walk-in clinics and urgent care centers provide medical care for people who do not have a primary care health provider, or have one but are unable to reach them. You can see a nurse or doctor without an appointment for minor illness and injuries, but often there is a line or longer wait times. When you go to a walk-in clinic or urgent care center, you need to bring your College International Health Insurance Plan card (for international students) or your OHIP card (for Ontario residents). If you live in Waterloo or Kitchener, here is a list of walk-in clinics that you can visit: 1. Benton Medical Centre [LINK: http://www.bentonmedicalclinic.com] 51 Benton St, Kitchener 226-240-3014 2. Laurentian Walk-in Clinic [LINK: https://www.wwhealthline.ca/displayservice.aspx?id=101690] 750 Ottawa St S, Kitchener (Zehrs) 519-570-3174 7. Onyx Urgent Care [LINK: https://onyxurgentcare.com/] 580 Lancaster St W, Kitchener 519-896-6699 8. Math learning and study strategies Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1467736] Not sure what areas of math you need help with? Use the math self-assessment tool [LINK: https://tlp-lpa.ca/math/self-assessments] to find out. Math learning strategies Make sure you are comfortable with the foundational math topics, including: Whole number operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, square root) Fraction operations Reducing fractions (proper, improper, mixed numbers) Decimal operations and place value Order of operations Percent Ratios, rates and proportions A great way to improve your learning is to start thinking about your thinking. Check out this video [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/videos/detail/13] on starting to think about your thinking and save this document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/91] to look back on during your semester.

document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/91] to look back on during your semester. College classes are much different than high school. This video will walk you through how to learn in post-secondary lectures [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/lil.html] . You can also save this document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/92] to bring with you to class. Learning math online and in person can be different. This video will show you how to be successful in an online math class [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/videos/detail/14] . Check out these tips to improve math learning : Complete homework/practice questions Check your work after you have solved a problem and fix your mistakes right away (so you do not repeat them) Re-do example problems from class independently Re-do problems from tests and assignments that were wrong Re-watch class recordings (if available)

Re-do problems from tests and assignments that were wrong Re-watch class recordings (if available) Ask questions during class when things are unclear Ask the instructor questions outside of class when things are unclear Ask friends for help Sit at the front of the classroom Take notes in class Finish assignments a day or two early to leave time to ask questions Use online math resources outside of course resources Practice a little bit every day Seek help from a tutor Use the calculator you will be using on tests when practicing Practice pre-requisite basic concepts (one topic at a time) Be sure to download our Math Learning Strategies Checklist [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/157] as well to help you stay on track. Math test-taking strategies Not sure how to study for a math test or exam? Are your current math study habits not working as they did in high school? This video [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/es.html]

This video [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/es.html] discusses how to study effectively for math tests and exams. You can also save or print this document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/93] to look back on while you're studying. More test-taking tips: Preparing for math tests, creating formula sheets and creating summary reviews [LINK: https://tlp-lpa.ca/math/preparing-for-tests] Featured Document Job Fair Preparation [LINK: /students/docs/detail/178/job-fair-preparation] Job Fairs can be stressful. Learn what you can do before, during and after a job fair to make the best impression possible. [LINK: mailto:at@collegec.on.ca] Echo SmartPen The Echo SmartPen can record everything you hear, say, and write while linking your audio recordings to your notes. [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35028253] Echo 2 SmartPen The Echo 2 SmartPen can record everything you hear, say, and write, while adding your audio recordings to your notes. Recognized for its clear audio quality and superb operability, the WS-853 features Auto Mode, which automatically adjusts the recording level to match the volume of the sound source. Comes with 8 GB internal storage. Device comes with: Carrying case Learn how to use the Olympus WS853 recorder (User Guide). What are assistive technologies? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2859407] Assistive Technology Overview Students registered with Accessible Learning [LINK: https://studentsuccess.collegec.on.ca/myLearning/AcademicAndTestingAccommodations] have access to many different assistive technologies to support their learning. What is Assistive Technology? Assistive Technology (AT) is any equipment used to increase efficiency, maintain function, or improve the capability of individuals with disabilities. Students use Assistive Technology to research, write, and study more effectively. Examples Text-to-Speech Software: speaks everything on a computer screen, including alternative format textbooks, website text etc. Speech-to-text Software: allows the user to say commands and to enter text using their voice Recording devices: allows the user to capture information presented verbally (i.e.lectures) to review at a later time

Speech-to-text Software: allows the user to say commands and to enter text using their voice Recording devices: allows the user to capture information presented verbally (i.e.lectures) to review at a later time Frequency Modulation (FM) Systems: transmits an instructor’s voice directly to the student at a constant level, ensuring that the instructor’s voice is heard above the level of background noise Mind-mapping software: allows the user to organize their ideas through web-diagrams and create visual linkages between concepts Word Prediction: predicts words on the basis of the first few letters typed, which allows users to select the required word from a drop down menu Adapted from College [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Committee on Disability Issues (CCDI): LD Resource Guide, 2008 [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Assistive Technology Available

Committee on Disability Issues (CCDI): LD Resource Guide, 2008 [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Assistive Technology Available Our labs are equipped with computers, height-adjustable desks, printers, scanners, software programs and devices to support a wide variety of learning needs. AT available at all College campuses: Text-to-speech software: Read&Write Speech-to-text: Dragon Naturally Speaking Screen Magnifier: ZoomText Screen reader: JAWS Mind-mapping software: Mindomo Note taking support: Glean, Digital recorders, Smart Pens Alternative keyboards and mice Featured Document Pregnancy Pocket Guide - Advice for Treating Common Conditions in Pregnancy [LINK: /students/docs/detail/165/pregnancy-pocket-guide-advice-] The Pregnancy and Breastfeeding pocket guide is for women who are planning a pregnancy or who are pregnant or breastfeeding and for their families and healthcare professionals. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Starting your term off right for math success Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1470047] Things pick up quickly once the semester gets going. It is important to start the semester on the right foot and prepare yourself. Check out the tips below to help you start your math course with the right mindset. Get math help early Math builds on itself. Likely, what you learn in the first lesson of your math class will be needed throughout the course. Reach out to your instructor or book a math help appointment as soon as you are: Confused about a topic you learned in class. Stuck on a math practice problem. Preparing for a math test, quiz, etc. Remember, College provides free math help [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/math] for eligible students. Follow your instructional plan Your instructional plan will give you an overview of the topics to be covered in your math course.

Follow your instructional plan Your instructional plan will give you an overview of the topics to be covered in your math course. Set aside some time to check over the plan before your class, so you know what topics will be covered. Even if these topics are new to you, it’s good to prepare yourself for what will come next. Don't skip the first class The first class is when the instructor explains the overview of the course, what their expectations are for students and what students can expect from the instructor. You will benefit from attending this first class for many reasons, including: Getting an overview of the course in a nutshell. Receiving information on free college resources (like math help!). Learning where to locate textbooks and class materials. Experiencing the first lesson. Meeting others in the class. Meeting your instructor. Learning the instructor's office hours. Explore your eCollege course shell Every math class is different.

Explore your eCollege course shell Every math class is different. It’s important to explore your eCollege course shell for class notes, instructor announcements, and extra resources you may need during the course. Here are some things to explore in the course shell during the first week of classes: Location of class notes. Format of class notes (printable slides, videos, etc.). Calculator requirements. Pearson MyLab or Lyryx log in (if your instructor uses it). Online textbooks. Math help appointment booking instructions. Does your class use Pearson MyLab? The Study Plan feature is a great tool for extra practice and tracking progress. This video [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/videos/detail/12] walks you through how to use the Study Plan feature. Explore math resources outside of class There are many free, useful math resources available outside of the classroom, from graphing technology to interactive mini-lessons. We recommend exploring our list of

There are many free, useful math resources available outside of the classroom, from graphing technology to interactive mini-lessons. We recommend exploring our list of math content resources and exercises by topic [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/10] and that you save the 10 Math Success Strategies [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/90] in your notebook or on your bulletin board at home! Student Success Advising No matter your campus or program, there is a Student Success Advisor (SSA) available to support you. We help with academic policies and procedures, navigating the college, setting goals for success, and accessing services. If you don't know where to go, start with an SSA! Self-Serve Advising Resources [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-success-advising/resources] What is a Student Success Advisor? Book an SSA Appointment [LINK: /s/student-success-advising/appointments] We are located at every College campus, virtually and in-person. Use the SSA Search Tool [LINK: https://stucollegecon.sharepoint.com.mcas.ms/sites/WhoismySSA?e=1:70cb87aa9a074485aa2774a60efd0e5a&CT=1704997539954&OR=OWA-NT&CID=3c7bedc2-c16d-6ed5-5d8d-9115604669c4&WSL=1] to identify who your advisor is, then book an appointment with them. If no appointments are available with your SSA, complete the

to identify who your advisor is, then book an appointment with them. If no appointments are available with your SSA, complete the Ask For Help Form [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/form.aspx?id=3652170] and they will contact you directly. Please note you will only see appointments if you are a student eligible for service. 11 appointments still available. Book an appointment [LINK: /s/student-success-advising/appointments] SSA Drop-In for Quick Questions You can meet with your SSA for a brief one-on-one to have your quick question answered. Each SSA is available at 1pm available on a first-come, first-served basis. Depending on the day, drop-in may be virtual or in person. A quick question is often related to "how something works", or "where to find" something. If you need a plan for getting back on track, or to review which courses to take, please book an appointment. Next step: enter the

If you need a plan for getting back on track, or to review which courses to take, please book an appointment. Next step: enter the Advising Booking Calendar [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-success-advising/appointments/app/?workGroupIds=2&siteId=13] and view your SSA's hours and locations (we offer a mixture of virtual and in-person options). How We Can Help Student Success Advisors assist you through your academic journey by coaching, supporting and guiding you to set and meet academic goals. We can help you with: Planning for your academic program with reference to your Academic Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] Understanding college systems, policies, procedures and processes Implementing strategies for making informed decisions and achieving your goals Accessing referrals to academic, wellness, and personal support resources

Implementing strategies for making informed decisions and achieving your goals Accessing referrals to academic, wellness, and personal support resources Check-in with your SSA at least once a semester to make sure you are meeting your program requirements, and review the consultation notes after every meeting through your Student Success Advisor dashboard. International Student Immigration Advising International Student Immigration Advisors (ISIAs) are Regulated Canadian Immigration Consultants (RCICs) or Regulated International Student Immigration Advisors (RISIAs). They are available to guide students and provide information to ensure international student compliance relating to studying and working in Canada. International Student Immigration Advisors are available by booking a one-on-one appointment or attending a drop-in session with other students. Find your assigned ISIA by using this online tool [LINK: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=OjndTYrpBESEH8S-zdklpdpdkjT6afJIqFr5RLQV4jxURDNPVDZKVllJQzVEVVdTU0NMOURCV1Y2RS4u] . Book an appointment with your International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: /s/internationalstudentimmigrationadvising/appointments] Make an appointment for assistance with immigration-related topics, including: study and work permits temporary resident visas

study and work permits temporary resident visas electronic travel authorization (eTA) work eligibility For other international student support services. please contact your International Transition Team [LINK: mailto:mailto:internationaltransition@collegec.on.ca] . New appointment times are added on a daily basis. If there are no available appointments or the available times do not fit with your schedule, check back again tomorrow for more options. IMPORTANT: You must cancel your appointment if you are unable to attend. Please review our cancellation guidelines. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/docs/134/ISA-Cancellation-Policy-(3).pdf] Please note you will only see appointments if you are a student eligible for service. 43 appointments still available. Book an appointment [LINK: /s/internationalstudentimmigrationadvising/appointments] Work Eligibility in Canada Can I Work in Canada? - Youtube [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8eRf1AwxVpc]

Can I Work in Canada? - Youtube [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8eRf1AwxVpc] How to use the Work Eligibility Self-Assessment Tool (WESAT). What you need to know about working in Canada [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/immigration-information/work-eligibility] Visit the College International website for further information. International Transition Services International Transition Coordinators (ITCs) provide specialized support to international students prior to departure from their home country and during their period of adjustment to Canada and College College. We assist with housing, settlement, acculturation, as well as provide guidance on accessing important college and community resources. Please email internationaltransition@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto: internationaltransition@collegec.on.ca] if you have questions. Book a transition services appointment [LINK: /s/international-transition-support/appointments] Book an appointment with one of our International Transition Coordinators (ITCs) for help with: Pre-arrival travel and planning Housing search Navigating college and community supports and resources Cultural adjustment and settlement Safety and well-being If no appointments are available, email

Safety and well-being If no appointments are available, email internationaltransition@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:internationaltransition@collegec.on.ca] with the subject "Need an ITC Appointment". Include your full name, student number, program, and whether you are a full- or part-time student. Please note you will only see appointments if you are a student eligible for service. 3 appointments still available. Book an appointment [LINK: /s/international-transition-support/appointments] International Support Services The International Support Services [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/student-support] webpage has useful information for international students embarking on studies at College College. You will find resources on Orientation, housing, travel, transportation, cost of living estimates, and links to events and webinars on a variety of topics of importance and interest to students. Information Sessions and Webinars

You will find resources on Orientation, housing, travel, transportation, cost of living estimates, and links to events and webinars on a variety of topics of importance and interest to students. Information Sessions and Webinars International Transition Coordinators host online events and webinars designed to address the unique needs of international students. Visit Events & Activities [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/experiences/skills/providers?page=0&keywords=International] on the Student Success Portal (keyword: International) for the latest offering from College International. Pre-Arrival and Travel Information If you are planning to travel to Canada, please read each section of the College International Travel to Canada Plan [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/student-support/travel-to-canada] carefully. This plan includes important information on preparing for your arrival and transition to Canada and College College.

carefully. This plan includes important information on preparing for your arrival and transition to Canada and College College. Register for one of our upcoming Travel to Canada [LINK: https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_kDgxySLdRb6JaVsZOqsF1w] webinars. This session provides information on required documents and advice on how to plan for your travel and arrival in Canada. Housing Start your housing search as early as possible once you receive your visa. Find and securing long-term accommodation takes time. Prior to departing your home country, be sure to have a place to stay upon arrival in Canada (temporary and/or long-term). Visit our housing webpage [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/student-support/housing] to learn more about the Canadian housing market, short-term and long-term housing options, estimated rental costs, how to search for housing and more. Your First Days in Canada Check out our list of

Your First Days in Canada Check out our list of settlement resources [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/resources/search/?order=Relevance&topicsUseAnd=true&topics=International%20Student] for information on important tasks you will need to tend to once you arrive in Canada like arranging transportation, setting up your mobile network, opening a bank account, getting a bus pass, accessing health services, and more. You can also check out this YouTube playlist for Start-Up Tips and Information. [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLG_bXxTyZqB1wlXrXDWRrvrxDtxPyrGTr]

Indigenous Services Be-Dah-Bin Gamik, a Place of New Beginnings With the support of Elders, we named Indigenous Services Be-Dah-Bin Gamik. This  phrase translates to a Place of New Beginnings, representing the physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual work we do to embody the teachings that come with holding space for new beginnings. We provide academic and cultural services and support for Indigenous students at College, including First Nations (status and non-status), Métis, and Inuit. Students reconnecting to their Indigenous identities can attend our events and access Be-Dah-Bin Gamik services. Non-Indigenous students are welcome to attend our campus-wide community events and workshops in collaboration with various departments. For more information, visit Indigenous at College [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/indigenous] or email Indigenous Services at bedahbingamik@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:bedahbingamik@collegec.on.ca] .

bedahbingamik@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:bedahbingamik@collegec.on.ca] . Our Commitment to Indigenous Students At Be-Dah-Bin Gamik, we support Indigenous students through culturally informed services and programs as well as prioritize land-based supports. Be-Dah-Bin Gamik is where Indigenous (First, Nations, Metis, and Inuit) students, college employees, and their guests can gather to study, access technology, and socialize. We live in relationship with the land through teaching gardens, land-based teachings, and increased access to land-based activities. By integrating Indigenous knowledge and practices into all aspects of college life, we empower Indigenous students to thrive and shine on campus and within their communities. Appointments [LINK: /s/indigenous-services/appointments] Current students can book an appointment with our Indigenous student wellness advisor or email jhill1@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:jhill1@collegec.on.ca] .

jhill1@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:jhill1@collegec.on.ca] . Please note you will only see appointments if you are a student eligible for service. no appointments are currently available. Book an appointment [LINK: /s/indigenous-services/appointments] Bursaries & Scholarships Bursary and scholarship information is shared via our social media accounts. We host workshops each term to help students  with the application process. Programming Elders in Residence Every week, Elders from various nations share their Indigenous wisdom, skills, language, and cultural heritage with students. Workshops & Land-Based Education We provide various Indigenous-led workshops and learning opportunities in a welcoming environment that encourage connecting with others and enhances your college experience. Weekly Lunches Join us every Wednesday for a free warm lunch in a community setting—no registration needed. Be-Da-Bin Gamik Locations Kitchener - Doon Campus: 2A601 (main level, A wing) (

Kitchener - Doon Campus: 2A601 (main level, A wing) ( pdf map [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww-assets.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fdocuments%2Fwww%2Fabout%2Fcampuses%2Fkitchener-doon%2Fkitchener-doon-main-building-floor-plan-2.pdf%3FMcasTsid%3D15600&McasCSRF=f474c6ca41e8e0234023c1f16e708744166ecdd42c660c396a63909d372cec7e] ) Waterloo Campus: 1F08 (beside Tim Hortons) ( pdf map [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww-assets.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fdocuments%2Fwww%2Fabout%2Fcampuses%2Fwaterloo%2Fwaterloo-floor-plan-1.pdf%3FMcasTsid%3D15600&McasCSRF=f474c6ca41e8e0234023c1f16e708744166ecdd42c660c396a63909d372cec7e] )

Student Rights & Responsibilities College students have the right to learn in a safe environment, voice their opinions, and appeal a decision when one feels that they did not get a fair process. They also have the responsibility to know what is expected of them, communicate thoughtfully, and respect others. Our department is uniquely positioned to help navigate the intersection of people and their various backgrounds and the conflicts that can sometimes arise, while holding students to a high standard of personal responsibility and upholding the Student Rights and Responsibility policy. Reasons to Contact Us Reach out to our office if you are seeking a resolution to any of the following types of concerns: Conflicts involving students:  If you have problems with another student that make learning hard or if conflicts happen outside of class or group work.

Reach out to our office if you are seeking a resolution to any of the following types of concerns: Conflicts involving students:  If you have problems with another student that make learning hard or if conflicts happen outside of class or group work. Issue with full participation in the student experience: If you face barriers that stop you from fully joining in college activities. Bullying, Harassment, and Discrimination: If you are being bullied, harassed, or discriminated against, or if you see it happening and want help addressing it. Fair treatment: If you believe college policies were not applied fairly or have questions about procedural fairness. Student Expectations for Online Engagement: If you need information about respectful and responsible behaviours for online learning environments according to college policies [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-expectations-for-online-engagement.pdf]

Student Expectations for Online Engagement: If you need information about respectful and responsible behaviours for online learning environments according to college policies [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-expectations-for-online-engagement.pdf] If you are unsure, please reach out and we will direct you accordingly. How to Seek Support If you have any questions about your student rights and responsibilities or our processes, you can email us at srr@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:srr@collegec.on.ca] . Please include your student number, use your College email address, and give a summary of your concerns and questions so we can help you better. If you would like to report an incident , you can complete our incident report form [LINK: https://collegec-advocate.symplicity.com/public_report/index.php/pid925408?] . Include as much information as possible.

. Include as much information as possible. This helps us prepare to support you and direct you to the most appropriate resources. *Note: Filling out the form does not always start a formal resolution process. We will contact you to gather more information and work with you to determine the most appropriate next steps. We respect your privacy and will not take any action without your consent. Our Guiding Principles Community and Respect: College values respect. Students should share their opinions and debate in a way that protects safety, dignity, and other’s rights. Fairness and Procedural Integrity: Our department aims to be fair and clear in our processes. We help students in understanding on their responsibilities and other college policies. Empowering students: We believe in empowering students to resolve conflicts and learn from them. Whenever possible and appropriate, we encourage informal resolution through open dialogue or mediation, allowing you to co-create resolutions.

We believe in empowering students to resolve conflicts and learn from them. Whenever possible and appropriate, we encourage informal resolution through open dialogue or mediation, allowing you to co-create resolutions. Safety: We believe that students have the right to feel physically and emotionally safe while on campus. We use a trauma informed approach to support students from a wholistic lens. This means that we understand the impact of a student’s mental, physical, social, emotional and spiritual health on their overall academic success and interactions with others. By understanding how trauma affects them, we aim to create a safe and supportive place while working with students. Developmental Approach: We are a commitment to supporting students in their personal and academic growth. We see our responses to incidents as chances to learn and improve. Other Resources Are you in an emergency and need immediate support?

Other Resources Are you in an emergency and need immediate support? If you are on-campus reach out to Security Services at one of their desk locations or call at 519-748-5220 ext.3357. For support off-campus call dial 911 for police. Understanding Your Academic Progression College College is guided by policies and procedures that protect your rights and responsibilities as a student. These policies and procedures guide your academic progression and determine your eligibility to graduate. Since your success is important to us, we want to help you understand how important these policies are and how they will impact you. Check your Academic Program Handbook Progression Requirement Guide for more on weighted averages and progression requirements. Finding Your Program's Progression Requirements Each program has different progression requirements. Check your program's progression requirements by: Logging into the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] Selecting the "Academic Handbooks" tab Selecting "Academic Progress Through Your Studies" in the table of contents Scrolling down to the title "Progression Requirements," and selecting your School's "Progression Requirements Guide"

Teach-Me-Tech Library Services offers a range of technology supports for students online, to help you learn how to use tech more effectively. You can: Book a 40-minute tech how-to consultation - more details below! Access online tutorials and guides from our Digital Skills Toolkit [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/digital-skills] Book a tech how-to consultation [LINK: /s/teach-me-tech/appointments] Tech how-to appointments are available for: introductory      computer skills scanning      and uploading documents to eCollege navigating MyCollege, eCollege, eTexts and other college applications using      Zoom and Teams troubleshooting      software issues instructions installing College-provided software for PC and Mac using      Microsoft Office 365 products using      collaboration and creativity tools When attending your appointment, make sure you: Come prepared      with details and questions about your tech issue Arrive on time.

Come prepared      with details and questions about your tech issue Arrive on time. We will only wait 10 minutes, after which you forfeit your appointment. Please note you will only see appointments if you are a student eligible for service. no appointments are currently available. Book an appointment [LINK: /s/teach-me-tech/appointments] ​Useful online tools and workshops Digital Skills Toolkit [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/digital-skills] Learn to use Zoom, Office 365, video production and other computer skills. LinkedIn Learning [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/linkedIn-learning] Access a large range of professional instructional videos and online courses to help enhance your software, IT, design and technology skills. Virtual Workshops [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/experiences/skills/providers?page=0] Attend an online Teach Me Tech workshop. We cover a range of topics related to Office 365, Adobe Acrobat and more.

Attend an online Teach Me Tech workshop. We cover a range of topics related to Office 365, Adobe Acrobat and more. ​Tech how-to consultation guidelines We do not assist with assignments, but we will provide examples and resources to guide you in mastering new concepts. We do not handle repairs or software installation. Appointments are 40 minutes and available on a first-come, first-served basis. Appointments are based on staff availability and are not guaranteed. Appointments must be made at least two days in advance and not more than one week in advance. You can access up to one appointment per week. Please ensure you cancel or reschedule your appointments with 24 hours or more notice. If you fail to do so it will be marked as a missed appointment. Frequently missed appointments may impact your ability to self-book service appointments in the future. If you do not arrive within the first 10 minutes of your appointment, your appointment will be marked as missed.

Testing Services We are focused on facilitating the academic success of all students, with a priority placed on ensuring that those requiring testing accommodations receive them in a convenient, accessible, and respectful manner. If you have any questions, you can contact us by emailing TestingServices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:TestingServices@collegec.on.ca] or calling 548-889-0130, choosing option #1 and select your campus. Accommodated Tests Students with approved accessibility accommodations related to testing through Accessible Services have the option to write with their campus Test Centre. Students may request an appointment through the Test Centre section of Accommodate [LINK: https://collegec-accommodate.symplicity.com/] . It is the student's responsibility to keep track of upcoming test dates and to book tests 7 days in advance (or 14 days for any tests occurring the week before Student Success week and the last week of the Fall, Winter and Spring semester).

. It is the student's responsibility to keep track of upcoming test dates and to book tests 7 days in advance (or 14 days for any tests occurring the week before Student Success week and the last week of the Fall, Winter and Spring semester). Please refer to the following video of how to request a testing appointment in Accommodate: Booking a Testing      Appointment [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OtWmC6ALb3c] If you are experiencing difficulties submitting your request, please contact us. Booking Procedures for Accommodated McMaster BScN Tests Student      completes Section 1 of the McMaster      BScN - Accommodated Test Booking Form [LINK: https://cms.collegec.on.ca/sites/virtual-learning-commons/student-success/OpenAccess/book%20a%20test/mcmaster-bscn-accommodated-test-booking-form.pdf] and sends the form to their      Program Coordinator (for nursing courses) or Professor (for health &      elective courses) a minimum of 14 days in advance of the test date.

McMaster      BScN - Accommodated Test Booking Form [LINK: https://cms.collegec.on.ca/sites/virtual-learning-commons/student-success/OpenAccess/book%20a%20test/mcmaster-bscn-accommodated-test-booking-form.pdf] and sends the form to their      Program Coordinator (for nursing courses) or Professor (for health &      elective courses) a minimum of 14 days in advance of the test date. Faculty      completes Section 2 of the McMaster      BScN - Accommodated Test Booking Form [LINK: https://cms.collegec.on.ca/sites/virtual-learning-commons/student-success/OpenAccess/book%20a%20test/mcmaster-bscn-accommodated-test-booking-form.pdf] and sends the form, and any      applicable test files, to the Doon Test Centre. Test      Centre processes requests and sends confirmation emails to Faculty and the      student. Make-Up Tests "Make-up test" refers to tests administered to students outside of scheduled class time due to a conflict or special consideration (e.g., illness).

Make-Up Tests "Make-up test" refers to tests administered to students outside of scheduled class time due to a conflict or special consideration (e.g., illness). Students must obtain approval from their faculty to write a make-up test. If approved, your faculty may choose to handle the make-up test directly or use Test Centre services. Requests for students to write a make-up test at the Test Centre must come directly from faculty. Writing at the Test Centre Review what you should do before, during and after your assessment:

Peer Tutoring We offer FREE help with your course content from upper-level students in your program! Peer Tutors provide support primarily with first-year courses in diploma and degree programs. Peer Tutoring starts in week 2 of the term. Students can access up to two peer tutoring appointments per week. Students can have one appointment booked at a time; once the first appointment is completed, students can book a second appointment pending availability. Appointment times are subject to Tutor availability. Peer Tutors are upper-level students who have previously taken the course. Peer Tutoring support is available for specific courses each term - not all courses are supported. Questions? Please contact peerservices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:peerservices@collegec.on.ca] . Looking for after-hours help with Accounting, Economics, Finance, Math or Physics? Simply Math [LINK: https://landing.brainfuse.com/saml.asp?oauth_consumer_key=226C361D] can help, visit the

Simply Math [LINK: https://landing.brainfuse.com/saml.asp?oauth_consumer_key=226C361D] can help, visit the Math Services [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/math] page to learn more! Book a peer tutoring appointment [LINK: /s/tutoring/appointments] If you see the message " all appointments are currently booked ": You are enrolled in a course that has tutoring available, but all current timeslots are booked. Continue to check back daily as new appointment bookings become available. If you see the message " no appointments are currently available ": You are not currently enrolled in a course supported by peer tutoring. Please note you will only see appointments if you are a student eligible for service. no appointments are currently available. Book an appointment [LINK: /s/tutoring/appointments] What type of support can a peer tutor provide? Peer tutors can: Clarify course content. Work through example questions. Provide study tips and strategies. Suggest helpful resources.

Provide study tips and strategies. Suggest helpful resources. Peer tutors cannot: Support with anything that is being evaluated or submitted for marks (including assignments, quizzes, projects, etc.). Do your homework for you. Re-teach the course content. Peer tutoring is not a substitute for going to class. Cover content that has not yet been introduced in your class. Answer questions outside of appointment times. What can I expect at a tutoring session? Before your appointment, review the content (lecture notes, textbook readings, etc.) you would like to cover in your appointment. When you come for your appointment: Arrive on time (tutors will only wait 10 minutes) Bring your course materials, class notes, textbook or practice material Be prepared with questions that you want to ask your tutor Be ready to actively participate in the peer tutoring process. Tutors will ask lots of questions and support you in using your class resources to find the answers.

Be ready to actively participate in the peer tutoring process. Tutors will ask lots of questions and support you in using your class resources to find the answers. Tutors may not have all the answers to your questions; therefore, some questions will need to be directed to your instructor. Additional peer tutoring guidelines Tutoring is not guaranteed for any course in any program. Students can book appointments up to 10 minutes before the schedule time. Appointments are available on a first-come, first-served basis and are based on tutor availability. Students can access up to two hours of peer tutoring per week, having only one appointment booked at a time. Interested in becoming a peer tutor? Eligible students must have achieved a minimum grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 in their first year of study. When the hiring process opens, peer tutor positions will be posted on the My Career Portal [LINK: https://mycareer.collegec.on.ca/home.htm] .
My Career Portal [LINK: https://mycareer.collegec.on.ca/home.htm] . Students recommended by their program coordinator will be emailed directly by the peer services coordinator.

Math Services We offer FREE help with course content from our math consultants! Math consultants provide support for students in full-time College programs who have classes with course codes beginning with "MATH" or "STAT." Appointments are available from 9 am to 4 pm, Monday to F riday Appointments are subject to availability. Students can access one 50-minute math help appointment per week. Math consultants are full-time College staff with professional math backgrounds. Questions? Please contact LearningServices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:LearningServices@collegec.on.ca] . Math resources Book a math help appointment [LINK: /s/math/appointments] If you see the message " all appointments are currently booked ": You are enrolled in a course that offers math help, but all current timeslots are booked.

": You are enrolled in a course that offers math help, but all current timeslots are booked. Continue to check back daily as new appointment bookings become available. If you see the message " no appointments are currently available ": You are not currently enrolled in a course supported by math help. Please note you will only see appointments if you are a student eligible for service. no appointments are currently available. Book an appointment [LINK: /s/math/appointments] How to prepare for a math help appointment Before your appointment, review any content you would like to cover during your appointment (lecture notes, textbook sections, etc.) When you arrive at your appointment: Arrive on time. If you are more than 10 minutes late, you will be marked absent and need to reschedule. Come prepared with specific questions for the math consultant. Have your textbook, course notes, calculator or other course materials available for your appointment. How can a math consultant help me?

Have your textbook, course notes, calculator or other course materials available for your appointment. How can a math consultant help me? Math consultants can: Clarify course content Work through examples Provide study tips and strategies Suggest helpful resources Math consultants cannot: Help students with material that has not yet been taught in class. Help with any material submitted for marks, like assignments, quizzes, tests, projects, etc. Teach an entire topic. Math help is not a substitute for going to class. Math help appointment guidelines Students can book a math help appointment up to seven days in advance. Students must book appointments with at least two hours' notice. Appointments are 50 minutes in length. Appointments are available on a first-come, first-served basis. Students can access one math help appointment a week. Exceptions may apply. Students can bring up to three other classmates to their appointment.

Exceptions may apply. Students can bring up to three other classmates to their appointment. Students can cancel appointments up to six hours in advance through their upcoming appointments page. For cancellations within less than six hours, please email LearningServices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:LearningServices@collegec.on.ca] . Simply Math Simply Math powered by Brainfuse [LINK: https://landing.brainfuse.com/saml.asp?oauth_consumer_key=226C361D] Simply Math is an online tutoring resource that will provide you with just-in-time support after hours and on weekends. Access a live tutor to get immediate help with Accounting, Economics, Finance, Math or Physics. Live Tutors are available: Monday to Friday: 5 PM to 11:59 PM Saturday & Sunday: 12:01 AM to 11:59 PM

Writing & Citing As of July 17, 2025, appointments and drop-ins with Writing Consultants are no longer offered. For resources to help support your learning with writing, please see the resources below Writing tutorials We offer a series of self-guided tutorials [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/writing-guide] to help you enhance your writing skills and your understanding of proper reference and citation styles. Grammarly Students have access to Grammarly [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/grammarly] , an AI-powered digital writing assistant. Grammarly’s software helps improve spelling, grammar, tone and style by analyzing writing and providing recommendations and explanatory notes.

Research Services Library Services offers online supports and resources to help with your research assignments. You can: Book a 40-minute research consultation Contact us through our online chat or text service [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ask-us/chat-text] Visit the library website [LINK: https://library.collegec.on.ca/] for access to all our research resources What happens at a research consultation? Library staff can: Help with the development of your topic and subtopics that will guide your research. Recommend online resources (e.g. article databases, eBooks) for your research and demonstrate how to use these effectively. Help you learn how to assess what is credible information. Answer questions you have related to citing and referencing (e.g. APA). Please note: We do not assist with writing or proofreading your work. We will also not select resources for your research paper. Book a research consultation [LINK: /s/research/appointments]

We will also not select resources for your research paper. Book a research consultation [LINK: /s/research/appointments] Make sure you come prepared with a copy of your assignment details, questions, research topic or statement, etc. Arrive on time. We will only wait 10 minutes, after which you forfeit your appointment. If no appointments are available that fit your schedule, email us [LINK: mailto:cwoodley@collegec.on.ca?subject=Requesting SSP Research Appointment] . Include your full name, student number, and your preferred meeting time and we will try to accommodate your request. Please be advised that our staff are only available Monday to Friday, 8:30 am - 4:00 pm ET, and that we book appointments no further than one week in advance. Please note you will only see appointments if you are a current student. 9 appointments still available. Book an appointment [LINK: /s/research/appointments] Research consultation guidelines

Book an appointment [LINK: /s/research/appointments] Research consultation guidelines Appointments are 40 minutes and available on a first-come, first-served basis. Appointments are based on staff availability and are not guaranteed. Appointments must be made at least two days in advance and not more than two weeks in advance. You can access up to one appointment per week. Please ensure you cancel or reschedule your appointments with 24 hours or more notice. If you fail to do so it will be marked as a missed appointment. Frequently missed appointments may impact your ability to self-book service appointments in the future. If you do not arrive within the first 10 minutes of your appointment, your appointment will be marked as missed. Library staff are available to chat [LINK: https://ca.libraryh3lp.com/chat/college@chat.ca.libraryh3lp.com?skin=15491] . We can help you do research, find resources, and reference appropriately. Online research resources

We can help you do research, find resources, and reference appropriately. Online research resources Library Services has an amazing number of digital resources available to the College community. e-Books [LINK: http://lib.collegec.on.ca/books] Article databases [LINK: http://lib.collegec.on.ca/magazines-journals-news] Online media and videos [LINK: http://lib.collegec.on.ca/videos] Copyright compliant images [LINK: http://lib.collegec.on.ca/images] Standards and codes [LINK: http://lib.collegec.on.ca/standards-codes] Browse more by type [LINK: https://library.collegec.on.ca/browse/find-resources-by-type] and subject [LINK: https://library.collegec.on.ca/browse/find-resources-by-subject] Research tutorials Library Services offers a selection of online tutorials [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/research-skills-tutorials] that you can access anytime, anywhere.

selection of online tutorials [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/research-skills-tutorials] that you can access anytime, anywhere. These tutorials help guide you through the research process when a staff member is not available or if you prefer to work independently.

Learning and Study Skills Learning and study skills build the foundation for academic success in your college program. Learn how to manage your time, read, take notes and study effectively using the information and tools below. Workshops & Events Learning & Study Skills workshops are available to all students throughout the semester to help you improve your academic skills (no referral is required. Workshops available this semester include: Getting Organized Learning and Studying Reading and Note-taking Studying for Exams Slay the Procrastination Dragon Thrive Workshop Series Visit the Events & Activities Page [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/skills/providers] to register today. Learning Skills Advising Appointments [LINK: /s/learningstudyskills/appointments] ALL students can access drop-ins - click book an appointment [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/learningstudyskills/appointments/app/?workGroupIds=4,16&siteId=9]

students can access drop-ins - click book an appointment [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/learningstudyskills/appointments/app/?workGroupIds=4,16&siteId=9] now to see the upcoming drop-in schedule One-on-one Learning Skills advising is a referral-based service. If you are looking for support with time management and study skills, connect with a Student Success Advisor through the Ask For Help [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/form.aspx?id=3652170] form. See our FAQ sheet [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/277] about Learning Skills appointments. If you do not see a One-on-one appointment available to book, it may mean you have not been referred to this service or, if you do have a referral for learning skills advising, that all current appointment times are booked. Managing Your Time Learn how to prioritize, approach procrastination, and plan your time. Note-Taking Learn how note-taking supports your learning. Reading Find out how to read more effectively with active reading strategies. Studying Explore effective study techniques and tools. Test-taking Learn strategies for taking different types of tests and managing test anxiety. Working in Groups Make the most of group work with tools for getting started and completing projects. Career Services Career Services provides career and employment advising support to all full-time College students and international graduates. Questions? Please contact CareerServices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:CareerServices@collegec.on.ca] Job Postings Search for jobs that match your skills and experience. Apply to on-campus, part-time job opportunities. Resume and Interview Tools Get instant feedback on your resume. Create a resume. Practice your interview skills. Job Search Tools Get clarity on your strengths from career assessments. Learn how to be successful in the Canadian job market. Career Appointment Guidelines Appointments are available on a first-come, first-served basis. Students should book one appointment at a time and may not book more than one appointment per week. Students may book an appointment with any Career Advisor. Appointments are up to 45 minutes in length.

Students may book an appointment with any Career Advisor. Appointments are up to 45 minutes in length. For virtual appointments, students must be in a safe location that is free of distractions. Please be on time for your appointment. If you do not attend your appointment within the first 10 minutes, you will be marked as absent, and this may impact your ability to book future appointments. Book a Career Advising Appointment [LINK: /s/career/appointments] Meet with a Career Advisor for assistance with: Choosing a job or academic program for your future Finding work (part-time and full-time) Resume, Cover Letter, and LinkedIn Advice Interview preparation If no appointments are available, email careerservices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:careerservices@collegec.on.ca] with the subject "Need an Appointment." For help finding work while you study, see the Working While Studying section below. Please note you will only see appointments if you are a student eligible for service.
