Medical Clinic Physical and mental health care have a big impact on your college experience. The Medical Clinic offers a variety of health services to support your well-being. Nurse practitioners [LINK: https://npao.org/about-npao/what-is-a-np/] , physicians and nurses are available for College students with OHIP, CIHIP (College Student Health Insurance Plan), or other health insurance plans. Effective Monday January 15 th , 2024, prenatal care services will no longer be offered in the Medical Clinic. Students who are pregnant are advised to go to a local walk-in clinic for prenatal care. If you live in Waterloo or Kitchener, here is a list of walk-in clinics [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/26] that you can visit. If you live outside of Waterloo or Kitchener, you can find your nearest walk-in clinic or urgent care center by searching “ walk-in clinic near me” on your preferred internet browser.

walk-in clinic near me” on your preferred internet browser. Students who are pregnant and experiencing abdominal pain, bleeding, severe vomiting, or other urgent concerns are advised to go to the nearest emergency department [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/25] . Services offered Services we offer include: Diagnosis and treatment of medical conditions. Sexual health care, STI testing and treatment. Birth control, IUD insertions and medical abortions. Transgender and gender-affirming care. Mental health care. Referral to specialists. Prescription medication. Immunizations and TB skin testing. Lab services. Wound care and first aid. Uninsured Services [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/50] When and where should I go for medical care? You can contact the Medical Clinic first for any health concerns you have. Our clinic offers same-day and next-day appointments for urgent illness and injuries.

You can contact the Medical Clinic first for any health concerns you have. Our clinic offers same-day and next-day appointments for urgent illness and injuries. Walk-in Clinics [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/26] You should go to a walk-in clinic if the Medical Clinic is closed, and your medical concern cannot wait until the next day. Minor illness and injuries include fever, infection, cuts that may require stitches, joint sprains, vomiting, urinary tract infections, cough, sore throat or ear pain. View a list of local walk-in clinics. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/26] Emergency Room [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/25] You should go to a local emergency room if you have a life-threatening medical emergency.

Emergency Room [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/25] You should go to a local emergency room if you have a life-threatening medical emergency. A potential life-threatening medical emergency includes severe chest pain, difficulty breathing, sudden numbness or weakness, sudden inability to see, walk or talk, severe abdominal pain, broken bone, head injuries, sudden confusion, or active plan to hurt yourself or others. View a list of local emergency rooms. Counselling Services Counselling Services is a safe and private place for a student to meet with a professional Counsellor to address concerns that may be affecting them socially, emotionally, and /or academically. College's Counselling services are FREE for all students. College is invested in supporting the health and wellness of our students. Please see the Student Mental Health Policy [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-mental-health-policy.pdf?_gl=1*1a3t1ya*_gcl_au*OTIxMDU5NDc4LjE3NDEwOTYwNTQ.*_ga*MTY4MDAzMTA4My4xNzM2ODAyMzA1*_ga_RN8C0HR85Y*MTc0MjMwMjY2Ny4xLjEuMTc0MjMxMzM5Mi41My4wLjEyOTcyODkyNjI.] for more information. How do I book a counselling appointment? Counselling Services is available by appointment. Same-day appointments may be available but not guaranteed. In-person, virtual, and telephone appointments are available to currently enrolled students who are living in Ontario. To book an appointment:

In-person, virtual, and telephone appointments are available to currently enrolled students who are living in Ontario. To book an appointment: Call 519-748-5220, ext. 3679 Email counselling@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:counselling@collegec.on.ca] Visit the counselling office at the Doon Welcome Centre on the 2nd Floor. Why might I see a counsellor? Here are some of the reasons you may want to see a counsellor: Feelings of loneliness and isolation Transition challenges to adjusting to college and/or living to a new Country Thoughts of suicide and self-harm Feeling anxious, overwhelmed, depressed Dealing with relationship challenges Trauma (i.e., sexual, physical or emotional) Concerns with sleep, diet, managing health related issues Other Mental Wellness Resources Good2Talk: Free and confidential telephone or text support. Dial 1-866-925-5454 to talk, or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868 College’s Medical Clinic [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/medicalclinic]

Dial 1-866-925-5454 to talk, or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868 College’s Medical Clinic [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/medicalclinic] College’s Peer Wellness Service [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/peer-mental-wellness] For Immediate Emergency Support: If you are experiencing thoughts of suicide, call 988 or go to the nearest emergency room. When on campus , go to security or call 519-748-5220, ext. 5555 When off campus: HERE 24/7 (KW, Cambridge, Guelph): Call 1-844-437-3247 Crisis Services Canada : Call 1-833-456-4566 Call 911 or go to your local hospital’s emergency department What can I expect from counselling You and the counsellor will discuss: What is bothering you. What has helped you deal with past challenges. What are you hoping to be different and/or reduce your stress. What skills and strategies may help you manage your feelings, thoughts and/or situation. Will others know what I discuss in Counselling?

What skills and strategies may help you manage your feelings, thoughts and/or situation. Will others know what I discuss in Counselling? No, what you talk about with your counsellor is kept between you and your counsellor. Confidentiality (keeping your information private) is strictly followed. Your information is not shared with your faculty, nor is it shared with immigration. The only time a counsellor needs to let emergency personnel or college Care Team know that you are involved with counselling is if you threaten to harm yourself or someone else. The counsellor has a duty to keep you and others safe from harm and to involve the appropriate people to help you stay safe.

Peer Wellness Services We offer INFORMAL supportive listening and wellness activities to help support your mental wellness, encourage connection, and learn about resources available to you. College’s Peer Wellness Services are: Completely FREE Inclusive, engaging, and accessible for all! Drop-in based (meaning you don’t have to book an appointment) Confidential and non-judgemental What is Peer Support? Peer support is a supportive relationship between people who have a lived experience in common. Being a student is complex. Why not talk to someone who has been right where you are now! The Breathing Space The Breathing Space is a wellness-focused, inclusive space for students needing to take a break from their academics, destress, and access tools and resources to support their wellness. Within this space, Peer Wellness Navigators can provide a listening ear and, if needed, direct students to appropriate wellness resources.

The Breathing Space is a wellness-focused, inclusive space for students needing to take a break from their academics, destress, and access tools and resources to support their wellness. Within this space, Peer Wellness Navigators can provide a listening ear and, if needed, direct students to appropriate wellness resources. We encourage students to use the space for their wellness while following the guidelines. Locations: Kitchener - Doon Campus, Welcome Centre Room 104 Intended Use of the Breathing Space Recharge Wellness Space - Students may need a place to escape from the noise and stress of the school environment. The Breathing Space is intended for students to engage in self-care practices and take a break from academic work. Drop-In Activities - Participating in events and drop-in activities can build connections and give students an opportunity to learn about self-care techniques to help with wellness. Peer Wellness Connections -

Participating in events and drop-in activities can build connections and give students an opportunity to learn about self-care techniques to help with wellness. Peer Wellness Connections - Students can utilize the Peer Wellness Navigators for discussions on supporting their wellness, learning about resources, and connecting with current students in a safe wellness environment. Guidelines for Using the Breathing Space The Breathing Space is intended to support wellness and is not a location to “hang out” or do group work. You may be asked to leave if you are not following the guidelines for use. Avoid Loud or Disruptive Activities - This space is intended for low noise activities. Group work, social hangouts, phone or video calling are not permitted. Disrespectful Attitudes and Opinions will Not be Tolerated - Respect for the space, the staff, and other students is a top priority.

Disrespectful Attitudes and Opinions will Not be Tolerated - Respect for the space, the staff, and other students is a top priority. Behaviour not allowed includes harassment, crossing boundaries, disrespecting space, hurtful comments, etc. Avoid Attending Online Classes or Meetings . No Sleeping Allowed - While sleep/rest is a fantastic way to take care of yourself, this space is not meant to be a nap room. What is a Peer Wellness Navigator? Peer Wellness Navigators are current College students who use their lived experience with mental health and/or substance use to focus on building connections and sharing wellness tools, strategies, and resources. Peer Wellness Services are built around mutual respect and trust. No information or services shared in this space are intended to replace clinical wellness services such as counselling and medical.

Peer Wellness Services are built around mutual respect and trust. No information or services shared in this space are intended to replace clinical wellness services such as counselling and medical. Always seek the advice of your physician or other qualified healthcare provider with any questions about your health or wellness if you have any concerns. How to Participate Exploring the activities in The Breathing Space offered by the Peer Wellness Navigators is a great first step to supporting your wellness and becoming connected in an informal way. Looking to participate in a Peer Wellness Navigator activity or group? Check out the Peer Wellness Navigator Schedules [LINK: https://sway.office.com/YXqHECFASd8Nqnhw?ref=Link] to see how you can get involved. For a full list events to support your wellness, check out the SSP’s events page. Stay Connected! The Peer Wellness Navigators share helpful tips to support your wellness on our social media pages.

The Peer Wellness Navigators share helpful tips to support your wellness on our social media pages. [LINK: https://www.instagram.com/ccstudentsuccess/] Looking for Mental Wellness Resources? Sexual and Gender-based Violence Prevention and Support If you have experienced sexual or gender-based violence, we are here to support you. Your rights [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/student-rights/rights] are recognized and supported at College College, including the right to be safe. To get support from this service book an appointment by email or call the Sexual and Gender-based Violence Prevention and Support Office directly. Visit our website [LINK: https://studentsuccess.collegec.on.ca/myWellness/sexualandgenderbasedviolence] for more details on sexual and gender-based violence, what consent means, how to support others and our privacy and confidentiality information. Questions? Email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca] or call (519) 748-5220 ext. 3079. Learn about consent at a workshop [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events/search?Text=consent+culture&EventType=&Location=&campus=] Sign-up for workshops [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events/search?Text=consent+culture&EventType=&Location=&campus=] Book an appointment for sexual and gender-based violence support The Sexual and Gender-based Violence Support Coordinator provides help based on your individual needs. Appointments with this service are confidential. Your timeframe for accessing support is completely up to you. Whether an incident happened recently or a long time ago, you still deserve support! You do not need to disclose what happened in order to get help. You will not be disciplined if alcohol or drugs were      involved. Your international student visa will not be impacted by accessing this service. If you are unsafe or need immediate support on campus, contact

Your international student visa will not be impacted by accessing this service. If you are unsafe or need immediate support on campus, contact campus security [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/security-services/contact] . If you are off-campus call 911 or visit your local hospital. You can email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca] for and appointment and support.

Wellness & Health Promotion Being a student is complex. To THRIVE, you need to take care of your whole self. This means looking after yourself, especially in the following areas, to set yourself up for success: Stress Management Nutrition & Healthy Eating Sleep Movement & Physical Activity Sexual Health Substance Misuse Supporting yourself when you are feeling well increases your chances of staying well. Explore some of the key areas of your wellness and evidence-based information below. In addition, Student Health & Wellness has events, workshops, and resource tables [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events] to help support your wellness through every step of your student journey! NEW LAUNCH! Check out the Great College Cookbook [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/docs/225/Recipe-Book-DIGITAL_Jan-2025.pdf] for healthy and affordable recipes! For added stress relief, download the Student Success Colouring Book.

For added stress relief, download the Student Success Colouring Book. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/admin/docs/Detail/310] Stress Management Being a student often means balancing many parts of our lives. Being able to recognize signs of stress and learn ways to manage your stress will be crucial to your academic success and wellness! Some ways to manage your stress include time management, setting goals [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/164] , setting realistic expectations, taking care of yourself, practicing self-care, and being proactive! Nutrition & Healthy Eating The foods we eat have a direct impact on how we feel and how we perform at work or in an academic setting.

Nutrition & Healthy Eating The foods we eat have a direct impact on how we feel and how we perform at work or in an academic setting. Learning to eat well, meal prep, and cook can be a challenge! To set yourself up for success, we've put together our top tips: Eat lots of vegetables and fruit. Choose whole grain foods. Eat high protein foods. Limit highly and ultra-processed foods. Make water your drink of choice. Additional Resources: The Great College Cookbook [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/docs/225/Recipe-Book-DIGITAL_Jan-2025.pdf] Canada's Food Guide [LINK: https://food-guide.canada.ca/en/] Sleep Did you know: Adults need 7 to 9 hours of sleep each night [LINK: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/healthy-living/canadian-adults-getting-enough-sleep-infographic.html] to feel their best? Learn strategies to improve your sleep: Be consistent.

Learn strategies to improve your sleep: Be consistent. Go to bed at the same time each night and get up at the same time each morning, including on the weekends. Make sure your bedroom is quiet, dark, relaxing, and at a comfortable temperature. Remove electronic devices, such as TVs, computers, and phones, from the bedroom. Avoid large meals, caffeine, and alcohol before bedtime. Get exercise. Being physically active can help you fall asleep more easily at night. Substance Use Get all the facts when it comes to alcohol, cannabis, and other substances. The substances you choose to use might be hurting, more than helping. Knowing the right information to make informed decisions about substance use is an important first step! For more information on substance use, check out the below links. Student Engagement Student Engagement connects you with volunteer and learning opportunities to enhance your college experience outside of your academic program. We are committed to welcoming and including all members of our diverse college community through initiatives that allow everyone to develop a sense of belonging and connection. For      general questions related to Student Engagement’s initiatives,      contact studentengagement@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:studentengagement@collegec.on.ca] . Co-Curricular Record The Co-Curricular Record (CCR) is an official document, complementary to an academic transcript, which recognizes and records your learning through approved co-curricular experiences at College College. Search the Student Success Portal Events & Activities page for CCR eligible opportunities. Attend a CCR eligible opportunity to enrich your college experience outside of your program by learning something new and meeting students in other programs.

What's New and Upcoming Leadership Workshop Series Leadership Workshops are designed to help you develop essential leadership skills necessary to participate effectively in a rapidly changing workforce and world. Collectively, the Leadership Workshops focus on enhancing self-awareness, strengthening core leadership competencies, and inspiring you to become leaders of positive change. Co-Curricular Record Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2201634] The Student Success Portal’s Events & Activities page gives you access to workshops, clubs, committees, volunteer roles, and recreational opportunities each term, many of which are eligible for Co-Curricular Record (CCR) recognition. How do I find opportunities that I can include on my CCR? From the Events & Activities page, use the search term “CCR” or click here [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events?descending=false&endorsementIds=3195436&page=1&sortBy=Start&studentSiteId=17] for a list of opportunities eligible for recognition on your Co-Curricular Record. All full-time students also receive the Get Involved Guide each week in their College inbox with some highlighted opportunities for the upcoming week. How does the CCR support my student experience and my career trajectory?

All full-time students also receive the Get Involved Guide each week in their College inbox with some highlighted opportunities for the upcoming week. How does the CCR support my student experience and my career trajectory? It demonstrates that you are invested in your personal and professional growth. It shows the ways you seek out opportunities for meaningful involvement in the College community. Helps you develop competencies that will support your personal and professional growth. Helps you write your resume and articulate your learning experiences when applying to jobs, co-op positions, volunteer roles, scholarships, additional post-secondary programs, or any other instances when you may need to demonstrate skills and knowledge gained outside of your academic program. College College Student Housing Find your home away from home! While studying at College College, it's important to consider all available housing options, including on and off-campus housing. College is committed to offering housing options and related services for our students. Please see our Student Housing Policy [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-housing-policy.pdf?_gl=1*1htin1v*_gcl_au*OTIxMDU5NDc4LjE3NDEwOTYwNTQ.*_ga*MTY4MDAzMTA4My4xNzM2ODAyMzA1*_ga_RN8C0HR85Y*MTc0MjMwMjY2Ny4xLjEuMTc0MjMxMzYwNC41Ny4wLjEyOTcyODkyNjI.] for more information. College Housing Brantford - 180 Dalhousie St. Student apartments and suites ideal for students at the Brantford campus. Kitchener - 99 College College Blvd. This residence is ideal for students attending the Kitchener - Doon and Cambridge - Fountain Street campuses. Milton - 1259 Lily Cres. Student apartments and suites ideal for students attending the Milton campuses.

Milton - 1259 Lily Cres. Student apartments and suites ideal for students attending the Milton campuses. Waterloo - 60 University Ave. East Student apartments and suites ideal for students attending Waterloo and Kitchener - Downtown campuses. Waterloo - 475 King St. North Student apartments and suites ideal for students attending Waterloo and Kitchener - Downtown campuses. Register for one of our upcoming Housing Wednesday sessions [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events?descending=false&page=1&sortBy=Start&studentSiteId=17&text=housing%20wednesdays] to learn about effective strategies for your housing search in Canada. Additional Housing Resources Off-Campus Rentals Live off campus with roommates or on your own. The most common way to search for off-campus housing is through rental listing websites or networking with family, friends, and other College College students. Visit our International Housing site [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/student-support/housing] for resources to search for off-campus rentals. These resources are applicable to international and domestic students. Temporary Housing If you do not find a place to live before you arrive in Canada, your option is to book temporary accommodations until you secure longer-term housing.

Temporary Housing If you do not find a place to live before you arrive in Canada, your option is to book temporary accommodations until you secure longer-term housing. There are hotel and potential residence options for you to explore. Visit the Temporary housing - hotels and residence [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/student-support/housing] information for links! Homestay Homestay is a program that matches international students with local host families to live with while studying at College. College College partners with Canada Homestay Network Inc. (CHN) to administer our Homestay program. For more information on the Homestay program, visit our International Housing page. [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/student-support/housing] Housing Search When searching for housing it is important to understand what is required of your search, and what will be required of you when you need to sign a lease. Visit our

When searching for housing it is important to understand what is required of your search, and what will be required of you when you need to sign a lease. Visit our International Housing site [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/student-support/housing] (under off-campus rentals), for resources in understanding your Canadian housing search. This information is applicable to both International and Domestic Students. More Ways to Connect If you are an international student and have questions about housing, please email an International Transition Coordinator here: internationaltransition@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaltransition@collegec.on.ca] If you are a domestic or International Student with questions about College’s Residence, email info@collegeresidence.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:info@collegeresidence.ca] , and for College's Off-Campus Housing, email info@collegeoffcampus.ca [LINK: mailto:info@collegeoffcampus.ca] .

Student Ask for Help - Advising Contact Instructions : Please tell us generally about how we can help. Note : Form submissions will be visible to the student and employees supporting student success. Personal information unrelated to the request or of a sensitive nature should not be included on the form . Typical response time: 3 - 7 business days To book an appointment with your Student Success Advisor (SSA) and view their drop-in schedule, visit the SSA Appointments page [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/appointments/app/topic/83?siteId=1] . For concerns about well-being, mental health or behavioural issues, please submit a Care Team referral [LINK: https://studentsuccess.collegec.on.ca/faculty/careteam] . Student Number (required) Campus Any Brantford Cambridge - Fountain Street Cambridge - Reuter Guelph Ingersoll Skills Training Centre Kitchener - Downtown Kitchener - Doon Milton Stratford Waterloo Program Name (required) Academic Concerns

(required) Academic Concerns Please indicate the general concerns by selecting from the following list, then specify the scope of the issue in the textbox below. Absences Academic Integrity College not meeting my expectations Co-op, field placement, or hands on learning Deadlines / tests Failing, withdrawing or discontinued Further education after this Interactions with peers in my classes Learning strategies and skills Scheduling issues Understanding college in Canada Registration concerns Other Personal Concerns Your form submission will be reviewed by a member of the Student Success Advising team. When it comes to personal matters, we can assist you with finding the right support to meet your needs. In some cases, that might be general assistance by a member of our team, and in others we may help you connect with a specialist in another department who can go into more detail. If mental health is central to your current situation, please consider a Care Team referral linked above.

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

College College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way.

These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. College protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to privacy@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:privacy@collegec.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way.

These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. College protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to privacy@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:privacy@collegec.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

What are assistive technologies? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2859407] Assistive Technology Overview Students registered with Accessible Learning [LINK: https://studentsuccess.collegec.on.ca/myLearning/AcademicAndTestingAccommodations] have access to many different assistive technologies to support their learning. What is Assistive Technology? Assistive Technology (AT) is any equipment used to increase efficiency, maintain function, or improve the capability of individuals with disabilities. Students use Assistive Technology to research, write, and study more effectively. Examples Text-to-Speech Software: speaks everything on a computer screen, including alternative format textbooks, website text etc. Speech-to-text Software: allows the user to say commands and to enter text using their voice Recording devices: allows the user to capture information presented verbally (i.e.lectures) to review at a later time

Speech-to-text Software: allows the user to say commands and to enter text using their voice Recording devices: allows the user to capture information presented verbally (i.e.lectures) to review at a later time Frequency Modulation (FM) Systems: transmits an instructor’s voice directly to the student at a constant level, ensuring that the instructor’s voice is heard above the level of background noise Mind-mapping software: allows the user to organize their ideas through web-diagrams and create visual linkages between concepts Word Prediction: predicts words on the basis of the first few letters typed, which allows users to select the required word from a drop down menu Adapted from College [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Committee on Disability Issues (CCDI): LD Resource Guide, 2008 [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Assistive Technology Available

Committee on Disability Issues (CCDI): LD Resource Guide, 2008 [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Assistive Technology Available Our labs are equipped with computers, height-adjustable desks, printers, scanners, software programs and devices to support a wide variety of learning needs. AT available at all College campuses: Text-to-speech software: Read&Write Speech-to-text: Dragon Naturally Speaking Screen Magnifier: ZoomText Screen reader: JAWS Mind-mapping software: Mindomo Note taking support: Glean, Digital recorders, Smart Pens Alternative keyboards and mice Featured FAQ As an international student, am I eligible to work in Canada? [LINK: /students/Faqs/detail/31/as-international-student-am-i-]

Assistive Software Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2866629] Assistive Software We have the following software available at all College campuses within the designated assistive technology space(s) [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/assistive-technology/hours-locations] . Read&Write For reading, writing, studying & research. Download links: Read&Write - Windows Set Up [LINK: https://fastdownloads2.texthelp.com/readwrite12/installers/ca/read&write.exe] Read&Write - Mac Setup [LINK: https://fastdownloads2.texthelp.com/readwritemac7/installers/read&write.dmg?_ga=2.10348597.1620579241.1571662788-848083162.1557423867] Read&Write - Chrome Browser Extension [LINK: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/readwrite-for-google-chro/inoeonmfapjbbkmdafoankkfajkcphgd] Read&Write - Edge Browser Extension [LINK: https://microsoftedge.microsoft.com/addons/detail/readwrite-for-microsoft-/bjglhpoliipklkfjcahfefdlfpifcinb]

Read&Write - Chrome Browser Extension [LINK: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/readwrite-for-google-chro/inoeonmfapjbbkmdafoankkfajkcphgd] Read&Write - Edge Browser Extension [LINK: https://microsoftedge.microsoft.com/addons/detail/readwrite-for-microsoft-/bjglhpoliipklkfjcahfefdlfpifcinb] Choose the Microsoft Account option when logging in and use your College email and password. Read&Write is a literacy toolbar with text-to-speech as well as learning tools to support reading, writing, studying and research within common computer applications. The full version of Read&Write is available for all current College students and employees to download using the links above. For Read&Write for Chromebooks, iPad, or Android tablets, please email us [LINK: mailto:at@collegec.on.ca] . Training Resources: Quick Reference Guide [LINK: https://www.texthelp.com/Uploads/MediaLibrary/texthelp/US-Training-Documents/Read-Write-for-Windows-Quick-Reference-Guide-11-2F2018.pdf]

Training Resources: Quick Reference Guide [LINK: https://www.texthelp.com/Uploads/MediaLibrary/texthelp/US-Training-Documents/Read-Write-for-Windows-Quick-Reference-Guide-11-2F2018.pdf] Training Guide [LINK: https://www.texthelp.com/Uploads/MediaLibrary/texthelp/US-Training-Documents/Read-Write-for-Windows-Quick-Start-Guide-USA-Jan-2019-(1).pdf] Read&Write for Windows Tutorials [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLvSZbmGbKpCQEi1OB-nu-wA5KexHppO9C] Read&Write Study Skills for Use in University (20 minute course) [LINK: https://training.texthelp.com/course/view.php?id=77] (Choose 'Login with Microsoft' and use your College email address and password) Dragon NaturallySpeaking Dragon NaturallySpeaking is a speech-to-text software program that allows you to turn your voice into text by speaking naturally. College provides access to the Windows version, but a mobile version is also available for you to purchase [LINK: https://www.nuance.com/dragon.html] . Quick links:

. Quick links: Get started using Dragon with these user guides [LINK: https://www.nuance.com/dragon/support/dragon-naturallyspeaking.html] Video - Dragon in action [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ImlKOA1MhlI] Mindomo Mindomo is a mind-mapping tool that can be used for: Brainstorming Capturing ideas and concepts Organizing written assignments and presentations Time and task management Users can access Mindomo online, as desktop software for Windows & Mac, as well as on Android, Chrome and iOS devices Access to Mindomo is available to students registered with Accessible Learning Services. Please reach out to AT@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:AT@collegec.on.ca] or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Quick links: Video - How to build a simple mind map with Mindomo [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DSnCEXpqi50] Video - How to create a mind map from your learning material [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=83JXkIrc4wM] ZoomText

Video - How to create a mind map from your learning material [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=83JXkIrc4wM] ZoomText ZoomText Magnifier/Reader is a fully integrated magnification and reading program tailored for low-vision users. Magnifier/Reader enlarges and enhances everything on your computer screen, echoes your typing and essential program activity, and automatically reads documents, web pages, and email. Quick links: Get Started using ZoomText with these user guides [LINK: https://zoomtext.zendesk.com/hc/en-us?_ga=2.264405452.2125255696.1531494935-161026172.1531494935] Video - Introducing ZoomText 11 [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fhLV6ydGqWg] JAWS JAWS (Job Access With Speech) is a screen reader that allows students who are blind or visually impaired to navigate the Internet and most Windows-based applications with a text-to-speech output or by a Refreshable Braille display. Quick links:

JAWS (Job Access With Speech) is a screen reader that allows students who are blind or visually impaired to navigate the Internet and most Windows-based applications with a text-to-speech output or by a Refreshable Braille display. Quick links: Get started using JAWS with these user guides [LINK: https://www.freedomscientific.com/products/blindness/jawsdocumentation] Video - Navigating Websites with JAWS [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3MUEyYoKwx0] Genio Notes Genio Notes is a recording and notetaking tool. Features: Record your lectures in class and online Add labels and notes Transcribe Compatibility: Chrome browser, Android, and iOS mobile devices Access to Genio Notes is available to students registered with Accessible Learning Services. Please reach out AT@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:AT@collegec.on.ca] or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Built-in Accessibility Features

or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Built-in Accessibility Features Most devices have powerful accessibility features already built into their operating systems. Our staff can help provide you with support to use your devices more effectively. Mac OS-X and iOS Accessibility Features On an Apple product, go to the "Accessibility" icon under the Settings icon to access the following tools: VoiceOver: screen reader Zoom: magnifier Display Accommodations like Dark mode Assistive Touch Text to Speech Quick links: Learn more about Mac OS-X and iOS Accessibility Features [LINK: https://www.apple.com/ca/accessibility/mac/] Video Playlist - Apple Accessibility [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLIl2EzNYri0cLtSlZowttih25VnSvWITu] Windows Accessibility Features On a Microsoft product, go to the "Ease of Access Center" in the computer's control panel. The Ease of Access Center provides access to the following tools: Magnifier Narrator: screen reader

Magnifier Narrator: screen reader Windows Speech Recognition On- Screen Keyboard Quick links: Learn more about Windows Accessibility Features [LINK: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/products/windows-accessibility?os=windows-10] Video - How to Customize Ease of Access Settings in Windows 10 [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xQMCMPbqeq8lity?os=windows-10] Featured Link Quizlet - Online flashcard maker [LINK: /students/Links/detail/3/quizlet-online-flashcard-maker] This website provides free tools for active studying and can help you make your own flashcards. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

College College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way.

These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. College protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to privacy@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:privacy@collegec.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Volunteer as a Peer Leader with SHORE Centre's "Talk Differently" program An innovative project to address gender-based violence and the barriers newcomers and marginalized groups face in accessing reproductive healthcare. Off-Campus Opportunities SHORE Centre, Kitchener, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Organization: SHORE Centre – Newcomer Educational Program Program Duration: 6–8 weeks (Fall & Winter sessions) Honorarium: $300 per peer leader( 2-3 hours/week) Program Overview: The Talk Differently Project is an innovative initiative to address gender-based violence (GBV) and the barriers newcomers and marginalized groups face in accessing reproductive healthcare. Through a community-led, peer-driven model, this program promotes healthier relationships, equitable attitudes, and systemic change. The program is rooted in the Kitchener-Waterloo region and supports individuals by raising awareness of reproductive health resources and how to access them.

Through a community-led, peer-driven model, this program promotes healthier relationships, equitable attitudes, and systemic change. The program is rooted in the Kitchener-Waterloo region and supports individuals by raising awareness of reproductive health resources and how to access them. Peer Leaders will be trained to create a welcoming, supportive, and educational atmosphere to facilitate workshops for participants from diverse backgrounds. Roller Skating in the Square Join Retro Rollers Inc. on Monday nights for free, adventurous family fun outside Kitchener City Hall! All skill levels are welcome. This community-focused event is intended to be a fun, casual, recreational program. Skate at your own risk. Off-Campus Opportunities 200 King Street West - Carl Zehr Square, Kitchener, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Join Retro Rollers Inc. on Monday nights for free, adventurous family fun outside Kitchener City Hall! All skill levels are welcome. This community-focused event is intended to be a fun, casual, recreational program. Attendees must accept that skaters of all levels may be on the rink simultaneously. Skate at your own risk. To manage the crowds, there may be a limit to how many people can be on the rink. DJ PDK and others will spin all night to keep you grooving, so grab a friend and your skates and get ready to roller disco dance the night away! No skates? No problem!

No skates? No problem! Skate rentals are available for a rental fee. Kids and Adult skate sizes are available. Socks are required. Bring your own or buy a pair on-site. Don't forget safety gear! Helmets are encouraged. Dates: Monday nights from May to September Event Time: 7pm - 10pm Location: Carl Zehr Square, 200 King Street West, Downtown Kitchener Free to Skate! Skate rentals available for a fee. Review the Rink Rules: 1. Skate at your own risk. 2. No skating while intoxicated. 3. Wear safety equipment. 4. Enter and exit the rink with caution. 5. Skate in a counterclockwise direction. 6. No stopping on the rink. 7. No food or drink on the rink. 8. Refrain from carrying children on the rink. 9. Faster skaters to the outside lane. 10. Extreme speed/racing while roller skating is not permitted. Have fun! PARKING: Downtown surface lots are free after 5pm and on weekends. Find the nearest lot at

PARKING: Downtown surface lots are free after 5pm and on weekends. Victim Services of Waterloo Region - Volunteer Crisis Responder Crisis Responders are responsible for immediate, mobile response to requests from emergency and police services within Waterloo Region. Volunteer duties include the provision of short-term emotional support and assistance to victims of crime, trauma, or other tragic circumstances. Volunteer Opportunities Victim Services Waterloo Region, Kitchener/Waterloo, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Looking to gain valuable volunteer experience? Want to give back to your community in a meaningful way? Come volunteer with us at Victim Services of Waterloo Region. Crisis Responders are responsible for immediate, mobile response to requests from emergency and police services within Waterloo Region. Volunteer duties include the provision of short-term emotional support and assistance to victims of crime, trauma, or other tragic circumstances.

Crisis Responders are responsible for immediate, mobile response to requests from emergency and police services within Waterloo Region. Volunteer duties include the provision of short-term emotional support and assistance to victims of crime, trauma, or other tragic circumstances. Crisis Responders also provide service by telephone and ensure appropriate options and/or referrals are available to victims. Volunteers are to conduct themselves and perform duties in accordance with the policies and procedures of Victim Services Waterloo Region. Position Requirements: •Must live in Waterloo Region. •Must be willing to commit to one year of service. •Must be willing to commit to a minimum of four shifts per month. •Must be willing to attend regular Volunteer meetings. •Must possess a valid driver’s licence, liability insurance and reliable transportation.

•Must be willing to attend regular Volunteer meetings. •Must possess a valid driver’s licence, liability insurance and reliable transportation. •Must successfully complete an interview, reference and criminal records check, online learning modules, as well as the 60hour volunteer training program. •Must be nineteen years of age or older. •Must be capable of maintaining confidentiality. •Must be able and willing to work as a team member. •Must have problem solving skills. •The ability to speak an additional language is a definite asset. •Must commit to 4 eight-hour ON CALL shifts/month. The duties of a Crisis Responder include: •Participate in 4 eight hour shifts per month. •Respond immediately to requests from police or other emergency personnel by attending on site, at an alternative location, or by telephone as appropriate. •Provide emotional support and assistance to each victim as needed. •Arrange for transportation and/or shelter as needed.

•Provide emotional support and assistance to each victim as needed. •Arrange for transportation and/or shelter as needed. •Assist victim in identifying immediate and long-term needs. Provide information, referrals and advocacy as necessary. •Follow-up with victims after initial contact to provide further support, determine status, and identify any further assistance which may be required. If you’re ready to make an impact, visit us online at www.vswr.ca/volunteer [LINK: http://www.vswr.ca/volunteer] and fill out an application form or email us at vswr@wrps.on.ca to request a form. * Student Engagement shares information with students about off-campus co-curricular opportunities to support their social and professional development. Anishnabeg Outreach Volunteer Anishnabeg Outreach is seeking volunteers for their Tutoring and Sports program Volunteer Opportunities Anishnabeg Outreach: 236 Woodhaven Road, Kitchener, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Background Information: We are a non-profit Indigenous organization that centers reconciliation on healing. For us this looks like having many different programs that are designed to help the urban Indigenous community be able to thrive in their life, such as our spirit bundle program that assists people with accessing free and healthy groceries, and our tutoring and sports program that uplifts Indigenous youth to better their education, learning, and skill development. Our centers are located in both Kitchener and Guelph to help broaden our reach to the community in all cities which includes Kitchener, Waterloo, Cambridge, and Guelph. Responsibilities of this volunteer role include:

Our centers are located in both Kitchener and Guelph to help broaden our reach to the community in all cities which includes Kitchener, Waterloo, Cambridge, and Guelph. Responsibilities of this volunteer role include: 1.To guide students through their homework and help the student fully comprehend the intended lesson. 2.To help student build and expand various skills including time management, communication, social, critical thinking, etc. 3.To be a support system for students when they may be feeling overwhelmed or discouraged by education. 4.To help explain opportunities from and through schooling to students so that they may find passions, interests, and pathways. 5.To help supervise and ensure the safety of all students by creating a safe workspace, ensuring students are following safety rules, and communicating thoroughly to the AO Tutoring and Sports team.

4.To help explain opportunities from and through schooling to students so that they may find passions, interests, and pathways. 5.To help supervise and ensure the safety of all students by creating a safe workspace, ensuring students are following safety rules, and communicating thoroughly to the AO Tutoring and Sports team. 6.To help create a fun, productive and supportive workspace through positivity and encouragement, ensuring all students are being respectful of other students, and more. 7.To lead games and activities while students are using the gym space Here is the link to our website that gives more information on the program and where students can register to become a tutor:

Review my preferences [LINK: /students/Settings] Description This workshop provides participants with a foundational knowledge of what sexual violence is and discusses what effective bystander intervention looks like.

Description This workshop provides participants with a foundational knowledge of what sexual violence is and discusses what effective bystander intervention looks like. There will be an opportunity to explore how you can intervene, and what the effects are of different intervention tactics. This workshop is part of the College Consent Culture series and will be presented by the Sexual Assault Support Centre of Waterloo Region [LINK: https://www.sascwr.org/] (SASC). Past workshop participants have said: "I truly enjoyed this workshop, and especially loved working through the scenarios at the end in order to apply the information in a practical manner” “This workshop was very helpful in terms of understanding the best strategies”. Description The Community of Health Care Research, facilitated by the Centre for Health Care Research & Innovation [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fresearch.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fcentre-for-health-care-research-and-innovation%3F%3FMcasTsid%3D20893&McasCSRF=887c92582d448243e9ea20c5e0372c52b0266ab73ba7eb418cabc140c5eefb2a] , aims to explore and discuss topics and questions about research in health care. The final Community meeting for the Spring term will be held from 1:00-2:00pm on Wednesday, August 6 . All are welcome to join (faculty, staff, students) and all levels of experience with research are welcome! Students who attend and participate in at least two Community meetings in a term are eligible to receive Co-Curricular Record (CCR) recognition. Review my preferences [LINK: /students/Settings] Description Ready to turn your food business idea into reality?

Description Ready to turn your food business idea into reality? Join us for an inspiring and practical session tailored for aspiring culinary and food entrepreneurs. Whether you’re dreaming of starting a bakery, food truck, catering service, or packaged goods brand, this event will walk you through the first steps—especially how to fund your venture. You’ll hear from successful entrepreneur Lenore Johnson , owner of LenJo Bakes , as she shares how she started her business, the funding options she explored, and what she learned along the way. We’ll also cover a range of funding pathways—from grants and loans to alternative models—so you can find the right fit for your idea. Whether you’re still shaping your concept or ready to get started, this session will give you the tools and confidence to move forward. Discover what’s possible—and how to pay for it. Starting your term off right for math success Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1470047] Things pick up quickly once the semester gets going. It is important to start the semester on the right foot and prepare yourself. Check out the tips below to help you start your math course with the right mindset. Get math help early Math builds on itself. Likely, what you learn in the first lesson of your math class will be needed throughout the course. Reach out to your instructor or book a math help appointment as soon as you are: Confused about a topic you learned in class. Stuck on a math practice problem. Preparing for a math test, quiz, etc. Remember, College provides free math help [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/math] for eligible students. Follow your instructional plan Your instructional plan will give you an overview of the topics to be covered in your math course.

Follow your instructional plan Your instructional plan will give you an overview of the topics to be covered in your math course. Set aside some time to check over the plan before your class, so you know what topics will be covered. Even if these topics are new to you, it’s good to prepare yourself for what will come next. Don't skip the first class The first class is when the instructor explains the overview of the course, what their expectations are for students and what students can expect from the instructor. You will benefit from attending this first class for many reasons, including: Getting an overview of the course in a nutshell. Receiving information on free college resources (like math help!). Learning where to locate textbooks and class materials. Experiencing the first lesson. Meeting others in the class. Meeting your instructor. Learning the instructor's office hours. Explore your eCollege course shell Every math class is different.

Explore your eCollege course shell Every math class is different. It’s important to explore your eCollege course shell for class notes, instructor announcements, and extra resources you may need during the course. Here are some things to explore in the course shell during the first week of classes: Location of class notes. Format of class notes (printable slides, videos, etc.). Calculator requirements. Pearson MyLab or Lyryx log in (if your instructor uses it). Online textbooks. Math help appointment booking instructions. Does your class use Pearson MyLab? The Study Plan feature is a great tool for extra practice and tracking progress. This video [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/videos/detail/12] walks you through how to use the Study Plan feature. Explore math resources outside of class There are many free, useful math resources available outside of the classroom, from graphing technology to interactive mini-lessons. We recommend exploring our list of

There are many free, useful math resources available outside of the classroom, from graphing technology to interactive mini-lessons. We recommend exploring our list of math content resources and exercises by topic [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/10] and that you save the 10 Math Success Strategies [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/90] in your notebook or on your bulletin board at home! Topics include functions, limits, derivatives, integrals. 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence Save Send Feedback 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence is an international campaign that runs every year from November 25 to December 10. Let's unite as a community to support survivors and advocate for a world free from violence. If you are looking for support, aren't sure what to do, or need someone to speak to, please reach out to College's Sexual & Gender-Based Violence Prevention & Support Office [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/sgbv] by emailing sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca] . Get involved throughout the 16 days. Below are actions you can take, events you can attend, and important resources you can use in our shared vision of living in a world free from harm. Date Action, Event, or Resource Monday, November 25 Action: Wear Purple to stand in solidarity for the elimination of violence against women. Event: Consent Culture Pop-Up Monday, November 25, 9:30am - 11:30am

Consent Culture Pop-Up Monday, November 25, 9:30am - 11:30am Doon Residence If you live in residence, come and say 'hello' and learn more about the work of College Consent Culture, and the 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence. Tuesday, November 26 Action: Learn about what makes a healthy relationship. How can we recognize and change unhealthy behaviours in the context of our relationships? What traits make a relationship healthy? Upcoming Event: College Consent Culture: Healthy Relationships Wednesday, November 27, 2pm - 3:30pm Join College Consent Culture and SASC Waterloo to learn all about healthy relationships. Register for the workshop [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events/detail/4784188] Wednesday, November 27 Attend Event: College Consent Culture: Healthy Relationships Register for the workshop [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events/detail/4784188] Thursday, November 28 Action:

Thursday, November 28 Action: Check out the social media post competition run by the School of Business at the Faculty Hub Window at the Downtown Kitchener Campus. Friday, November 29 Resource Highlight: Spectrum [LINK: https://ourspectrum.com/] Waterloo Region's Rainbow Community Space Saturday, November 30 Resource Highlight: Sexual Assault Centre (SAC) Brant [LINK: https://sacbrant.ca/] Sexual Assault Support Centre Sunday, December 1 Resource Highlight: Sexual Assault Support Centre (SASC) Waterloo Region [LINK: https://www.sascwr.org/] Sexual Assault Support Centre Monday, December 2 Resource Highlight: Guelph-Wellington Women in Crisis (GWWIC) [LINK: https://gwwomenincrisis.org/] Domestic violence shelter and sexual violence supports Tuesday, December 3 Action: Learn about the experience of trans community members by checking out Trans Pulse Canada. [LINK: https://transpulsecanada.ca/] Wednesday, December 4 Action: Educate yourself about gender-based violence. What does it mean?

Educate yourself about gender-based violence. What does it mean? How can it be stopped? What individual actions can be taken to create safer communities for all? Thursday, December 5 Action: Pick up a White Ribbon! These will be available at the Welcome Centre at Doon Campus, and the Welcome Desks at all other campuses. Resource Highlight: White Ribbon Canada [LINK: https://www.whiteribbon.ca/?lng=en] Dedicated to engaging men and boys in efforts to end gender-based violence Friday, December 6 Action: Wear your White Ribbon to acknowledge National Day of Remembrance and Action on Violence Against Women. White Ribbons can be picked up at your campus Welcome Desk, while supplies last. Saturday, December 7 Resource Highlight: Nova Vita Domestic Violence Prevention Services [LINK: https://novavita.org/] Domestic Violence Shelter Sunday, December 8 Resource Highlight: Sexual Assault and Violence Intervention Services (SAVIS) Halton [LINK: https://www.savisofhalton.org/]

Resource Highlight: Sexual Assault and Violence Intervention Services (SAVIS) Halton [LINK: https://www.savisofhalton.org/] Sexual Assault Support Centre Monday, December 9 Event: Consent Culture Pop-Up Monday, December 9, 11am - 1pm Brantford Campus Come by and learn more about the work of College Consent Culture! We'll have games and treats. Tuesday, December 10 Event: Human Rights Day [LINK: https://www.un.org/en/observances/human-rights-day] Featured Video Why do people get so anxious about math? [LINK: /students/Videos/detail/16/why-do-people-get-so-anxious-a] This TED-Ed video by Orly Rubinsten can help you understand math anxiety and looks at current research on the topic. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Check your College student email regularly for event updates. You can find campus events, webinars, and volunteer opportunities on the Student Success Portal [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/experiences/skills/providers?page=0] . Academic Integrity Violation Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4750611] If you have been accused of an academic integrity [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/academic-integrity?_gl=1*ld4duw*_gcl_au*MTE1MjgwODA1NS4xNzIxMjIyNDM4*_ga*MTg5MTk2Nzk2Ni4xNzE4MTI0ODc1*_ga_RN8C0HR85Y*MTcyMzY0NzE0OC4xLjEuMTcyMzY1Mjg4OC41MC4wLjE1NDU0ODk5NDQ.] violation, it is important to understand the seriousness of this situation. Academic integrity is about doing your schoolwork honestly and fairly. Additionally, you may discuss with your professor to better understand what is considered an academic integrity violation. You may also book an appointment with an Academic Integrity Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/academic-integrity] or seek support from a Peer Tutor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/tutoring] or Writing Consultant [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/writing] .

Writing Consultant [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/writing] . If you believe the violation was incorrectly applied, you may be eligible to submit an appeal [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts] . Assistance with appeals is available from the CSI Student Advocates [LINK: https://www.collegestudents.com/representation/academicappeals/] . Co-Curricular Record Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2201634] The Student Success Portal’s Events & Activities page gives you access to workshops, clubs, committees, volunteer roles, and recreational opportunities each term, many of which are eligible for Co-Curricular Record (CCR) recognition. How do I find opportunities that I can include on my CCR? From the Events & Activities page, use the search term “CCR” or click here [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-engagement/events?descending=false&endorsementIds=3195436&page=1&sortBy=Start&studentSiteId=17] for a list of opportunities eligible for recognition on your Co-Curricular Record. All full-time students also receive the Get Involved Guide each week in their College inbox with some highlighted opportunities for the upcoming week. How does the CCR support my student experience and my career trajectory?

All full-time students also receive the Get Involved Guide each week in their College inbox with some highlighted opportunities for the upcoming week. How does the CCR support my student experience and my career trajectory? It demonstrates that you are invested in your personal and professional growth. It shows the ways you seek out opportunities for meaningful involvement in the College community. Helps you develop competencies that will support your personal and professional growth. Helps you write your resume and articulate your learning experiences when applying to jobs, co-op positions, volunteer roles, scholarships, additional post-secondary programs, or any other instances when you may need to demonstrate skills and knowledge gained outside of your academic program. How do I get my ONE Card? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1341423] Please review the Get Your Card [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/onecard/get-your-card] webpage for instructions on uploading your ONE Card photo, information about how you will receive your card, and more. You can also read the ONE Card frequently asked questions. [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/onecard/faq] If you move after you upload your photo, please keep your address up to date on the Student Portal. Students living outside of Canada will not receive a physical copy of their ONE Card but have access to a digital copy on ONE Card Portal [LINK: https://onecard.collegec.on.ca/login.aspx?ReturnUrl=/] . For additional questions about ONE Card, please email ONECard@collegec.on.ca. Before Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      should arrive 15-minutes before their test start time to secure personal      items and complete check-in. Testing      appointments may be cancelled if students arrive more than 20-minutes late      from the indicated start time. Present      a non-expired physical photo ID (OneCard or government-issued      ID). Only      items required for the assessment will be permitted in the testing      room. All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre.

All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre. To      maintain a quiet and controlled testing environment for all test takers,      children are not permitted within the Test Centre and cannot be left      unattended while any student is writing. All      computer-based tests at the Test Centre will be conducted on assigned      desktop computers. Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test.

Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test. Please      note the Test Centres may not have power outlets for laptops. To      ensure a comfortable and healthy environment for everyone, Test Centres      are a designated scent-free zone. We kindly request that all individuals      refrain from wearing or using scented products. Only      water is permitted in the testing room (approved accommodations      excepted). Recording Devices Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2866660] Recording Devices All items are available to borrow for a two-week loan from the Teach Me Tech Lab (room 2A501) at Doon. Students at other campuses wishing to access these resources can do so by emailing us. [LINK: mailto:at@collegec.on.ca] Echo SmartPen The Echo SmartPen can record everything you hear, say, and write while linking your audio recordings to your notes. Lets you replay audio directly from paper by tapping on your notes. Device comes with: Bag USB Cable Headphones Notebook Learn how to use the Echo SmartPen (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35028253] Echo 2 SmartPen The Echo 2 SmartPen can record everything you hear, say, and write, while adding your audio recordings to your notes. Quickly replay audio from your Echo 2 SmartPen or mobile device with a simple tap on your handwritten notes. Device comes with: Bag USB Cable

Bag USB Cable Headphones Notebook Learn how to use the Echo 2 SmartPen (User Guide) [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=36735348] Olympus WS-853 Detailed recordings for all situations. The Olympus WS-853 is a digital voice recorder with two directional microphones positioned at a 90° layout. Recognized for its clear audio quality and superb operability, the WS-853 features Auto Mode, which automatically adjusts the recording level to match the volume of the sound source. Comes with 8 GB internal storage. Device comes with: Carrying case Learn how to use the Olympus WS853 recorder (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35027990] Phillips Voice Tracer 6010 The Philips Voice Tracer 6010 is ideal for lectures and interviews. The built-in motion sensor selects the microphone sensitivity to suit the recording situation, and its automatic zoom feature ensures superior distance recording and suppresses surrounding noises.

The Philips Voice Tracer 6010 is ideal for lectures and interviews. The built-in motion sensor selects the microphone sensitivity to suit the recording situation, and its automatic zoom feature ensures superior distance recording and suppresses surrounding noises. Comes with 8 GB internal storage. Device comes with: USB Cable Learn how to use the Philips Voice Tracer 6010 (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35027865] Phillips Voice Tracer LFH0882 The Philips Voice Tracer LFH0882 records up to 573 hours of data in 3 common MP3 mono formats and 3 stereo formats. This allows for a higher sampling rate and clearer recordings. Functioning as a USB mass storage device, any type of file can be conveniently stored and shared on the device. Request a Letter: Accepted, Enrolled, Graduated Save Send Feedback Do you need a letter stating that you have been accepted, enrolled or that you have graduated? Do you need a verification of enrolment letter for your Registered Education Savings Plan (RESP)? Do you need a special or customized letter for an employer, day care or insurance company? Do you have a document that requires an official College seal or stamp? Read the information below to access the letter you need and the process and fee associated with it. Online (Free of Charge) To generate a letter free of charge, log on to the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx] and select the ‘Services’ tab then select “Print A Letter’. You will be presented with a drop down box with the four letter types: Accepted and Confirmed Letter program title, start/end date, and session start/end date. Currently Enrolled Letter

program title, start/end date, and session start/end date. Currently Enrolled Letter program title, start date, full time status, program start/end date, session start/end date Proof of Program Completion Letter program title, program start date/completion date RESP – Verification of Enrolment program title, start date, co-op program, current start date, full-time status, program length, level entering and credential type Do not submit this letter to College, it must be submitted to the institution (e.g. bank) administering your RESP. NOTE: Online standard letters above cannot be modified to include additional or different information. Important Note Regarding Canada Pension Plan Canada Pension Plan (CPP) will accept the ‘Currently Enrolled’ letter. The letter must be dated after the start of the academic year. You must: Generate the letter after the start of the academic year/semester. Write “see attached" in Section B of the Declaration of Attendance at School or University.

Generate the letter after the start of the academic year/semester. Write “see attached" in Section B of the Declaration of Attendance at School or University. The ‘Currently Enrolled Letter” replaces the signature required on the form. Submit both the form and the online letter to the government. Specialized or Custom Letter (Charges Apply) If the online letter service does not suffice, you may request a special or customized letter by completing and submitting the Completion of Letter Form with payment to the Registrar’s Office. You may request to have the letter mailed to you or pick it up in person. Please allow a minimum 24-48 hours for processing and be prepared to provide photo identification for your request. In Person or by Fax (Charges Apply) You may request a letter by completing and submitting the Completion of Letter Form with payment to the Registrar’s Office in person or send by fax to (519) 895-1097.

In Person or by Fax (Charges Apply) You may request a letter by completing and submitting the Completion of Letter Form with payment to the Registrar’s Office in person or send by fax to (519) 895-1097. Please allow a minimum 24-48 hours for processing and be prepared to provide photo identification for your request. Letter and Documentation Verification Request Form If you require a letter or form to be verified with the College stamp or seal, you must bring the document(s) to the Registrar’s Office in person for verification and for the stamp or seal to be affixed. Please allow a minimum 24-48 hours for processing and be prepared to provide photo identification for your request. Attention International Students: Select the ‘Currently Enrolled’ letter for applications related to study permit extensions, Temporary Resident Visa’s, U.S. Visas etc. Once you have downloaded the letter, please email internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca]

Once you have downloaded the letter, please email internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca] with your student number to request instructions related to Citizenship and Immigration Canada applications. Please Note: If you need a letter related to working in Canada (off-campus, co-op, on-campus) and other Citizenship and Immigration Canada applications and information, please contact internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca] Featured Link Matrices and vectors practice [LINK: /students/Links/detail/35/matrices-and-vectors-practice] Matrices and vectors practice problems. Withdrawing (Program or Course) Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1957592] From a Program You can request a withdrawal from your program and/or refund on your Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] and click on Services > My Forms. For questions related to the withdrawal process, please email the Student Records department studentrecords@collegec.on.ca . For questions related to fees and refunds, please email Student Fees at studentfees@collegec.on.ca . Note that to be eligible for a refund, you must normally withdraw by the deadline - please see Academic Dates [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/academic-dates] . From a Course To withdraw from a course, log onto the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] , navigate to the "My Courses" tab, and select the course you wish to drop.

Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] , navigate to the "My Courses" tab, and select the course you wish to drop. If the "X" option is greyed out, complete the Course Change Request Form under the "Services" tab. Note that dropping a course may affect your full-time status and fees, so it is advisable to consult with Student Records if you plan to drop multiple courses. International students are strongly encouraged to discuss any program changes with their International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/immigration-information/book-an-appointment] first.
