​Terminology: Grade Point Averages Save Send Feedback College commonly uses two types of Grade Point Averages (GPAs): Term Weighted Average (TWA): Represents your average grade for a specific term (or semester). Program Weighted Average (PWA): Reflects your cumulative average across your entire program. Definitions of these GPAs and details on how they are calculated are available on the Registrar’s Grading and Transcripts [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts] webpage. Below, you will find a general overview as well as an explanation of older terminology that is gradually being phased out. Term Weighted Average The TWA represents the average grade achieved across all courses in a specific term (commonly referred to as a “semester”). This metric is used to assess your academic standing and progression in your program at the end of each term. There are three possible outcomes based on your TWA: Promotion with Good Academic Standing:

There are three possible outcomes based on your TWA: Promotion with Good Academic Standing: Your TWA meets or exceeds the minimum average to graduate from your program. Note that this is often higher than the minimum grade required to earn a credit in a specific course. For example, the minimum grade to pass a course might be 55% but you could be required to have an average of at least 60% to graduate. Promotion on Probation: Your TWA is below the minimum average required to graduate from your program. Typically, the range is within 5%, though it is important to confirm this by reviewing the academic handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] for your school. Important: If you are on probation for two consecutive terms (excluding scheduled breaks), you will be discontinued from the program. Program Discontinuance: You may need to pause your studies for at least one term. During this time, you can explore part-time courses or other program options.

You may need to pause your studies for at least one term. During this time, you can explore part-time courses or other program options. When to Use Term Weighted Average The TWA is particularly useful at the end of one term and the start of the next, as it helps determine your academic standing and next steps. Where to Find It You can view your TWA once all final grades are posted to your record by accessing your Achievement Report through the Grades tab in your Student Portal. Program Weighted Average The PWA represents the average of all your course grades throughout your entire program. Sometimes it is also called a “Cohort Weighted Average”. It plays a critical role in determining your eligibility to graduate. Meeting the graduation requirements involves more than simply passing your courses; you must also achieve a minimum overall average: Certificates and Diplomas: Typically, a minimum PWA of 60% is required. Degree Programs: Generally, a minimum PWA of 65% is needed.

Certificates and Diplomas: Typically, a minimum PWA of 60% is required. Degree Programs: Generally, a minimum PWA of 65% is needed. Specialized Programs: Some programs may have higher requirements to comply with external accreditation standards. Progression Requirements Guides for each school are available here: College College Academic Handbooks [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook] . When to Use Program Weighted Average The PWA is particularly useful if you are struggling in one or more courses. Mid-semester, it is important to evaluate how your current grades will impact your overall average and your ability to graduate in the future. Where to Find It Your PWA can be found in the “Achievement Report” section of the Student Portal. Older Terminology To improve clarity and usability, we have updated some key terms, and you will see this reflected in College policies: "Term Weighted Average" (TWA) replaces the older "Session Weighted Average"

(TWA) replaces the older "Session Weighted Average" when referring to your average grade for a specific term (or semester). "Program Weighted Average" (PWA) is now used instead of "Cohort Weighted Average" to describe the average grade across your entire program. These updates aim to make the terminology more intuitive and reflective of their specific purposes. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infoPages/detail/3/how-do-i-take-notes] Featured FAQ What Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP) am I eligible for if my program is a two-year program completed in sixteen months? [LINK: /students/Faqs/detail/25/what-post-graduation-work-perm] For a two-year program completed in sixteen months, the program length is considered to be two years and, therefore, you should be eligible for a three-year PGWP. You can find your program length on the program webpage or on your Letter of Acceptance (LOA). Supplemental Assessment Save Send Feedback To be eligible for a supplemental assessment, you must meet specific criteria, such as completing all term work, having no academic integrity violations, and being within 3% of the passing grade. You are also limited to one supplemental assessment per term. If you meet these criteria, contact your Program Coordinator or Faculty to proceed. You can find information about your Program Coordinator in the Academic Handbooks [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] . Appealing a Course Grade Save Send Feedback Course grade appeals should be based on procedural errors, technical issues, or medical/compassionate grounds, not on dissatisfaction with the grade itself. For more details, review the Academic Dispute Resolution and Appeal Procedure under "Academic Administration" on the policies webpage [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/about/corporate-information/policies] . To appeal a course grade, you must email the faculty with the subject labeled ‘Course Appeal.’ In the email, you must describe the issues, including copies of emails, proof of work completed, and any other pertinent details. You must wait five business days for the faculty to respond to your email. If the faculty does not change their decision or respond, complete these steps in the Academic Appeal Request found on the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] under ‘My Services’ > ‘My Forms’. The

under ‘My Services’ > ‘My Forms’. The CSI also provides assistance [LINK: https://www.collegestudents.com/representation/academicappeals/] to students who are seeking an academic appeal. Course Grade Appeal Procedure Does your concern meet the scope and criteria for an appeal? Consult the Academic Dispute Resolution and Appeal Procedure (see the policies link above). If your concern does not meet the scope or criteria identified in the procedure, you cannot submit an appeal. Step 1: Faculty Contact your professor or program coordinator to discuss your issue. If your concerns are not addressed or resolved within 5 days, move to step 2. *Please note, the deadline to begin Step 1 is within five working days of receipt of the grade or academic decision. Step 2: Submit Appeal Form (Appeal to Chair) Submit an appeal form and attach supporting documentation from Step 1. Your Chair will review the appeal request and make a decision within 5 working days.

Submit an appeal form and attach supporting documentation from Step 1. Your Chair will review the appeal request and make a decision within 5 working days. To submit an appeal form, sign onto the Student Portal, select the ‘Service’ tab, click the ‘My Forms’ button. Step 3: Continue Appeal Form (Appeal to Dean) The appeal form will provide the option to continue to Step 3 if your Step 2 appeal is denied. Your Dean will review the appeal request and make a decision within 5 working days. Step 4: Continue Appeal Form (Appeal to Registrar) The appeal form will provide the option to continue to Step 4 if your Step 3 appeal is denied. The Registrar will review the appeal request and make a decision within 10 working days. Discontinuance and Reapplying Save Send Feedback The college will discontinue students who have a Term Weighted Average of less than 49.99% (for most programs) or have failed to clear probation after two consecutive terms. However, students should refer to their Academic Handbook Progression Requirements Guide [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide#appendices] for program specific requirements. Discontinued students are ineligible to register in their original Program of Studies for a minimum of one term. They can apply to another college program, if it doesn’t share a common platform to the program they were discontinued from. If a student wants to return to their original program after the discontinuance period, they must apply for re-admission. Please see the Discontinuance Procedure [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/policies/discontinuance-procedure] and Readmission Procedure [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/policies/readmission-procedure]

and Readmission Procedure [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/policies/readmission-procedure] for more information. Accessing Your Timetable Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1341425] Your timetable is located on your Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] under Calendar > My Timetable. To be able to view your timetable, you must complete all the steps required for registration. See the Registration Help [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/current-students/returning-students] webpage for more information about timetables. Registration information for international students [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/apply-to-college/complete-your-registration] includes detailed instructions on completing all required steps. Once you have completed the steps for registration, it will take a minimum of 24 hours for your timetable to appear in your Student Portal. If you have completed all the steps and still cannot see your timetable, please contact: First year (level 1) international students: email

Ontario Student Assistance Program (OSAP) Save Send Feedback OSAP is designed to assist eligible students in Ontario with funding their postsecondary education. To be eligible for OSAP, you must meet the following criteria: Citizenship or Residency: You must be a Canadian citizen, Permanent Resident, or Protected Person Ontario Residency: You need to be an Ontario resident and have lived in Ontario for at least 12 months prior to the start of your post-secondary education. This is the process for applying for OSAP: Application: To apply for OSAP, visit the official OSAP website [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/page/osap-ontario-student-assistance-program] and complete the application form. Please ensure that all required information is accurately provided. Processing Time: After submitting your OSAP application, the processing time is typically 6 to 8 weeks. However, please be aware that this timeframe may vary if additional information or documents are requested. Check Status:

However, please be aware that this timeframe may vary if additional information or documents are requested. Check Status: You can keep track of your application’s status by using the ‘Check Status’ link on your OSAP account. This will also allow you to view updates, communications, and any required documents. Disbursement of OSAP Funding Once you have paid your tuition deposit, completed your OSAP application, and received an OSAP assessment, your student account will be updated to reflect your OSAP payment. The Ministry of Colleges and Universities will confirm your enrollment approximately 10 days before classes commence. After this confirmation, your OSAP funding will be released within 7 to 10 business days. A portion of your funding intended for tuition will be directed to the college, and any remaining funds (if applicable) will be deposited into the bank account you have specified with the

After this confirmation, your OSAP funding will be released within 7 to 10 business days. A portion of your funding intended for tuition will be directed to the college, and any remaining funds (if applicable) will be deposited into the bank account you have specified with the National Student Loans Service Centre [LINK: https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method] (NSLSC). If you have any questions or require further assistance regarding your OSAP application or financial matters, please feel free to contact our Financial Aid Office: osap@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:osap@collegec.on.ca] . Changing Programs Save Send Feedback You must first identify a new program that is 'open’ to students by reviewing the list on the Open Programs [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/fulltime/open-programs] webpage. If you need help deciding which program is the best match for your career goal, you can book an appointment with a Career Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/career] or email careerservices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:CareerServices@collegec.on.ca] . Once you have confirmed the new program you would like to apply to, you must withdraw from your current program. You can find the Withdrawal Form on the student portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] click: SERVICES > MY FORMS > WITHDRAWAL FORM. Please be aware that you may choose to withdraw from your studies immediately or you may select the option to withdraw at the end of the current term. International Students

Please be aware that you may choose to withdraw from your studies immediately or you may select the option to withdraw at the end of the current term. International Students For international students, once you withdraw, you may not be eligible to work until you receive a new offer letter. International students are strongly encouraged to discuss any program changes with their International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/immigration-information/book-an-appointment] (ISIA) first . To apply to a new program, you will use the OCAS application portal and follow the steps you followed when you initially applied to college. You can have your original account re-opened by emailing the International Admissions team at internationaladmissions@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:internationaladmissions@collegec.on.ca] . After a successful acceptance into the new program, any balance in your student account will be applied to your new program.

. After a successful acceptance into the new program, any balance in your student account will be applied to your new program. Already Completed Courses If you wish to change your program after completing some courses, you must first withdraw from your current program (see above) and apply to the new one through an Advanced Standing Application Form (see the Registrar [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/student-forms] for more information). A $35 processing fee is charged during the submission. Ensure all required information is accurately completed to avoid delays. If you are an international student, consult your ISIA to understand how the change may affect your study permit. Payment Plans for Tuition & Fees Save Send Feedback College College does not offer traditional installment plans or payment extensions. However, eligible students in Level 2 or higher can opt into a Payment Schedule, which allows for 50% of the fees to be paid by the due date, with the remaining 50% due three days before classes start. A fee applies for opting into this schedule. To set up the Payment Schedule, confirm your invoice on the Student Portal and pay 50% of the due amount. International students are assigned an ISIA based on their program. You can book an appointment with your assigned ISIA on the Student Success Portal. Winter 2025: Interim Semester for Discontinued Students Save Send Feedback Join the General Arts and Science (GAS) Interim Semester (0791), which allows you to maintain full-time status (on probation). Courses available during the Interim Semester: COMM 2210 (or 1085 if you were not successful in this course) MDIA1070 – Information, Data and Current Events (GenEd) SOC1140 Canada in the Future (GenEd) Two Program Electives that can be selected from your original program or the GAS electives list. After the Interim Semester If you clear probation, you can register for your original program using an Advanced Standing application for any level beyond Level 1. If you need to start in Level 1, you must reapply through OCAS. If you are unsuccessful in the interim semester, you will be discontinued and must apply for another program. The Interim Semester is not an option for two consecutive terms. Important Notes

The Interim Semester is not an option for two consecutive terms. Important Notes The interim semester does not replace or override the "discontinuance requirement" from your current program. Students must still meet the waiting period for discontinuance as indicated in the notice from your academic area before being able to continue in your original program. Not all elective courses taken in the interim semester will work towards your desired program of study. Please speak with your Student Success Advisor or Program Coordinator when choosing electives. International Students must remain in compliance with requirements set out by Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) to be eligible for a post-graduate work permit (PGWP). Please speak with an International Student Immigration Advisor (ISIA) for clarification about these rules. Here are some questions you might ask them:

Please speak with an International Student Immigration Advisor (ISIA) for clarification about these rules. Here are some questions you might ask them: "Since I started my studies at College College before the changes to IRCC policy, am I able to change my two-year diploma program to a 1-year certificate and still be eligible for a PGWP?" "Can I combine two different 1-year certificates to be eligible for a PGWP that will be up to 3 years long?" "How will taking a whole term of online courses through the interim semester affect my eligibility for PGWP?" Students receiving OSAP funding for their program will need to check with their funding agency to confirm that their tuition can be applied towards the interim semester. Please contact the Registrar's Office for questions about tuition and fees. Continuing Education courses are not a part of the GAS Interim Semester and are subject to additional fees. Next Steps Please

Next Steps Please see your SSA [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-success-advising] to explore whether the interim semester is right for you, and for assistance with the process of getting registered. You have opted not to reveal your name and email address to providers of events you book into. Review my preferences [LINK: /s/student-engagement/Settings] Description This
workshop is part of the Getting Started Series. What does a healthy relationship actually look, sound, and feel like? What are “red flags” that someone may be trying to control or harm us? This workshop explores the characteristics of healthy, unhealthy, and abusive relationships, and critically examines the role that consent, boundaries, and communication have in forming and nurturing healthy relationships. Learning Objectives: Learn positive skills for healthy communication, boundaries, and mutual support Understand the nuances of communicating digitally in a respectful, supportive manner Identify harmful behaviors, with a focus on digital harm Learn resources for support This workshop is part of the College Consent Culture series and will be presented by the

Learn resources for support This workshop is part of the College Consent Culture series and will be presented by the Sexual Assault Support Centre of Waterloo Region [LINK: https://www.sascwr.org/] (SASC). Past workshop participants have said: “This workshop taught me how to recognize boundaries through other peoples’ actions, mannerisms, and tone of voice.” Endorsements CCR ENDORSED Co-Curricular Record Other information Email: Jdoroshenko@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:Jdoroshenko@collegec.on.ca] Providers College Consent Culture (CCC) [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/Detail/2198852] Primary Skills Communication [LINK: /s/student-engagement/skills/providers?skillIds=5] Equity, Diversity, & Inclusion [LINK: /s/student-engagement/skills/providers?skillIds=7] More 'Workshops and Training' events SHINE Wellness Series: Rewriting your Personal Narrative [LINK: /s/student-engagement/Events/Detail/5264738]

I want to work while I’m studying at College – how can I find a job? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4086179] When looking for work, it is important to find something that will allow you to prioritize your studies. Even if you can work full-time hours (35+ hours per week) you should apply to part-time jobs as these types of jobs usually have flexible schedules. Please be mindful of the hours that you work; succeeding in your studies should be your top priority. Watch our video series on tips for part-time job searching [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LKbOtK4ljs8&list=PLG_bXxTyZqB3J6-0V9dDL20kQgAqfZ-Dz] . Visit the Career Services page [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/career] for resources (sample resumes, tip sheets, and more) and to register for workshops about part-time job searching. Hours involved Calculate hours URL Description None [LINK: #] None [LINK: #] From a Program You can request a withdrawal from your program and/or refund on your Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] and click on Services > My Forms. For questions related to the withdrawal process, please email the Student Records department studentrecords@collegec.on.ca .

studentrecords@collegec.on.ca . For questions related to fees and refunds, please email Student Fees at studentfees@collegec.on.ca . Note that to be eligible for a refund, you must normally withdraw by the deadline - please see Academic Dates [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/academic-dates] . From a Course To withdraw from a course, log onto the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] , navigate to the "My Courses" tab, and select the course you wish to drop. If the "X" option is greyed out, complete the Course Change Request Form under the "Services" tab. Note that dropping a course may affect your full-time status and fees, so it is advisable to consult with Student Records if you plan to drop multiple courses. International students are strongly encouraged to discuss any program changes with their

International students are strongly encouraged to discuss any program changes with their International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/immigration-information/book-an-appointment] first. What is considered to be a regularly scheduled break for an international student? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1970505] According to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), a regularly scheduled break must be part of the designated learning institution's (DLI) academic calendar. Walk-in Clinics Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/3461120] Walk-in clinics and urgent care centers provide medical care for people who do not have a primary care health provider, or have one but are unable to reach them. You can see a nurse or doctor without an appointment for minor illness and injuries, but often there is a line or longer wait times. When you go to a walk-in clinic or urgent care center, you need to bring your College International Health Insurance Plan card (for international students) or your OHIP card (for Ontario residents). If you live in Waterloo or Kitchener, here is a list of walk-in clinics that you can visit: 1. Benton Medical Centre [LINK: http://www.bentonmedicalclinic.com] 51 Benton St, Kitchener 226-240-3014 2. KW Healthy Living Family Practice [LINK: http://www.kwmedicalcentre.com] 1360 Weber St E, Kitchener 519-893-6060 3. KW Urgent Care Clinics [LINK: http://www.kwurgentcare.ca/]

3. KW Urgent Care Clinics [LINK: http://www.kwurgentcare.ca/] 385 Fairway Rd S, Kitchener 519-748-2327 751 Victoria St S, Kitchener 519-745-2273 4. K-W Walk-In Clinic [LINK: https://waterlooclinic.com/] 100 The Boardwalk, Kitchener (Walmart) 519-279-4098 5. Kitchener Walk-In Clinic [LINK: https://www.kitchenerwalkin.ca/] 5 Manitou Drive, Kitchener 519-904-4200 6. Laurentian Walk-in Clinic [LINK: https://www.wwhealthline.ca/displayservice.aspx?id=101690] 750 Ottawa St S, Kitchener (Zehrs) 519-570-3174 7. Onyx Urgent Care [LINK: https://onyxurgentcare.com/] 580 Lancaster St W, Kitchener 519-896-6699 8. Spruce Medical Walk-in Clinic [LINK: http://www.sprucemedical.ca] 318 Spruce St, Unit 105, Waterloo 519-725-1111 9. Tannery Medical Centre 120-121 Charles St W, Kitchener 519-618-9260 10. Waterloo Walk-in Clinic [LINK: https://waterlooclinic.com/] University Shops Plaza II 170 University Ave W, Unit 13, Waterloo 519-725-1514 11.

519-725-1514 11. Westmount Place Walk-In Clinic [LINK: https://waterlooclinic.com/] 50 Westmount Rd N, Waterloo 519-954-0111 If you live outside of Waterloo or Kitchener, you can find your nearest walk-in clinic or urgent care center by searching “walk-in clinic near me” on your preferred internet browser. Featured FAQ How can I open a bank account as an international student? [LINK: /students/Faqs/detail/29/how-can-i-open-bank-account-as] The process and documents required for opening a bank account in Canada depends on which bank you select. If you already have a GIC with a Canadian bank, you may want to consider doing all your banking with that bank. Hours involved Calculate hours URL Description None [LINK: #] None [LINK: #] When looking for work, it is important to find something that will allow you to prioritize your studies. Even if you can work full-time hours (35+ hours per week) you should apply to part-time jobs as these types of jobs usually have flexible schedules.

When looking for work, it is important to find something that will allow you to prioritize your studies. Even if you can work full-time hours (35+ hours per week) you should apply to part-time jobs as these types of jobs usually have flexible schedules. Please be mindful of the hours that you work; succeeding in your studies should be your top priority. Watch our video series on tips for part-time job searching [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LKbOtK4ljs8&list=PLG_bXxTyZqB3J6-0V9dDL20kQgAqfZ-Dz] . Visit the Career Services page [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/career] for resources (sample resumes, tip sheets, and more) and to register for workshops about part-time job searching. Math learning and study strategies Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1467736] Not sure what areas of math you need help with? Use the math self-assessment tool [LINK: https://tlp-lpa.ca/math/self-assessments] to find out. Math learning strategies Make sure you are comfortable with the foundational math topics, including: Whole number operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, square root) Fraction operations Reducing fractions (proper, improper, mixed numbers) Decimal operations and place value Order of operations Percent Ratios, rates and proportions A great way to improve your learning is to start thinking about your thinking. Check out this video [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/videos/detail/13] on starting to think about your thinking and save this document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/91] to look back on during your semester.

document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/91] to look back on during your semester. College classes are much different than high school. This video will walk you through how to learn in post-secondary lectures [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/lil.html] . You can also save this document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/92] to bring with you to class. Learning math online and in person can be different. This video will show you how to be successful in an online math class [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/videos/detail/14] . Check out these tips to improve math learning : Complete homework/practice questions Check your work after you have solved a problem and fix your mistakes right away (so you do not repeat them) Re-do example problems from class independently Re-do problems from tests and assignments that were wrong Re-watch class recordings (if available)

Re-do problems from tests and assignments that were wrong Re-watch class recordings (if available) Ask questions during class when things are unclear Ask the instructor questions outside of class when things are unclear Ask friends for help Sit at the front of the classroom Take notes in class Finish assignments a day or two early to leave time to ask questions Use online math resources outside of course resources Practice a little bit every day Seek help from a tutor Use the calculator you will be using on tests when practicing Practice pre-requisite basic concepts (one topic at a time) Be sure to download our Math Learning Strategies Checklist [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/157] as well to help you stay on track. Math test-taking strategies Not sure how to study for a math test or exam? Are your current math study habits not working as they did in high school? This video [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/es.html]

This video [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/es.html] discusses how to study effectively for math tests and exams. You can also save or print this document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/93] to look back on while you're studying. More test-taking tips: Preparing for math tests, creating formula sheets and creating summary reviews [LINK: https://tlp-lpa.ca/math/preparing-for-tests] Featured FAQ When should I apply for a co-op work permit (CWP)? [LINK: /students/Faqs/detail/11/when-should-i-apply-for-co-op-] Due to long CWP application processing times, it is recommended that you apply for the CWP together with your study permit, even if the acceptance letter includes an optional co-op. Understanding Math Anxiety Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1470053] Understanding math anxiety Math anxiety is more than just disliking math. Sometimes you may feel: Fear of making mistakes, lack of confidence in math. Fast heart beating, sweatiness, nausea when anticipating or engaging in math tasks. Wanting to quit when confused or making mistakes in math. Stress before evaluations such as tests, quizzes and exams. Nervous before math class. Procrastination of math homework or assignments. Unable to concentrate on a math task. Does math anxiety affect math ability? The video below explains more about what math anxiety is and does to your brain when you're experiencing it. Math anxiety and working memory Our working memory is a system in our brain responsible for temporarily storing and manipulating information and is essential when solving most math problems. Our working memory can store very limited amounts of information.

Our working memory is a system in our brain responsible for temporarily storing and manipulating information and is essential when solving most math problems. Our working memory can store very limited amounts of information. The amount of information our working memory can store at one time is sometimes referred to a s cognitive load. When our cognitive load has reached its maximum capacity, we stop processing information. Elevated levels of anxiety can affect working memory, decreasing its efficiency. This is not permanent and only occurs for the duration of time that the anxiety lasts. Since math requires working memory, trying to do math under high levels of anxiety can at times feel impossible. So what does this mean? Anxiety can affect math performance no matter how good someone is at math. Our math skills may be just fine and we need to tackle the anxiety!

Anxiety can affect math performance no matter how good someone is at math. Our math skills may be just fine and we need to tackle the anxiety! When we learn to reduce the anxiety we feel when doing or anticipating math tasks, our working memory can process information much more easily and efficiently, making things seem more manageable. Myths about math Math comes with its stereotypes. Here are three things that are not true about math: People of different race and sex have varying innate math ability There is a best way to solve a math problem You have to have a 'math brain' to understand math Debunking math stereotypes can shed some positive light on the subject and our ability to improve our math skills. The next time you hear someone say any of the things above, remember they are not true! Strategies for overcoming and managing math anxiety The following strategies are things you can start doing today to help manage and overcome math anxiety.

Strategies for overcoming and managing math anxiety The following strategies are things you can start doing today to help manage and overcome math anxiety. This list is not exhaustive and some things may work better for some people than others. There is no particular order in which you have to follow the strategies. Try whichever ones resonate best with you! Strengthen foundational math knowledge Math builds on itself. Imagine trying to calculate 5+7−4 without knowing how addition or subtractions works. This would be extremely difficult and could lead to things like lack of confidence, defeat, and frustration. Having strong foundational knowledge of the prerequisite skills needed for the math you are required to do will make things easier. When you attempt to solve a math problem without the required foundational knowledge, your working memory can become overloaded. Cognitive load is the amount of information that can be stored in working memory at one time.

When you attempt to solve a math problem without the required foundational knowledge, your working memory can become overloaded. Cognitive load is the amount of information that can be stored in working memory at one time. The weaker your foundational math knowledge is, the more resources are taken up in working memory when solving a math problem, increasing cognitive load and leaving fewer brain resources for the steps required to solve the problem at hand. With a stronger math foundation, more working memory resources can be allocated to solving the problem at hand, and less on trying to understand the basics at the same time. The stronger our basics, the more math confidence you can build. Not sure what foundational knowledge you need to strengthen? Check out this list of foundational math skills. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/9] Find math learning strategies that work for you On the

Find math learning strategies that work for you On the math learning page [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/9] you can find a list of math learning strategies you can try. You can keep track of the strategies you have used in a Strategies Checklist Chart [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/157] . Not all math learning strategies will work for everyone. It is important that you find the ones that work for you. Implementing a math learning strategy will improve understanding, help to develop skills and increase confidence. More learning and study strategies can be found on the Learning & Study Skills page. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/learningstudyskills] Regular math practice Practicing math by solving math problems is essential to gaining stronger math understanding.

Regular math practice Practicing math by solving math problems is essential to gaining stronger math understanding. Studies [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fuweb.cas.usf.edu.mcas.ms%2F~drohrer%2Fpdfs%2FHartwig_et_al_2022JEPA.pdf%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] show that spacing out math practice over a period of time rather than completing it all-at-once helps knowledge retention. Diaphragm breathing Diaphragm breathing is a breathing technique that engages the diaphragm (a muscle at the base of our lungs and heart). This breathing technique can help to calm us by lowering heartbeat and stabilizing blood pressure (Learning Diaphragmatic Breathing, 2016) The video below is a demonstration of how to breath with your diaphragm: More math anxiety resources:

The video below is a demonstration of how to breath with your diaphragm: More math anxiety resources: Embracing failure [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fsuccessportal.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fstudents%2Fvideos%2Fdetail%2F20%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] to benefit your academic and personal growth. Download this document [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fsuccessportal.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fstudents%2Fdocs%2FDetail%2F94%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] on embracing failure.

document [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fsuccessportal.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fstudents%2Fdocs%2FDetail%2F94%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] on embracing failure. Hours involved Calculate hours URL Description None [LINK: #] None [LINK: #] Second program applications can be submitted while you are studying in your current program or after you have completed your first program at College. As programs fill quickly, you are encouraged to submit your application as early as possible. The International Office manages all second program applications for existing students.

As programs fill quickly, you are encouraged to submit your application as early as possible. The International Office manages all second program applications for existing students. The admissions team creates the new application internally and ensures access to OCAS is given so you can access your acceptance once it is issued. To apply Complete the second program application form [LINK: https://forms.office.com/r/8pii9iV5qP] . Once your form has been submitted, please allow up to 14 business days to process your request. An application fee is not required for most second program applications, however, some exceptions apply. Important: Program and campus changes are not permitted once an acceptance letter has been issued. Ensure your personal information, including your local Canadian address, is up-to-date in the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx] . Applications will be evaluated on a first-come, first-served basis.

. Applications will be evaluated on a first-come, first-served basis. Applications must be received no later than three weeks prior to the start of the term. International Admissions does not maintain waitlists for programs. If your program of interest is closed, there is no guarantee that your request can be accommodated. Electives (Part-Time) Save Send Feedback To enroll in part-time degree electives, visit the Degree Electives Course List. You must register through the Part-time Studies Course Registration Form, which opens on the first day of classes. Submit your form early to secure a spot on your desired course, as availability is limited. There are two ways to add courses through the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] : Option A: Under the 'My Courses' tab Click ‘Browse Continuing Education’ tab. Search for the course you would like to add. Click ‘Details’ Click on white box of the section you would like to enter Click ‘Add to Cart’ On the left side of the screen, click ‘Checkout and Enroll’ Click ‘Confirm Address’ Scroll to the bottom of the page and click ‘Save’ Click ‘Online Payment’ Follow the payment instructions to pay Option B: Add course(s) under the My Forms tab (Laserfiche): Click ‘Services’ tab > My Forms

Add course(s) under the My Forms tab (Laserfiche): Click ‘Services’ tab > My Forms Log into Laserfiche (Using eCollege login info) Complete the Laserfiche digital Part-time Course Registration Form in full. Notes You can only add up to 3 courses per form. If you have more than 3 courses submit multiple forms. Click Submit and save/email yourself a copy of the confirmation form. Be patient and watch your College email address for updates. Payment is expected within 72 hours (about 3 days) to finalize your registration, or you will lose your seat in the course. Please carefully follow instructions sent to you via your College email address to make payment. You may also be interested in this

Please carefully follow instructions sent to you via your College email address to make payment. Download the iCent app from Google Play or the App Store. Enter "Canada: as your destination country and "College College" as your institution name. Enter your College Credentials (College student email address). A security PIN will be sent to your student email address for verification. Use this PIN to log into the iCent app and follow the instructions on the Mandatory Start Questionnaire. Hours involved Calculate hours URL Description None [LINK: #] None [LINK: #] Students who are enrolled full-time during the academic sessions before and after a regularly scheduled break and who decide to undertake a full-time or part-time course load during their scheduled program break are eligible to work off campus on a full-time basis.

Students who are enrolled full-time during the academic sessions before and after a regularly scheduled break and who decide to undertake a full-time or part-time course load during their scheduled program break are eligible to work off campus on a full-time basis. If a program of study does not provide a scheduled program break and a student chooses to take their own break from the program, it is considered a leave from studies and it is not a scheduled program break. Students who take a leave from studies are not eligible to work on or off-campus during that break. Providers A provider is a person or organisation related to this experience. If you are eligible for a program change, you can view program availability under "Open Programs" on the College College Full-time Programs website here [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/fulltime/open-programs] . Campus changes are not permitted during your first year of studies. Following toggle tip provides clarification Skip to content [LINK: https://open.math.uwaterloo.ca/1#inner] Help Frequently Asked Questions [LINK: faq.do] System Requirements [LINK: https://www.digitaled.com/products/system-requirements.aspx] How to Enter Math [LINK: mathHelp.do] Contact Us [LINK: contact.do] Toggle navigation System Homepage Linear Algebra 1 [LINK: /1] Class Homepage Linear Algebra 1 This is the courseware for MATH 136: Linear Algebra 1 for Honours Mathematics at the University of Waterloo. Topics include systems of linear equations, matrix algebra, elementary matrices, and computational issues. Other areas of the course focus on the real n-space, vector spaces and subspaces, basis and dimension, rank of a matrix, linear transformations and matrix representations. Determinants, eigenvalues and diagonalization, and their applications are also explored. Units Vectors in Euclidean Space [LINK: #unit-5] Systems of Linear Equations [LINK: #unit-3]

Vectors in Euclidean Space [LINK: #unit-5] Systems of Linear Equations [LINK: #unit-3] Matrices and Linear Mappings [LINK: #unit-4] Vector Spaces [LINK: #unit-1] Inverses and Determinants [LINK: #unit-2] Diagonalization [LINK: #unit-6] Vectors in Euclidean Space In this module, we will look at basic properties of vectors in Euclidean space. This setting will allow us to use geometric interpretations to introduce the important concepts of spanning, linear independence, and bases. Lesson: Vector Addition and Scalar Multiplication [LINK: 1/5/assignments/204] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/204] Lesson: Properties of Vectors and Spanning [LINK: 1/5/assignments/203] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/203] Lesson: Linear Independence and Surfaces [LINK: 1/5/assignments/202] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/202] Quiz: Vector Addition and Scalar Multiplication [LINK: 1/5/assignments/21] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/21] Lesson: Subspaces [LINK: 1/5/assignments/201] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/201]

Lesson: Subspaces [LINK: 1/5/assignments/201] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/201] Quiz: Subspaces [LINK: 1/5/assignments/22] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/22] Lesson: Dot Product and Cross Product [LINK: 1/5/assignments/206] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/206] Quiz: Dot Product, Cross Product, and Scalar Equations [LINK: 1/5/assignments/39] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/39] Lesson: Scalar Equation of a Plane and Projections [LINK: 1/5/assignments/205] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/205] Quiz: Projections [LINK: 1/5/assignments/40] Start [LINK: 1/5/assignments/40] Systems of Linear Equations Already we have seen many cases in linear algebra where it is required to solve m equations in n unknowns — for example, when determining whether a vector is in the span of a set of vectors, when determining if a set of vectors is linearly independent, or when calculating the formula for the cross product. We will see that there are many other cases where we need to do this.

unknowns — for example, when determining whether a vector is in the span of a set of vectors, when determining if a set of vectors is linearly independent, or when calculating the formula for the cross product. We will see that there are many other cases where we need to do this. Additionally, such problems not only arise in linear algebra, but in many other areas of mathematics, science, economics, business, et cetera. In real-world situations, we could easily have thousands of equations and thousands of variables. Thus, it is important to learn and understand the theory behind this, and not just simply memorize the method for solving small systems. Matrices and Linear Mappings In this module, we will look at matrices as objects rather than just as a tool for solving systems of linear equations. In doing so, we will be led to the idea of linear mappings. Vector Spaces In this module, we will extend lots of what we did with vectors in R n to general vector spaces.

n to general vector spaces. In particular, we will look at spanning, linear independence, subspaces, and bases. We will then use this theory to precisely define dimension, and to look at coordinates of a vector with respect to a basis. Inverses and Determinants In this module, we will look at properties of invertible matrices, how to determine if a matrix is invertible using the determinant, and some of the uses of invertible matrices and determinants. Diagonalization We now look at one of the most important and useful pieces of linear algebra — diagonalization. In this module, we will need to use material from every module. Algebra Practice Test Test your knowledge of introductory Algebra with this Algebra practice exam. Whether you are studying for a school math test or looking to test your math skills, this free practice test will challenge your knowledge of algebra. View Answers as You Go View 1 Question at a Time 1. -3ab + 4ac - 2ad = -(3ab - 4ac + 2ad) True False -3ab + 4ac - 2ad = -(3ab - 4ac + 2ad) -3ab + 4ac - 2ad = -3ab + 4ac - 2ad Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 2. A father gave $500 to his two sons. He gave X dollars to one son. Which of the following expressions correctly shows the amount he gave to the other son. a. $500 +  X b. $500 ÷ X c. $500 x X d. $500 - X If X represents the amount given to one son, $500 - X represents the amount given to the other son. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 3. Solve X where 5X = 20. a. 4 b. 5 c. 10 d. 15 5X = 20 X = 20 ÷ 5 X = 4 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 4. Solve X where X - 5 = 15. a. 10 b. 15 c. 20 d.

20 d. 25 X - 5 = 15 X = 15 + 5 X = 20 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 5. Solve X where 3X + 7 - 2 = 8. a. 1 b. 2 c. 3 d. 4 3X + 7 - 2 = 8 3X + 5 = 8 3X = 3 X = 3 ÷ 3 X = 1 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 6. Irene is N years old. If Tom is twice as old, which of the following algebraic statements shows his age now? a. 2N b. 2N + X c. 2 - N d. N - 2 If Irene is N years old and Tom is twice as old as Irene, the algebraic formula to show how old Tom is would be 2 x N or 2N. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 7. John has B bats and buys C bats more. He then gives away D bats. Which of the following algebraic statements corretly shows how many bats John has left? a. D - BC b. B - C - D c. B + C - D d. B + D + C If John starts with B bats and buys C more bats, the total number of bats John has would be represented by the formula B + C. When John gives D bats away, the sum of B + C would subtract D bats to determine how many he has left.

If John starts with B bats and buys C more bats, the total number of bats John has would be represented by the formula B + C. When John gives D bats away, the sum of B + C would subtract D bats to determine how many he has left. So, the formula is B + C - D. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 8. What is the representation algebraically of the cost of L feet of lumber at Y dollars per foot? a. L + Y b. LY c. L / Y d. L - Y There are a variety of ways to show multiplication, L x Y. LY L · Y (L)(Y) Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 9. 3x + 6x = a. 3x b. 9 + 2 x c. 9x d. 9x + 2 3x + 6x = 9x Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 10. 5a + 2b - b + 4a = a. 9a + b b. a + b c. 7a - 3b d. 6a 5a + 2b - b + 4a = 5a + 4a + 2b - b = 9a + b Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 11. Find the value of 3abc, where a = 2, b = 3 and c = 4. a. 12 b. 27 c. 72 d. 82 If a = 2, b = 3 and c = 4, 3abc = 3(2)(3)(4) = 6 x 12 = 72 Incorrect answer.

6 x 12 = 72 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 12. The sum of a certain number and 3 times the number is 40. What is the number? a. 8 b. 9 c. 10 d. 11 8 + 3(8) = 32 9 + 3(9) = 36 10 + 3(10) = 40 11 + 3(11) = 44 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 13. Joe is lending Frank $500 and Frank has 4 years to pay it back. Joe is charging 6% interest. Frank wants to determine how much interest he'll pay over the 4 years. He sets up the formula, interest (i) = loan amount (l) x rate (r) x time (t). Find i. a. $12 b. $120 c. $125 d. $1,200 i = l x r x t l = $500, r = 6% and t = 4 years l = $500 x .06 x 4 i = $30 x 4 i = $120 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 14. In V = 2m - 3, V is which of the following? a. Constant b. Dependent Variable c. Independent Variable d. Exponent A dependent variable is a variable that depends on one or more other variables. In this equation, V depends on the value of m.

A dependent variable is a variable that depends on one or more other variables. In this equation, V depends on the value of m. An independent variable is a variable that can have its value chosen without considering the values of other variables. In this equation, m is an independent variable. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 15. In B = 3 + 4w, 3 is which of the following? a. Constant b. Dependent Variable c. Independent Variable d. Coefficient A constant is a value that does not change. In this equation, 3 is a fixed number that will not change. A coefficient is a number used to multiple a variable. In this equation, 4 is a coefficient of the independent variable w. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 16. V = bdt. Solve the formula for d. a. d = b/tv b. d = t/bv c. d = vbt d. d = v/bt v = bdt v = d bt Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 17. B = 1hm . Solve the formula for h. 2 a. h = 1/2Bm b. h = 2B/m c. h = 2m/B d. h = 2Bm B = 1hm 2 2B = 1hm 2B

2B = 1hm 2B = h m Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 18. The absolute value of -14 is 14. True False The absolute value of a number, even a negative number, is a positive number. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 19. - 3 + (-14) = a. 11 b. -11 c. -17 d. -42 - 3 + (-14) = - 3 - 14 = - 17 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 20. 20 - (-6) = a. 14 b. -14 c. 26 d. 120 20 - (-6) = 20 + 6 = 26 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 21. Add the following: 3x - 2y + 2y + 3z + 2z - 4x - 5y. a. x - 5y - z b. x - c. - x - 5y - z d. - x - 5y + 5z 3x - 2y + 2y + 3z + 2z - 4x - 5y = 3x - 4x - 2y - 5y + 2y + 3z + 2z = -x - 5y + 5z Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 22. 6x - 10 = 4(x + 3). Solve for x. a. x = 9 b. x = 10 c. x = 11 d. x = 12 6x - 10 = 4(x + 3) 6x - 10 = 4x + 12 6x = 4x + 22 2x = 22 x = 11 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 23. x - 6 = 17. Solve for x. a. x = 23 b. x = 11 c. x = 102 d. x = 17 / 6 x - 6 = 17

x = 17 / 6 x - 6 = 17 x = 17 + 6 x = 23 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 24. Which of the following is not a grouping symbol? a. parentheses b. braces c. brackets d. arrows Grouping symbols such as parentheses, brackets and braces in math will contain numbers, variables and operations. The grouping symbol tells you to do the operation first. An arrow, on the other hand, is an implicaiton notation to show that both sides of an notation are equal. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 25. A minus sign that precedes a parenthesis causes the sign of each term within the parentheses to change when the parentheses are removed. True False If a minus sign appears outside of a parentheses, the minus sign changes the terms within the parentheses when the parentheses is removed. For example, - (2x - 4y) -2x + 4y Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 26. If X equals 5, what is the value of 6X + 2X - X? a. 25 b. 30 c. 35 d. 40 If x = 5, 6x + 2x - x =

If x = 5, 6x + 2x - x = 6(5) + 2(5) - 5 = 30 + 10 - 5 = 35 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 27. If 10 is separated into two parts, one of which is y, represent the second part. a. 10 / y b. 10 + y c. 10 - y d. y - 10 If 10 is separated into two parts, one of which is y, the second part will be 10 - y. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 28. Find 3 consecutive numbers such that 3 times the first is equal to 8 more than the sum of the other two. a. 8, 9, 10 b. 9, 10, 11 c. 11, 12, 13 d. 12, 13, 14 x = 1st number x + 1 = 2nd number x + 2 = 3rd number 3x = x + 1 + x + 2 + 8 3x = 2x + 11 x = 11 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 29. The ratio of the height of two buildings is 7 to 5. The first building is 210 feet tall. How tall is the second building? a. 140 b. 145 c. 150 d. 160 7/5 = 210/x 7x = 1,050 x = 150 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. 30. Factor the polynomial 5x - 15. a. x = 5 b. 5(x - 3) c. x - 3 d. 5x - 3(5)

d. 5x - 3(5) When factoring, look to see what you can take out of a parentheses to put out front of it. It is the opposite of distributing in polynomial expressions. The first term 5x can be factored (5)(x). The second term 15 can be factored (5)(3). 5 is the only factor common to both terms. Divide out the 5 from the terms and move the common factor to the front of the parentheses. Remember, when dividing 15 by 5, a 3 is left over. 5x/5 - 15/5 = x - 3 Move the common factor to the front. 5(x - 3) Incorrect answer. 7/30 × 7. John has B bats and buys C bats more. He then gives away D bats. Which of the following algebraic statements corretly shows how many bats John has left? a. D - BC b. B - C - D c. B + C - D d. B + D + C If John starts with B bats and buys C more bats, the total number of bats John has would be represented by the formula B + C. When John gives D bats away, the sum of B + C would subtract D bats to determine how many he has left. So, the formula is B + C - D. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. i = $120 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. Prev Next Finish 14/30 × 14. In V = 2m - 3, V is which of the following? a. Constant b. Dependent Variable c. Independent Variable d. Exponent A dependent variable is a variable that depends on one or more other variables. In this equation, V depends on the value of m. An independent variable is a variable that can have its value chosen without considering the values of other variables. In this equation, m is an independent variable. Incorrect answer. In this equation, 4 is a coefficient of the independent variable w. Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. Prev Next Finish 16/30 × 16.

Find 3 consecutive numbers such that 3 times the first is equal to 8 more than the sum of the other two. a. 8, 9, 10 b. 9, 10, 11 c. 11, 12, 13 d. 12, 13, 14 x = 1st number x + 1 = 2nd number x + 2 = 3rd number 3x = x + 1 + x + 2 + 8 3x = 2x + 11 x = 11 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. Prev Next Finish 29/30 × 29. The ratio of the height of two buildings is 7 to 5. The first building is 210 feet tall. How tall is the second building? a. 140 b. 145 c. 150 d. 160 7/5 = 210/x 7x = 1,050 x = 150 Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. Prev Next Finish 30/30 × 30. Factor the polynomial 5x - 15. a. x = 5 b. 5(x - 3) c. x - 3 d. 5x - 3(5) When factoring, look to see what you can take out of a parentheses to put out front of it. It is the opposite of distributing in polynomial expressions. The first term 5x can be factored (5)(x). The second term 15 can be factored (5)(3). 5 is the only factor common to both terms.

The second term 15 can be factored (5)(3). 5 is the only factor common to both terms. Divide out the 5 from the terms and move the common factor to the front of the parentheses. Remember, when dividing 15 by 5, a 3 is left over. 5x/5 - 15/5 = x - 3 Move the common factor to the front. 5(x - 3) Incorrect answer. Please choose another answer. Math learning and study strategies Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1467736] Not sure what areas of math you need help with? Use the math self-assessment tool [LINK: https://tlp-lpa.ca/math/self-assessments] to find out. Math learning strategies Make sure you are comfortable with the foundational math topics, including: Whole number operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, square root) Fraction operations Reducing fractions (proper, improper, mixed numbers) Decimal operations and place value Order of operations Percent Ratios, rates and proportions A great way to improve your learning is to start thinking about your thinking. Check out this video [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/videos/detail/13] on starting to think about your thinking and save this document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/91] to look back on during your semester.

document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/91] to look back on during your semester. College classes are much different than high school. This video will walk you through how to learn in post-secondary lectures [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/lil.html] . You can also save this document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/92] to bring with you to class. Learning math online and in person can be different. This video will show you how to be successful in an online math class [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/videos/detail/14] . Check out these tips to improve math learning : Complete homework/practice questions Check your work after you have solved a problem and fix your mistakes right away (so you do not repeat them) Re-do example problems from class independently Re-do problems from tests and assignments that were wrong Re-watch class recordings (if available)

Re-do problems from tests and assignments that were wrong Re-watch class recordings (if available) Ask questions during class when things are unclear Ask the instructor questions outside of class when things are unclear Ask friends for help Sit at the front of the classroom Take notes in class Finish assignments a day or two early to leave time to ask questions Use online math resources outside of course resources Practice a little bit every day Seek help from a tutor Use the calculator you will be using on tests when practicing Practice pre-requisite basic concepts (one topic at a time) Be sure to download our Math Learning Strategies Checklist [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/157] as well to help you stay on track. Math test-taking strategies Not sure how to study for a math test or exam? Are your current math study habits not working as they did in high school? This video [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/es.html]

This video [LINK: http://wolczuk.com/es.html] discusses how to study effectively for math tests and exams. You can also save or print this document [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/93] to look back on while you're studying. Late Start to the Semester Save Send Feedback If you have a late start to the semester, you may need to create a Learning Agreement with your Program Chair. Start by reviewing your Academic Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] before reaching out to their instructors to discuss missed work. Please also review the "Instructional Plan" for each of your courses on eCollege [LINK: https://college.desire2learn.com/] . If you have any concerns, book an appointment [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-success-advising/appointments] with a Student Success Advisor for additional support. Following toggle tip provides clarification Skip to content [LINK: https://courseware.cemc.uwaterloo.ca/40#inner] Help [LINK: https://cemc.uwaterloo.ca/resources/courseware/help.html] Toggle navigation System Homepage [LINK: https://www.cemc.uwaterloo.ca/courseware/] Problem Solving and Mathematical Discovery [LINK: /40] Class Homepage Problem Solving and Mathematical Discovery This courseware helps students to become better problem solvers. Students will learn about roughly a dozen problem techniques (such as Draw a useful diagram, Find a pattern, Consider cases) and explicitly look at problem solving in a number of major topic areas (such as Number Theory, Counting, Geometry). None of the problems presented in this course uses material beyond that covered in the Advanced Functions and Pre-Calculus courseware. The majority of the problems discussed would be accessible to strong and motivated students in Grades 10 and 11. Units Introduction [LINK: #unit-122]

Units Introduction [LINK: #unit-122] Techniques [LINK: #unit-123] Equations, Algebra, and Functions [LINK: #unit-124] Number Theory [LINK: #unit-125] Counting [LINK: #unit-126] Geometry [LINK: #unit-127] Problem Solving Wrap-up [LINK: #unit-128] Additional Resources [LINK: #unit-129] Introduction In this unit we solve one difficult problem and some easier variations of the problem. Through the development of the solutions we begin to think about problem solving strategies and techniques that will be formalized in the next unit. Introduction [LINK: 40/122/assignments/1030] Start [LINK: 40/122/assignments/1030] Welcome video A journey through one problem [LINK: 40/122/assignments/1031] Start [LINK: 40/122/assignments/1031] Includes Problems 1-5 Techniques In this unit we explore a variety of problem solving techniques. Equations, Algebra, and Functions We apply some of the techniques learned in the previous unit to solve problems involving equations, algebra, and functions.

Equations, Algebra, and Functions We apply some of the techniques learned in the previous unit to solve problems involving equations, algebra, and functions. Number Theory We apply some of the techniques learned in the Techniques unit to solve problems involving number theory. Counting We apply some of the techniques learned in the Techniques unit to solve problems involving counting. Geometry We apply some of the techniques learned in the Techniques unit to solve problems involving geometry. Problem Solving Wrap-up In this final unit we present some concluding thoughts and solve a set of challenging problems that highlight most of the techniques and topics covered throughout the course. Additional Resources Möbius [LINK: https://www.digitaled.com/products/courseware/] University of Waterloo [LINK: https://uwaterloo.ca/] © 2018 University of Waterloo. Emergency Room Information Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/3400236] You should only go to an emergency room if you have a life-threatening medical emergency. There may be longer wait times, especially if your concern is not a life-threatening medical emergency. When you go to an emergency department, you need to bring your College International Health Insurance Plan card (for international students) or your OHIP card (for Ontario residents). If you live in Waterloo, Kitchener, Cambridge or Guelph, here is a list of the local emergency departments. 1. Grand River Hospital Emergency Room [LINK: https://www.grhosp.on.ca/care/services-departments/emergency/current-emergency-wait] 835 King St. W Kitchener, ON 2. St. Mary’s General Hospital: Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.smgh.ca/patients-visitors/emergency-department-wait-times] 911 Queen’s Blvd Kitchener, ON 3.

Kitchener, ON 3. Cambridge Memorial Hospital: Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.cmh.org/programs/department-emergency-medicine] 700 Coronation Blvd Cambridge, ON 4. Guelph General Hospital Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.gghorg.ca/emergency-department/] 115 Delhi St Guelph, ON 5. Halton Healthcare [LINK: https://www.haltonhealthcare.on.ca/services_/28763/t28425-emergency-department] Emergency care is available at all three hospitals located in Oakville, Milton and Georgetown If you live outside of these cities, you can find your nearest emergency department by searching “emergency department near me” on your preferred internet browser. Changing Academic Block (Timetable) Save Send Feedback A change to a student's schedule is sometimes also referred to as changing "blocks", "sections", or "timetable". Administratively, each of these have slightly different meanings, but from a student's perspective, the implication is the same - you want to switch the days or times of the courses you are taking to different options. Certain programs allow students to switch academic blocks if there is space available. By switching to another academic block, you are agreeing to completely change your timetable. Requests to change or modify a timetable are not permitted in the following schools: Business, Human Services, and Applied Computer Science & IT. In other programs, it may be permitted. Here are the steps involved: Login to the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] Select the ‘My Courses’ tab Select the ‘Change Academic Block’ button View the block schedules

Select the ‘Change Academic Block’ button View the block schedules Note: blocks will only be displayed if a seat is available. Select your preferred academic block Select ‘Change to Block’ If the ‘Change Academic Block’ button is unavailable and you would like to make a change, submit a Course Change Request Form on the Student Portal under the ‘Services’ tab > ‘My Forms’. Your request will be reviewed for approval. There is no guarantee that your request will be approved. You might also be interested in this tutorial from the Registrar's Office [LINK: https://stucollegecon.sharepoint.com.mcas.ms/sites/registrar/Shared%20Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2Fregistrar%2FShared%20Documents%2FCommunications%2FTimetables%20%26%20Enrolment%2FTimetable%20and%20Enrolment%20Resources%2FChanging%20an%20Academic%20Block%20%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2Fregistrar%2FShared%20Documents%2FCommunications%2FTimetables%20%26%20Enrolment%2FTimetable%20and%20Enrolment%20Resources&p=true&ga=1] .

Can I engage in studies while on my regularly scheduled academic break and still work full time? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1970508] Students who are enrolled full-time during the academic sessions before and after a regularly scheduled break and who decide to undertake a full-time or part-time course load during their scheduled program break are eligible to work off campus on a full-time basis. If a program of study does not provide a scheduled program break and a student chooses to take their own break from the program, it is considered a leave from studies and it is not a scheduled program break. Students who take a leave from studies are not eligible to work on or off-campus during that break. Featured Info Page Laptops & Printers [LINK: /students/InfoPages/detail/18/laptops-and-printers] Laptops and printers available to Accessible Learning students. Let us know. [LINK: /adoption?Introductory%20Statistics] Summary provides an engaging, practical, and thorough overview of the core concepts and skills taught in most one-semester statistics courses. The text focuses on diverse applications from a variety of fields and societal contexts, including business, healthcare, sciences, sociology, political science, computing, and several others. The material supports students with conceptual narratives, detailed step-by-step examples, and a wealth of illustrations, as well as collaborative exercises, technology integration problems, and statistics labs.

The text focuses on diverse applications from a variety of fields and societal contexts, including business, healthcare, sciences, sociology, political science, computing, and several others. The material supports students with conceptual narratives, detailed step-by-step examples, and a wealth of illustrations, as well as collaborative exercises, technology integration problems, and statistics labs. The text assumes some knowledge of intermediate algebra, and includes thousands of problems and exercises that offer instructors and students ample opportunity to explore and reinforce useful statistical skills. The first edition of by OpenStax is available in web view here [LINK: https://openstax.org/books/introductory-statistics/pages/1-introduction] . Let us know. [LINK: /adoption?Prealgebra] Summary

[LINK: /adoption?Prealgebra] Summary is designed to meet scope and sequence requirements for a one-semester prealgebra or basic math course. The book’s organization makes it easy to adapt to a variety of course syllabi. The text introduces the fundamental concepts of algebra while addressing the needs of students with diverse backgrounds and learning styles. Each topic builds upon previously developed material to demonstrate the cohesiveness and structure of mathematics. The second edition contains detailed updates and accuracy revisions to address comments and suggestions from users. Dozens of faculty experts worked through the text, exercises and problems, graphics, and solutions to identify areas needing improvement. Though the authors made significant changes and enhancements, exercise and problem numbers remain nearly the same in order to ensure a smooth transition for faculty. The first edition of by OpenStax is available in web view

The first edition of by OpenStax is available in web view here [LINK: https://openstax.org/books/prealgebra/pages/1-introduction] .
