Following toggle tip provides clarification Skip to content [LINK: https://courseware.cemc.uwaterloo.ca/8#inner] Help [LINK: https://cemc.uwaterloo.ca/resources/courseware/help.html] Toggle navigation System Homepage [LINK: https://www.cemc.uwaterloo.ca/courseware/] Advanced Functions and Pre-Calculus [LINK: /8] Class Homepage Advanced Functions and Pre-Calculus This courseware extends students' experience with functions. Students will investigate the properties of polynomial, rational, exponential, logarithmic, trigonometric and radical functions; develop techniques for combining functions; broaden their understanding of rates of change; and develop facility in applying these concepts and skills. This courseware is considered prerequisite learning for the Calculus and Vectors courseware. Units Functions: Transformations and Properties [LINK: #unit-32] Polynomial Functions [LINK: #unit-43] Polynomial Equations and Inequalities [LINK: #unit-33] Rational Functions [LINK: #unit-34]

Polynomial Equations and Inequalities [LINK: #unit-33] Rational Functions [LINK: #unit-34] Exponential and Logarithmic Functions [LINK: #unit-35] Trigonometric Functions [LINK: #unit-36] Trigonometric Identities and Equations [LINK: #unit-37] Operations on Functions [LINK: #unit-38] Rates of Change [LINK: #unit-39] Functions: Transformations and Properties This unit introduces functions along with many terms and notations that will be encountered when working with them. A large portion of the unit deals with sketching functions using transformations. The unit concludes with a look at inverses. Relations and Functions [LINK: 8/32/assignments/43] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/43] The module begins with the definition of a function and how functions are represented. Domain and range, function notation, and composite functions are introduced and developed in this module. Interval Notation and Definitions [LINK: 8/32/assignments/75] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/75]

Interval Notation and Definitions [LINK: 8/32/assignments/75] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/75] Often in mathematics, solutions lie on an interval. Three techniques used to describe intervals are presented in this module. The module concludes with an example that is used to present  definitions of concepts that will be used throughout the course. Solving Linear Inequalities [LINK: 8/32/assignments/76] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/76] Is there a difference in how an inequality is solved versus the solution of an equation? In this module, this question is examined and a variety of different examples are solved. Graphing Five Base Functions [LINK: 8/32/assignments/108] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/108] In this module we look at the graphs of five base functions: the quadratic function, the square root function, the reciprocal function, the exponential function, and the absolute value function.

Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/108] In this module we look at the graphs of five base functions: the quadratic function, the square root function, the reciprocal function, the exponential function, and the absolute value function. For each function, we will look at efficient ways to sketch the graph, discuss domain and range, and make observations about some features of each graph. Translations [LINK: 8/32/assignments/109] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/109] Our examination of transformations begins with a look at translations. In this module, we develop a general rule for translations, we sketch graphs given a base function and translation, we determine equations of graphs that have been translated, and we find the translation that has been applied to one function to obtain another. Reflections [LINK: 8/32/assignments/110] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/110] How is the graph or equation of a function affected by a reflection about the x x - or y y -axis?

y -axis? In this module, we develop a general rule for these reflections, we examine even and odd functions, we sketch images which are reflections of base functions, and we determine equations of functions which have been reflected. Stretches [LINK: 8/32/assignments/111] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/111] When a function is stretched about the x x - or y y -axis, what is the effect on the graph and the equation? In this module, we develop a general rule for these types of transformations, we sketch various functions given a base graph and stretch using words or mapping notation, and we determine the transformation given the equation or graph of the pre-image and image. Combining Transformations [LINK: 8/32/assignments/112] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/112] In this module, we put all of the transformation pieces together. By looking at an equation, we determine which base function is being transformed and which transformations have been applied.

In this module, we put all of the transformation pieces together. By looking at an equation, we determine which base function is being transformed and which transformations have been applied. Two methods are presented for sketching functions using transformations. Inverses [LINK: 8/32/assignments/113] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/113] In this module, inverses are defined algebraically and geometrically. Given the graph of a function, we sketch the inverse, and given the equation of a function, we determine the equation of the inverse. All Exercises, Answers, and Solutions [LINK: 8/32/assignments/794] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/794] Enrichment, Extension, and Application [LINK: 8/32/assignments/280] Start [LINK: 8/32/assignments/280] Polynomial Functions This unit examines key characteristics and properties of polynomial functions, supportive in determining the shape of their graphs. Focus will be placed on studying the behaviour of 3rd and 4th degree polynomial functions.

This unit examines key characteristics and properties of polynomial functions, supportive in determining the shape of their graphs. Focus will be placed on studying the behaviour of 3rd and 4th degree polynomial functions. Through investigation, connections will be made between the algebraic, numeric, and graphical representations of these functions. Polynomial Equations and Inequalities This unit develops the factoring skills necessary to solve factorable polynomial equations and inequalities in one variable. Connections are made between the real roots of a polynomial equation and the -intercepts of the corresponding polynomial function. Skills are applied to solve problems involving polynomial functions and equations. Rational Functions This unit examines key characteristics and properties of rational functions, supportive in determining the shape of their graphs.

Rational Functions This unit examines key characteristics and properties of rational functions, supportive in determining the shape of their graphs. Focus will be placed on studying rational functions with linear or quadratic polynomial expressions in their numerators and/or denominators. Through investigation, connections will be made between the algebraic and graphical representations of these functions. Exponential and Logarithmic Functions This unit examines key characteristics and properties of exponential and logarithmic functions. Techniques used to solve exponential and logarithmic equations will be taught and applied to solving problems. Trigonometric Functions In this unit, you will be introduced to functions whose values repeat over regular intervals. The most common such functions are called sinusoidal functions. These functions will be examined graphically and algebraically.

The most common such functions are called sinusoidal functions. These functions will be examined graphically and algebraically. The ultimate goal is to be able to solve realistic applications that can be modeled by this type of function. Trigonometric Identities and Equations This unit explores equivalent trigonometric expressions and examines strategies to prove trigonometric identities and solve a variety of trigonometric equations. Knowledge of fundamental trigonometric identities will be extended to include compound angle and double angle formulas. Following toggle tip provides clarification Skip to content [LINK: https://courseware.cemc.uwaterloo.ca/27#inner] Help [LINK: https://cemc.uwaterloo.ca/resources/courseware/help.html] Toggle navigation System Homepage [LINK: https://www.cemc.uwaterloo.ca/courseware/] Grades 7 & 8 Mathematics [LINK: /27] Class Homepage Grades 7 & 8 Mathematics This course covers the topics typically taught in Canadian Grade 7 and 8 Mathematics curricula and, in some instances, extends ideas beyond grade level. Letters are included beside the unit names to help group the units into similar themes. For more information about the structure and general use of this courseware, see the Course Information unit. Units Representing and Comparing Numbers (N) [LINK: #unit-71] Operations (N) [LINK: #unit-72] Ratios, Rates, and Proportions (N) [LINK: #unit-75] Bisectors and Properties of Shapes (G) [LINK: #unit-73] Area, Volume, and Angles (G) [LINK: #unit-95] Transformations of Shapes (G) [LINK: #unit-85]

Area, Volume, and Angles (G) [LINK: #unit-95] Transformations of Shapes (G) [LINK: #unit-85] Representing Patterns (A) [LINK: #unit-69] Equations and the Pythagorean Theorem (A) [LINK: #unit-76] Data Collection and Graphs (D) [LINK: #unit-86] Data Analysis (D) [LINK: #unit-94] Probability (D) [LINK: #unit-96] Course Information [LINK: #unit-74] Representing and Comparing Numbers (N) Part A (Lessons 1–7) Topics include representing and comparing positive rational numbers (integers, fractions, and decimals), finding multiples and factors of positive integers, and determining the least common multiple (LCM) and the greatest common factor (GCF) of a pair of positive integers. Part B (Lessons 8–12) Topics include representing negative fractions and negative decimals, comparing the values of any two rational numbers, exponential notation, and using factor trees and prime factorizations to find the LCM or the GCF of a pair of positive integers. Lesson 1: What Are Rational Numbers?

Topics include representing negative fractions and negative decimals, comparing the values of any two rational numbers, exponential notation, and using factor trees and prime factorizations to find the LCM or the GCF of a pair of positive integers. Lesson 1: What Are Rational Numbers? [LINK: 27/71/assignments/541] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/541] This lesson examines three different number systems: whole numbers, integers, and rational numbers. Connections between different number systems are highlighted to set the groundwork for comparisons and operations. Lesson 2: Representing Rational Numbers on the Number Line [LINK: 27/71/assignments/540] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/540] Mathematicians often use the number line to solve problems. In this lesson, we review the number line, focusing on plotting fractions. Lesson 3: Comparing Fractions [LINK: 27/71/assignments/547] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/547] In math, symbols are important for communication.

Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/547] In math, symbols are important for communication. In this lesson, we review the “greater than” and “less than” symbols. In addition, we present two techniques used to compare fractions. Lesson 4: Describing Fractions as Decimals [LINK: 27/71/assignments/546] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/546] Rational numbers can be written as fractions or decimals. In this lesson, we discuss the connections between fractional representations and decimal representations, specifically, when it comes to plotting numbers on the number line. Lesson 5: Multiples of Positive Integers [LINK: 27/71/assignments/537] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/537] In this lesson, we review how to generate a list of multiples of an integer. Using our lists, we identify common multiples of two integers, paying particular attention to the least common multiple (LCM). Lesson 6: Factors of Positive Integers [LINK: 27/71/assignments/539] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/539]

Lesson 6: Factors of Positive Integers [LINK: 27/71/assignments/539] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/539] Factors, like multiples, have to do with multiplication. In this lesson, we solve problems by identifying factors of positive integers. Lesson 7: The Greatest Common Factor [LINK: 27/71/assignments/538] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/538] Expanding on the factors lesson, we compare the factors of two positive integers to find common factors; specifically, we are often interested in identifying the greatest common factor (GCF). We conclude by solving word problems that require us to apply factors to different contexts. Lesson 8: Comparing Negative Fractions [LINK: 27/71/assignments/548] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/548] Fractional quantities can be positive or negative. Similar to negative integers, negative fractions lie to the left of zero on the number line.

Fractional quantities can be positive or negative. Similar to negative integers, negative fractions lie to the left of zero on the number line. In this lesson, we plot negative fractions on the number line to help us understand and compare the values of these numbers. Lesson 9: Comparing Rational Numbers [LINK: 27/71/assignments/545] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/545] Rational numbers can be written as fractions or decimals. In this lesson, we compare negative decimal numbers by plotting them on the number line. We then compare negative fractions with negative decimals. The decimal equivalents of common fractions are determined and strategies for converting a fraction into a decimal are shown. Finally, we learn how to compare any two rational numbers. Lesson 10: Exponents [LINK: 27/71/assignments/543] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/543] In this lesson, we learn to represent repeated multiplication using exponential notation.

Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/543] In this lesson, we learn to represent repeated multiplication using exponential notation. Exponential notation is then used to represent whole numbers in expanded form using powers of ten. Square numbers and cube numbers are investigated. Lesson 11: Prime Factorization [LINK: 27/71/assignments/542] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/542] In this lesson, we review prime and composite numbers. We learn how to represent a composite number as a product of its prime factors using a factor tree. Lesson 12: Using Prime Factorizations [LINK: 27/71/assignments/544] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/544] Prime factorizations can be used to determine the greatest common factor (GCF) and the least common multiple (LCM) of a pair of positive integers. We explore how this can be done, and we use these strategies to solve word problems. All Exercises, Answers, and Solutions [LINK: 27/71/assignments/1274] Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/1274] Operations (N)

Start [LINK: 27/71/assignments/1274] Operations (N) Part A (Lessons 1–11) Topics include adding and subtracting rational numbers, multiplying and dividing a whole number by a positive rational number, and evaluating expressions using the order of operations. Part B (Lessons 12–19) Topics include multiplying, and dividing integers, fractions and decimal numbers, approximating square roots of positive integers, and evaluating expressions that include exponents using the order of operations. Ratios, Rates, and Proportions (N) Part A (Lessons 1–6) Topics include writing and interpreting ratios; finding equivalent ratios; converting between fractions, decimals, and percents; increasing and decreasing by a percentage; converting between units of measurement; and solving problems involving unit rates. Part B (Lessons 7–11)

Topics include writing and interpreting ratios; finding equivalent ratios; converting between fractions, decimals, and percents; increasing and decreasing by a percentage; converting between units of measurement; and solving problems involving unit rates. Part B (Lessons 7–11) Topics include recognizing proportional situations in word problems, tables and graphs; connecting unit relates to proportional relationships and their representations in tables, graphs and equations; and fractional percents and percents greater than 100 percent. Bisectors and Properties of Shapes (G) Part A (Lessons 1–6) Topics include constructions of angle bisectors and perpendicular bisectors, and the various properties of triangles, quadrilaterals, and more general polygons. In particular, different polygons are classified based on their side lengths and angle measurements. Part B (Lessons 7–10)

In particular, different polygons are classified based on their side lengths and angle measurements. Part B (Lessons 7–10) Topics include quadrilateral diagonals, circle terminology and construction, and applications of circles in the real-world. Area, Volume, and Angles (G) Part A (Lessons 1–5) Topics include calculating the area of parallelograms, triangles, trapezoids, and composite shapes; calculating the surface area, volume, and capacity of prisms; and representing 3D objects in different ways. Part B (Lessons 6–10) Topics include calculating the circumference and area of circles; calculating the volume and surface area of cylinders; and properties of angles formed by intersecting lines including parallel lines and transversals. Transformations of Shapes (G) Part A (Lessons 1–7)

Transformations of Shapes (G) Part A (Lessons 1–7) Topics include congruence of polygons, triangle congruence rules, plotting points on the Cartesian plane, the image of a polygon on the Cartesian plane under translations, reflections and/or rotations on the Cartesian plane, and tessellations. Part B (Lessons 8–11) Topics include similarity of polygons, triangle similarity rules, dilatations of polygons, and indirect measurements. Representing Patterns (A) Part A (Lessons 1–6) Topics include representing sequences using tables, general terms and graphs, describing patterns using variables and expressions, extending sequences, and solving problems involving unknown quantities. Part B (Lessons 7–11) Topics include equivalent expressions for the general term of a sequence, describing relationships and patterns using equations, and decreasing and naturally occurring sequences. Equations and the Pythagorean Theorem (A) Part A (Lessons 1–7)

Equations and the Pythagorean Theorem (A) Part A (Lessons 1–7) Topics include using variables in expressions, equations, and inequalities, identifying and exploring linear relationships, solving equations and inequalities by inspection, trial and error, and using visual models, and simplifying expressions by collecting like terms. Part B (Lessons 8-15) Topics include solving equations and inequalities using algebraic techniques, comparing the differences between evaluating an expression and solving an equation, exploring equations with multiple variables, and the Pythagorean Theorem. Data Collection and Graphs (D) Part A (Lessons 1–5)

Data Collection and Graphs (D) Part A (Lessons 1–5) Topics include different types of data; population, sample and census; bias in data collection arising from question wording, accepted answers and choice of sample group; frequency and relative frequency tables and graphs; reading and creating circle graphs; choosing an appropriate graph type for a data set; bias in data representation arising from the chosen graph type, graph structure and shape, and axis labels and scales. Part B (Lessons 6–9) Topics include organizing continuous data into stem-and-leaf plots and frequency tables with intervals; as well as creating and reading histograms, and scatter plots. Data Analysis (D) Part A (Lessons 1–4)

Data Analysis (D) Part A (Lessons 1–4) Topics include determining the mean, median, and mode of data sets; studying the effects of adding data to a data set or removing data from a data set; exploring the effect of outliers on the mean, median, and mode; and practising drawing conclusions and making predictions from data in graphs. Part B (Lessons 5–8) Topics include interpreting data, histograms, and scatter plots and drawing conclusions from these graphs; describing relationships between the two variables in a scatter plot; estimating rates of change associated with scatter plots; making predictions supported by the data in histograms and scatter plots; and using appropriate measures of central tendency to compare two data sets. Probability (D) Part A (Lessons 1–4)

Probability (D) Part A (Lessons 1–4) Topics include random experiments, outcomes, and events; calculating theoretical probabilities of single events; comparing probabilities of different events; independent events; experimental probability; and using probabilities to make predictions. Part B (Lessons 5–8) Topics include comparing theoretical probabilities and experimental probabilities; exploring how the number of trials impacts probability estimates; complementary events; setting up and running simulations using probability models; and revisiting independent events. Academic Probation Save Send Feedback There are two levels of probation: Probation 1 (P1) and Probation 2 (P2). Students are placed on probation if they have a Term Weighted Average between 55 - 59.99% (unless otherwise stated in the Academic School Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/index] ). Students on P1 are encouraged (not required) to meet with an SSA or their Program Coordinator to develop a learning plan. A learning plan is a document designed to support your academic achievement. Students who have a term weighted average in the same range for a second consecutive term will be placed on P2. Note: a scheduled break is ignored when determining consecutive semesters. When on P2, students are required to connect with an SSA or their program coordinator to develop a learning contract. This is a formal agreement that outlines the requirement for academic achievement.

When on P2, students are required to connect with an SSA or their program coordinator to develop a learning contract. This is a formal agreement that outlines the requirement for academic achievement. If a student's term weighted average remains in the same range after being on P2, they will be discontinued from their program. Important Notes Term Weighted Average is calculated using the grades for each course and adjusted for the number of credits associated with the course in which it was received. If a student is registered through part-time studies their course performance will be reflected in their cumulative weighted average. There is no term weighted average calculation for part-time studies unless they are registered in a program cohort. All students can attempt a course 2 times. For any subsequent attempts, the student must get approval from an academic administrator in the program in which they are registered.

All students can attempt a course 2 times. For any subsequent attempts, the student must get approval from an academic administrator in the program in which they are registered. Failed courses before September 1, 2024 will not be counted towards the maximum number of attempts. Enrollment Letter Save Send Feedback To request an enrollment letter, log into your Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] and navigate to the ‘Enrollment’ or ‘Services’ section. Select ‘Print a Letter,’ choose 'Currently Enrolled Letter,' and click 'Generate' to download your letter as a PDF file. If you encounter any issues, contact the Student Records team at studentrecords@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:studentrecords@collegec.on.ca] . Electives (Full-Time) Save Send Feedback To add an elective course to your timetable, log onto the Student Portal, navigate to ‘My Courses,’ and select the elective you wish to add. Ensure the course does not conflict with your other courses. If you take an elective and your full course load, additional fees may apply. For more information, refer to the college's electives website [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/electives] . Link to the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] Registration Hold: Cannot Add Elective If you cannot add an elective due to a "not ready for registration" status, it is likely due to unpaid fees. To resolve this, pay any outstanding fees or set up a payment schedule through the Student Portal. If you have already completed these tasks, contact Student Records [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts] for further assistance. Step-by-Step Guide Option 1:

Step-by-Step Guide Option 1: Once registration has opened, register through the Student Portal under the "My Courses" tab. Then follow these steps: Log onto the Student Portal Click the ‘My Courses’ tab Click the ‘Add Course’ button and scroll down to view Select the course View availability to ensure the course is available and open Select ‘Add to Cart’ Find the course in your cart and select ‘Checkout and Enroll’ Confirm your address. Select ‘Save’ at the bottom of the Contact Information page Confirm registration Option 2: Once registration has opened, add course(s) under the My Forms tab (Laserfiche): Log onto the Student Portal. Click the ‘Services’ tab > ‘My Forms’ > use the ‘Course Change Request Form’ Log into Laserfiche using your eCollege login details. Select course(s) Note: you can only add 3 courses per form – for more than 3 courses, submit multiple forms. Complete the form in its entirety Click submit. SAVE A COPY for your records

Click submit. SAVE A COPY for your records Be patient and watch your College email address for updates. Important: SSA/College Staff cannot provide status updates. The form goes to your Program Coordinator for approval and then to the Registrar’s Office for processing. Due to the high volume of requests, please allow up to 14 business days for processing. You may also be interested in this tutorial with screenshots [LINK: https://stucollegecon.sharepoint.com.mcas.ms/sites/registrar/Shared%20Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2Fregistrar%2FShared%20Documents%2FCommunications%2FTimetables%20%26%20Enrolment%2FTimetable%20and%20Enrolment%20Resources%2FHow%20to%20Add%20an%20Elective%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2Fregistrar%2FShared%20Documents%2FCommunications%2FTimetables%20%26%20Enrolment%2FTimetable%20and%20Enrolment%20Resources&p=true&ga=1] from the Registrar's Office. Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

College College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way.

These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. College protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to privacy@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:privacy@collegec.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Student Rights & Responsibilities FAQs Save Send Feedback Who do I contact if I have an emergency or safety concern? If you feel unsafe or need immediate attention on-campus, contact Safety and Security [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/safety-and-security/contact] . If you are off campus, contact emergency services by calling 911. If you are in crisis and need urgent mental health support, the following resources can help: Suicide Crisis Helpline (all of Canada): 988 HERE 24/7 (Kitchener, Waterloo, Cambridge, Guelph):1-844-437-3247 Good 2 Talk (Post-secondary student helpline): 1-866-925-5454 or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868 Crisis Support Peel (Mississauga, Brampton, Peel areas): 1-888-811-2222 Who can report a Student Rights and Responsibilities Violation? College students, employees, faculty, and members of the public may submit reports or reach out to our email. Can I make a report anonymously? Yes, we accept anonymous reports. Note that this can limit our responses available.

Yes, we accept anonymous reports. Note that this can limit our responses available. If we do not know who you are, we will be unable to follow-up with any updates or next steps on our process. To submit an anonymous report, complete the report form leaving the reporter name and contact information blank. If you would like some follow-up, you can provide an anonymous email address for us to contact. In some cases, we can keep reporters anonymous to other parties involved. If at any point in our process you choose to be anonymous after contacting our office, let us know. We will provide guidance on what that will look like moving forward. What are my options when making a report? The options we will provide you will depend on what the report or concerns are about. We will provide you with the most appropriate information and policies related to your concerns. In some cases, we may connect you with other departments better suited to support you. How do I schedule a meeting with you?

In some cases, we may connect you with other departments better suited to support you. How do I schedule a meeting with you? We ask that you first reach out to us via email or the report form with additional information on your concerns. This helps us better determine if we are the most appropriate resource for your inquiry. If we can provide further support, we will then share arrange a meeting with a member of our team via email. I’ve received an email from SRR about an incident, what happens next? Follow the instructions outlined in the emails from our office; there may be action items for you to follow. We recommend that you address it as soon as possible. Respond to the email with any questions or concerns you may have. If you received an email with a request to meet, its because we want to hear from you to gather your perspective. A meeting with our office is your opportunity to share your side of events and work on finding a resolution. How do I prepare for a meeting?

A meeting with our office is your opportunity to share your side of events and work on finding a resolution. How do I prepare for a meeting? We understand that connecting with our office can be overwhelming. Here’s some tips to help you feel ready: Review our policies and procedures so you know what to expect. Collect any important documentation like emails, text messages, screen captures, etc. You can send these to us before the meeting or bring them with you. If applicable, write down the names and contact information of any witnesses or other people involved. Make a timeline of events pr notes to help you remember details during the meeting. Consider if you want to bring a support person such as a family member, peer, or advisor. They can take notes and help be there as a moral support. Prepare any questions you have about the policies, procedures, outcome, etc. How do I challenge a decision made by SRR? The challenge process is outlined on page 6 of the

How do I challenge a decision made by SRR? The challenge process is outlined on page 6 of the Student Rights and Responsibilities Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-rights-and-responsibilities-procedure.pdf] If you want to challenge a decision that does not affect your academic status, email srr@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:srr@collegec.on.ca] and outline your grounds for appeal. The Director of Student Rights and Responsibilities will review it. Appropriate grounds for submitting a challenge are personal bias, unfair treatment or new information. Attach any documents any supporting documentation. If the decision does affect your academic status, submit a formal appeal form as outlined in Step 4 of the Academic Dispute and Appeal Resolution Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] (pdf).

Academic Dispute and Appeal Resolution Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] (pdf). You can find the form on the student portal under the Services tab, then click "Forms" in the Students in Full-time Programs section. Complete the Student Appeals Form on Laserfiche. Are my conversations with the SRRO confidential? Your conversations with the SRRO are private unless we believe you or someone else is at risk of harm. We won't act on your concerns without your permission unless there's an immediate risk. If we contact you because of a report, we may share some information with involved parties. All records are kept secure according to privacy laws. Exceptions [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/document/freedom-information-and-protection-privacy-manual/chapter-5-exemptions-and-exclusions] are records under statutes that expressly state that they prevail over FIPPA.

Exceptions [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/document/freedom-information-and-protection-privacy-manual/chapter-5-exemptions-and-exclusions] are records under statutes that expressly state that they prevail over FIPPA. Will SRR violations be visible on my permanent academic record? SRRO decisions and sanctions do not form part of a student's academic record except in cases of long-term suspension or discontinuance from the college. How long does it take to resolve an issue? We typically respond within 2 business days. Time to resolve an issue will depend on the concern, but we will try to move as quickly as possible and will keep you updated on timelines. Discontinuance and Reapplying Save Send Feedback The college will discontinue students who have a Term Weighted Average of less than 49.99% (for most programs) or have failed to clear probation after two consecutive terms. However, students should refer to their Academic Handbook Progression Requirements Guide [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide#appendices] for program specific requirements. Discontinued students are ineligible to register in their original Program of Studies for a minimum of one term. They can apply to another college program, if it doesn’t share a common platform to the program they were discontinued from. If a student wants to return to their original program after the discontinuance period, they must apply for re-admission. Please see the Discontinuance Procedure [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/policies/discontinuance-procedure] and Readmission Procedure [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/policies/readmission-procedure]

and Readmission Procedure [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/policies/readmission-procedure] for more information. Featured Video Using Elevator Pitch in VMock [LINK: /students/Videos/detail/38/using-elevator-pitch-in-vmock] Learn how to use VMock to practice your interview skills or 30 second personal pitch. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Learning Plan and Learning Contract Save Send Feedback A Learning Plan is a document developed between a student on Probation 1 [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts#:~:text=first%20probation%20(p1)] and a Student Success Advisor and is used to plan strategies that will support a student’s success. A Learning Contract is a formal agreement between the College and a student on Probation 2 [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts#:~:text=second%20probation%20(p2)] outlining specific achievement requirements for the student. Learning Contracts are required when students are on probation for a second time. Students on probation will receive an email from the Office of the Registrar to initiate the Learning Plan or Learning Contract process. Repeating Courses Save Send Feedback Students may attempt a course 2 times. A student wishing to register for a third time must have approval from the Academic Administrator with academic responsibility for the program. Before Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      should arrive 15-minutes before their test start time to secure personal      items and complete check-in. Testing      appointments may be cancelled if students arrive more than 20-minutes late      from the indicated start time. Present      a non-expired physical photo ID (OneCard or government-issued      ID). Only      items required for the assessment will be permitted in the testing      room. All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre.

All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre. To      maintain a quiet and controlled testing environment for all test takers,      children are not permitted within the Test Centre and cannot be left      unattended while any student is writing. All      computer-based tests at the Test Centre will be conducted on assigned      desktop computers. Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test.

Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test. Please      note the Test Centres may not have power outlets for laptops. To      ensure a comfortable and healthy environment for everyone, Test Centres      are a designated scent-free zone. We kindly request that all individuals      refrain from wearing or using scented products. Only      water is permitted in the testing room (approved accommodations      excepted). Featured FAQ Mental Health Support: Non-Emergency (College Specific) [LINK: /students/Faqs/detail/83/mental-health-support-non-emer] Counselling Services: Confidential, one-to-one appointments with counsellors are available to help students work through issues affecting their mental health.

Mental Health Support: Non-Emergency (College Specific) [LINK: /students/Faqs/detail/83/mental-health-support-non-emer] Counselling Services: Confidential, one-to-one appointments with counsellors are available to help students work through issues affecting their mental health. There is no cost to meet with a counsellor, and appointments can be in-person, virtual, or by telephone at all campuses. Dialogue Virtual... × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

During Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      are expected to follow direction of Test Centre staff. Students      can only communicate with Testing Centre staff. Staff cannot give any      guidance or answer questions regarding test/exam content. Faculty      will not be present in the Test Centre; however, students can request that      Test Centre staff to attempt to contact their faculty for clarifying      questions. Students      can request the use of blank scrap paper from Test Centre staff. All      testing materials must be returned to Test Centre staff at the end of the      test. It      is recommended that students use the washroom before their assessment. Washroom breaks during assessments will only be permitted if a Test Centre      staff member is available (approved accommodations excepted). In      case of emergency (fire alarm, lockdown), students are to follow the      instructions of the Test Centre staff.

Washroom breaks during assessments will only be permitted if a Test Centre      staff member is available (approved accommodations excepted). In      case of emergency (fire alarm, lockdown), students are to follow the      instructions of the Test Centre staff. The      Test Centre staff will adhere to the guidelines established by the Academic      Integrity [LINK: https://library.collegec.on.ca/academic-integrity] department in the event of an academic integrity      breach. College College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way.

Understanding Math Anxiety Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1470053] Understanding math anxiety Math anxiety is more than just disliking math. Sometimes you may feel: Fear of making mistakes, lack of confidence in math. Fast heart beating, sweatiness, nausea when anticipating or engaging in math tasks. Wanting to quit when confused or making mistakes in math. Stress before evaluations such as tests, quizzes and exams. Nervous before math class. Procrastination of math homework or assignments. Unable to concentrate on a math task. Does math anxiety affect math ability? The video below explains more about what math anxiety is and does to your brain when you're experiencing it. Math anxiety and working memory Our working memory is a system in our brain responsible for temporarily storing and manipulating information and is essential when solving most math problems. Our working memory can store very limited amounts of information.

Our working memory is a system in our brain responsible for temporarily storing and manipulating information and is essential when solving most math problems. Our working memory can store very limited amounts of information. The amount of information our working memory can store at one time is sometimes referred to a s cognitive load. When our cognitive load has reached its maximum capacity, we stop processing information. Elevated levels of anxiety can affect working memory, decreasing its efficiency. This is not permanent and only occurs for the duration of time that the anxiety lasts. Since math requires working memory, trying to do math under high levels of anxiety can at times feel impossible. So what does this mean? Anxiety can affect math performance no matter how good someone is at math. Our math skills may be just fine and we need to tackle the anxiety!

Anxiety can affect math performance no matter how good someone is at math. Our math skills may be just fine and we need to tackle the anxiety! When we learn to reduce the anxiety we feel when doing or anticipating math tasks, our working memory can process information much more easily and efficiently, making things seem more manageable. Myths about math Math comes with its stereotypes. Here are three things that are not true about math: People of different race and sex have varying innate math ability There is a best way to solve a math problem You have to have a 'math brain' to understand math Debunking math stereotypes can shed some positive light on the subject and our ability to improve our math skills. The next time you hear someone say any of the things above, remember they are not true! Strategies for overcoming and managing math anxiety The following strategies are things you can start doing today to help manage and overcome math anxiety.

Strategies for overcoming and managing math anxiety The following strategies are things you can start doing today to help manage and overcome math anxiety. This list is not exhaustive and some things may work better for some people than others. There is no particular order in which you have to follow the strategies. Try whichever ones resonate best with you! Strengthen foundational math knowledge Math builds on itself. Imagine trying to calculate 5+7−4 without knowing how addition or subtractions works. This would be extremely difficult and could lead to things like lack of confidence, defeat, and frustration. Having strong foundational knowledge of the prerequisite skills needed for the math you are required to do will make things easier. When you attempt to solve a math problem without the required foundational knowledge, your working memory can become overloaded. Cognitive load is the amount of information that can be stored in working memory at one time.

When you attempt to solve a math problem without the required foundational knowledge, your working memory can become overloaded. Cognitive load is the amount of information that can be stored in working memory at one time. The weaker your foundational math knowledge is, the more resources are taken up in working memory when solving a math problem, increasing cognitive load and leaving fewer brain resources for the steps required to solve the problem at hand. With a stronger math foundation, more working memory resources can be allocated to solving the problem at hand, and less on trying to understand the basics at the same time. The stronger our basics, the more math confidence you can build. Not sure what foundational knowledge you need to strengthen? Check out this list of foundational math skills. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/9] Find math learning strategies that work for you On the

Find math learning strategies that work for you On the math learning page [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/9] you can find a list of math learning strategies you can try. You can keep track of the strategies you have used in a Strategies Checklist Chart [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/157] . Not all math learning strategies will work for everyone. It is important that you find the ones that work for you. Implementing a math learning strategy will improve understanding, help to develop skills and increase confidence. More learning and study strategies can be found on the Learning & Study Skills page. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/learningstudyskills] Regular math practice Practicing math by solving math problems is essential to gaining stronger math understanding.

Regular math practice Practicing math by solving math problems is essential to gaining stronger math understanding. Studies [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fuweb.cas.usf.edu.mcas.ms%2F~drohrer%2Fpdfs%2FHartwig_et_al_2022JEPA.pdf%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] show that spacing out math practice over a period of time rather than completing it all-at-once helps knowledge retention. Diaphragm breathing Diaphragm breathing is a breathing technique that engages the diaphragm (a muscle at the base of our lungs and heart). This breathing technique can help to calm us by lowering heartbeat and stabilizing blood pressure (Learning Diaphragmatic Breathing, 2016) The video below is a demonstration of how to breath with your diaphragm: More math anxiety resources:

The video below is a demonstration of how to breath with your diaphragm: More math anxiety resources: Embracing failure [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fsuccessportal.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fstudents%2Fvideos%2Fdetail%2F20%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] to benefit your academic and personal growth. Download this document [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fsuccessportal.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fstudents%2Fdocs%2FDetail%2F94%3FMcasTsid%3D20892&McasCSRF=66ad11c9b90ec82b03a3b876260eab4bbb9c2745dd88156ac77b83d00c4997ea] on embracing failure.

Starting your term off right for math success Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/1470047] Things pick up quickly once the semester gets going. It is important to start the semester on the right foot and prepare yourself. Check out the tips below to help you start your math course with the right mindset. Get math help early Math builds on itself. Likely, what you learn in the first lesson of your math class will be needed throughout the course. Reach out to your instructor or book a math help appointment as soon as you are: Confused about a topic you learned in class. Stuck on a math practice problem. Preparing for a math test, quiz, etc. Remember, College provides free math help [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/math] for eligible students. Follow your instructional plan Your instructional plan will give you an overview of the topics to be covered in your math course.

Follow your instructional plan Your instructional plan will give you an overview of the topics to be covered in your math course. Set aside some time to check over the plan before your class, so you know what topics will be covered. Even if these topics are new to you, it’s good to prepare yourself for what will come next. Don't skip the first class The first class is when the instructor explains the overview of the course, what their expectations are for students and what students can expect from the instructor. You will benefit from attending this first class for many reasons, including: Getting an overview of the course in a nutshell. Receiving information on free college resources (like math help!). Learning where to locate textbooks and class materials. Experiencing the first lesson. Meeting others in the class. Meeting your instructor. Learning the instructor's office hours. Explore your eCollege course shell Every math class is different.

Explore your eCollege course shell Every math class is different. It’s important to explore your eCollege course shell for class notes, instructor announcements, and extra resources you may need during the course. Here are some things to explore in the course shell during the first week of classes: Location of class notes. Format of class notes (printable slides, videos, etc.). Calculator requirements. Pearson MyLab or Lyryx log in (if your instructor uses it). Online textbooks. Math help appointment booking instructions. Does your class use Pearson MyLab? The Study Plan feature is a great tool for extra practice and tracking progress. This video [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/videos/detail/12] walks you through how to use the Study Plan feature. Explore math resources outside of class There are many free, useful math resources available outside of the classroom, from graphing technology to interactive mini-lessons. We recommend exploring our list of

There are many free, useful math resources available outside of the classroom, from graphing technology to interactive mini-lessons. We recommend exploring our list of math content resources and exercises by topic [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/10] and that you save the 10 Math Success Strategies [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/docs/Detail/90] in your notebook or on your bulletin board at home! It can solve a variety of math problems, from simple addition to integration. Assistive and Learning Technologies services at College provide assistive math technologies [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/assistive-technology/math] for students to make math learning easier. Examples include math screen readers and math equation editors. You can book an assistive and learning technology appointment [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/assistive-technology] if you would like assistance or more information on these resources. Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

College College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way.

These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. College protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to privacy@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:privacy@collegec.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Walk-in Clinics Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/3461120] Walk-in clinics and urgent care centers provide medical care for people who do not have a primary care health provider, or have one but are unable to reach them. You can see a nurse or doctor without an appointment for minor illness and injuries, but often there is a line or longer wait times. When you go to a walk-in clinic or urgent care center, you need to bring your College International Health Insurance Plan card (for international students) or your OHIP card (for Ontario residents). If you live in Waterloo or Kitchener, here is a list of walk-in clinics that you can visit: 1. Benton Medical Centre [LINK: http://www.bentonmedicalclinic.com] 51 Benton St, Kitchener 226-240-3014 2. KW Healthy Living Family Practice [LINK: http://www.kwmedicalcentre.com] 1360 Weber St E, Kitchener 519-893-6060 3. KW Urgent Care Clinics [LINK: http://www.kwurgentcare.ca/]

3. KW Urgent Care Clinics [LINK: http://www.kwurgentcare.ca/] 385 Fairway Rd S, Kitchener 519-748-2327 751 Victoria St S, Kitchener 519-745-2273 4. K-W Walk-In Clinic [LINK: https://waterlooclinic.com/] 100 The Boardwalk, Kitchener (Walmart) 519-279-4098 5. Kitchener Walk-In Clinic [LINK: https://www.kitchenerwalkin.ca/] 5 Manitou Drive, Kitchener 519-904-4200 6. Laurentian Walk-in Clinic [LINK: https://www.wwhealthline.ca/displayservice.aspx?id=101690] 750 Ottawa St S, Kitchener (Zehrs) 519-570-3174 7. Onyx Urgent Care [LINK: https://onyxurgentcare.com/] 580 Lancaster St W, Kitchener 519-896-6699 8. Spruce Medical Walk-in Clinic [LINK: http://www.sprucemedical.ca] 318 Spruce St, Unit 105, Waterloo 519-725-1111 9. Tannery Medical Centre 120-121 Charles St W, Kitchener 519-618-9260 10. Waterloo Walk-in Clinic [LINK: https://waterlooclinic.com/] University Shops Plaza II 170 University Ave W, Unit 13, Waterloo 519-725-1514 11.

519-725-1514 11. Westmount Place Walk-In Clinic [LINK: https://waterlooclinic.com/] 50 Westmount Rd N, Waterloo 519-954-0111 If you live outside of Waterloo or Kitchener, you can find your nearest walk-in clinic or urgent care center by searching “walk-in clinic near me” on your preferred internet browser. Emergency Room Information Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/3400236] You should only go to an emergency room if you have a life-threatening medical emergency. There may be longer wait times, especially if your concern is not a life-threatening medical emergency. When you go to an emergency department, you need to bring your College International Health Insurance Plan card (for international students) or your OHIP card (for Ontario residents). If you live in Waterloo, Kitchener, Cambridge or Guelph, here is a list of the local emergency departments. 1. Grand River Hospital Emergency Room [LINK: https://www.grhosp.on.ca/care/services-departments/emergency/current-emergency-wait] 835 King St. W Kitchener, ON 2. Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

College College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way.

These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. College protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to privacy@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:privacy@collegec.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

Alternative Mice & Keyboards Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2866648] Alternative Mice & Keyboards All items are available to borrow for a two-week loan from the Teach Me Tech Lab (room 2A501) at Doon. Students at other campuses wishing to access these resources can do so by emailing us. [LINK: mailto:at@collegec.on.ca] Mice 3M Ergonomic Mouse The vertical grip design of the 3M Ergonomic Mouse keeps your hand and wrist at a neutral angle for improved comfort and ease-of-use, while the mouse works as a regular optical mouse. Device comes with: Bag Learn how to use the 3M Ergonomic Mouse (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35025618] Evoluent VerticalMouse (right) For relief of wrist pain. Evoluent's ergonomic VerticalMouse supports your right hand in an upright neutral position that avoids forearm twisting (for improved comfort and relief of wrist pain). Device comes with: Bag Driver for Windows

Bag Driver for Windows Learn how to use the Evoluent VerticalMouse (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35025365] Genius Pen Mouse The Genius Pen Mouse is a pen-shaped mouse that is designed for both right- and left-handed use, and gives you better handling and more comfort than a regular mouse. Device comes with: Pico Receiver CD for Software Installation Metal Clip Two Pen Tips Carrying Case User's Manual Learn how to use the Genius Pen Mouse (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35025976] Kensington Orbit Optical For greater comfort and ease-of-use. The symmetrical shape and hand-hugging design of the Orbit Optical Trackball provide the comfort and support of a mouse with the ease-of-use of a fingertip-controlled trackball. Device comes with: Bag Learn how to use the Kensington Orbit Optical (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35025607] Kensington Wireless Mobile Trackball

[LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35025607] Kensington Wireless Mobile Trackball Eases pain of repetitive stress injuries. The Orbit Wireless Mobile Trackball is an alternative mouse with a centered ball design that enables touch scrolling and can ease the pain of repetitive-stress injuries. Device comes with: Bag Learn how to use the Kensington Wireless Mobile Trackball (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35025370] Logitech MX Ergo Wireless Trackball Mouse NX Ergo is an ergonomic trackball mouse that reduces hand and wrist movement and results in 20% less muscle fatigue than a regular mouse. Device comes with: Bag Learn how to use the MX Ergo Wireless Trackball Mouse (User Guide) [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=36735335] Logitech MX Vertical Wireless Mouse MX Vertical is an advanced ergonomic mouse that is designed to reduce muscle strain, decrease wrist pressure, and improve posture. Device comes with: Box

Device comes with: Box Learn how to use the MX Vertical Wireless Mouse (User Guide) [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=36735327] Mycestro Mycestro is a wearable 3D mouse that fits on the index finger and allows you to control your computer, tablet, or phone using gestures and mouse-like functions. It can perform all the functions of a traditional computer mouse and more. Device comes with: Bag USB Cable Learn how to use the Mycestro (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35025854] Traxsys Joystick Plus Mouse The Joystick Plus alternative mouse is ideal for individuals who may have difficulties with a conventional mouse. Special features include a speed control key, latching drag switch, and buttons that allow only up/down or left/right movements of the cursor. Device comes with: SoftKnob (Yellow) T-bar (Black) Slim Joystick Perspex Keyguard USB to PS/2 Adaptor Learn how to use the Traxsys Joystick Plus mouse (User Guide).

USB to PS/2 Adaptor Learn how to use the Traxsys Joystick Plus mouse (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35024990] Keyboards Goldtouch Adjustable Keyboard Prevents carpal tunnel syndrome and other repetitive stress injuries. The Goldtouch Adjustable Keyboard offers complete adjustability, with 0°-30° of adjustments on the horizontal and vertical planes, helping to prevent carpal tunnel syndrome and other RSIs. This compact keyboard fits well in limited spaces, reducing shoulder strain when reaching for mice and other peripherals. Learn how to use the Goldtouch V2 Adjustable keyboard (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35026424] Key-U-See Keyboard Easy-to-see large print keys. Keys-U-See is a USB keyboard that has large print keys that are easy to see, even in low light, and includes internet, multimedia and energy-saver hot keys. Requires a USB keyboard connection. Learn how to use the Keys-U-See keyboard (User Guide).

Requires a USB keyboard connection. Learn how to use the Keys-U-See keyboard (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35026198] Logitech Ergo K860 Wireless Ergonomic Keyboard The Logitech Ergo K860 Wireless Ergonomic Keyboard is an advanced ergonomic keyboard that promotes a more relaxed typing posture - reducing wrist bending by 25% and offering 54% more wrist support. Device comes with: Box Learn how to use the Logitech Ergo K860 Wireless Ergonomic Keyboard (User Guide) [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=36735338] Microsoft Ergonomic Keyboard Promotes more natural hand, wrist and forearm position. The advanced design of the Microsoft Ergonomic Keyboard promotes a more natural hand, wrist, and forearm position for greater comfort, and its curved key layout makes keys easier to reach. The Zoom Slider lets you zoom in for close-ups of Web pages, images, and more with the touch of a finger.

The advanced design of the Microsoft Ergonomic Keyboard promotes a more natural hand, wrist, and forearm position for greater comfort, and its curved key layout makes keys easier to reach. The Zoom Slider lets you zoom in for close-ups of Web pages, images, and more with the touch of a finger. Learn how to use the Microsoft Ergonomic Keyboard (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35026439] Slimtouch 270 Keyboard Waterproof, antimicrobial keyboard. The Slimtouch 270 is an antimicrobial, waterproof keyboard made for smooth and quiet performance. The keyboard has a USB interface that easily connects without having to install specific drivers. Learn how to use the Slimtouch 270 keyboard (User Guide). [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/ld.php?content_id=35026388] Typematrix Keyboard Reduces wrist, arm, & shoulder strain. The straight vertical key column layout of the Typematrix keyboard works to increase typing accuracy and decrease wrist distortion.

The straight vertical key column layout of the Typematrix keyboard works to increase typing accuracy and decrease wrist distortion. Its slim size can also decrease the reaching distance to a user's mouse, and lessen arm and shoulder stress. TypeMatrix supports the Dvorak typing method and can switch from QWERTY to Dvorak modes. Learn how to use the Typematrix keyboard (User Guide). Contact – Student Success Portal For assistance with services on the Student Success Portal , please visit the specific service site from the HOME landing page. Each service will have unique contact information and methods that you can use to reach the service directly with your questions.

College College collects personal information from students under the legal authority of the Ontario Colleges of Applied Arts and Technology Act and ensures the personal information is managed in compliance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act in order offer students a comprehensive program of career-oriented, post-secondary education and training. The purpose of the Student Success Portal is to provide students with one shared system that enables students to self-book appointments with a variety of service teams at the College. As such, service teams will create consultation notes for students to review. These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way.

These may include appointment notes and recommended actions. Students can also access resources and request assistance via forms within the system where to ensure the relevant information can be used to support students in a timely and effective way. Students participating in Events & Activities are acknowledging the sharing of their information for the purposes of tracking booking, attendance and follow-up activities by college services and opportunity providers. College protects personal information and only discloses it as required by law. If you have any questions, please reach out to privacy@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:privacy@collegec.on.ca] . By accepting these terms, you consent to the Student Success Portal and the information sharing provisions within it.

International Student Support Services - International Transition Save Kitchener,
 Canada Industry 1 [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/search?industry=5202] College College [LINK: https://linkedin.com/company/College College] About International Transition Coordinators (ITCs) provide specialized service to international students to support their smooth transition to Canada and College College. We engage students at the pre-arrival stage and continue to provide guidance throughout their College journey. We offer important resources and information, relevant referrals, comprehensive webinar programming, student-focused campus outreach booths, and individualized one-on-one advising. Our extensive service includes supporting students with settlement and acculturation, including early college onboarding, travel to Canada, housing, accessing college and community resources, and more!

May 30 Attending vendors - Thundersnow Clay & Cards, Beads Beauty, Mountain Woodwork Canada, DREY Natural & Evolution, Havilah Jane Arts, peachytaozi.co, MaigeCreations, SimplySanDIY, M&3, The New Quarterly, Espoir Illustrations, Shifty Story, Fuchsia Peaches, Olena Chorna Fine Arts, Mightycat Scents, TATA Games Studio, Tanu and Sangram, Artist.Venus, Juneipers, and Vladimir Skvortsov. 7 to 9 p.m. - Live music by Sarah McLeod [LINK: https://www.facebook.com/sarahmcleodmusic/] , a self-taught solo musician who is growing her live shows across the Tri-Cities.

Sarah McLeod [LINK: https://www.facebook.com/sarahmcleodmusic/] , a self-taught solo musician who is growing her live shows across the Tri-Cities. [LINK: /en/things-to-do/open-streets.aspx] National Indigenous Peoples Day (June 21) [LINK: #] June 21 is National Indigenous Peoples Day. This day recognizes the cultures and contributions of the First Nations, Inuit, and Metis peoples, communities and nations. The City of Waterloo has been marking this occasion for the past eight years by partnering with local Indigenous artists who create and install original art pieces on the surface of Waterloo Public Square. These artworks serve as a visual reminder of the territory and land on which the city was founded. For 2025, Maddie Resmer, of Western Sky Designs [LINK: https://westernskydesigns.ca/]

For 2025, Maddie Resmer, of Western Sky Designs [LINK: https://westernskydesigns.ca/] , created a mural to honour the Anishinàbe worldview of interconnectedness. Watch the artist YouTube video [LINK: https://youtu.be/zYM2flt7t0s] to learn more about the design and story behind this years National Indigenous Peoples Day mural. Artist Statement: A circle of lifeforms moves together, each shape holding space for the next. This year’s mural honours the Anishinàbe worldview of interconnectedness, illustrating how all beings — animal, plant, sky, water, and land — are woven together into the delicate fabric of life. The gentle flow of forms reminds us of the humility required to know our place within, not above, the natural world. In this circle, the anishinàbe (person) is no more vital than the makwa (bear), nor is the ininatig (maple) greater than the nigig (otter).

nigig (otter). However, as we each lose empathy for (and connection to) the beings around us, so too do we lose one of nature’s greatest assets: diversity. In a time of growing division and unchecked individualism, our collective well-being depends on embracing these decolonized visions — futures rooted in balance, reciprocity, and care for all our relations. [LINK: /en/things-to-do/winterloo.aspx] Year round programming Neighbourhood Picnic Tables [LINK: #] City of Waterloo invites the public to come enjoy these creative, unique, and vibrant picnic tables featured in the Neighbourhood  Picnic Table Program. In 2021, in partnership with the City of Waterloo's Neighbourhoods team, Create Waterloo commissioned 18 local artists to create custom artwork on picnic tables located in one of six community gardens throughout Waterloo. In 2022, another 12 tables were added to the collection in four new neighbourhood parks. In 2023, an additional nine artists painted picnic tables in three more neighbourhood parks throughout Waterloo.

College Consent Culture Save Kitchener,
 Canada https://www.collegec.on.ca/student-engagement [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/student-engagement] Industry 1 [LINK: /students/organisations/search?industry=5202] About College Consent Culture is a series of workshops, events, and courses that help the College community in its pursuit to end gender-based violence (GBV). A series of workshops teach participants to ask for consent each time, stand up against norms that uphold rape culture and supports students by directing them to appropriate college and community resources. Have questions or looking for more information? College's Sexual and Gender-Based Violence Prevention and Support Office provides help based on your individual needs. There is no timeframe for when an incident occurred for someone to access support, and you do not need to disclose what happened in order to get help. Please email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca]

Please email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca] for appointments and information. When I am on a co-op term or completing my field placement, can I still work on or/and off-campus as an international student? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1970521] If a student with a Co-op Work Permit has full-time status during the “work experience” portion of their program (co-op or field placement), and if the student continues to comply with the eligibility requirements, the student may be eligible to work on and/or off-campus, in addition to their co-op/field placement work hours. If you have questions about your work eligibility, please book an appointment with your assigned International Student Immigration Advisor or email internationaladvisor@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaladvisor@collegec.on.ca] Find your ISIA by using our online tool [LINK: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=OjndTYrpBESEH8S-zdklpVu6V3IGYbRBjOsR_roF2JVURDNPVDZKVllJQzVEVVdTU0NMOURCV1Y2RSQlQCN0PWcu] before booking an appointment.

What is considered "full-time" work for international students? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/1970503] There is no set number of hours per week that counts as ‘full-time’ work for international students. You are free to work overtime or work two part-time jobs that add up to a greater than usual number of hours. However, your employer(s) must follow all provincial laws on overtime pay and time between shifts. Is Counselling for Me? Save Send Feedback Many students find they struggle to cope with various pressures they experience at times. It can be hard to live on your own for the first time or adjust to living in a new country. You may be worried about your academic performance or have test-taking anxiety. You may be simply overwhelmed with having to juggle so many demands such as work, relationships and school. In life, we can also face unexpected events such as a death, loss of a relationship, or a traumatic event that can affect us significantly. Counselling is a safe space where you will not be judged for what you are thinking, feeling or doing. Meeting with a counsellor can help reduce your feelings of stress and help you develop new perspectives and strategies for moving forward. Counselling Myths Seeing a counsellor means I’m "crazy," "weak," or "mentally ill." My problems aren’t severe enough for counselling. I don’t have time to meet with a counsellor for many weeks.

My problems aren’t severe enough for counselling. I don’t have time to meet with a counsellor for many weeks. When we are in physical pain, we know it is okay to reach out to a doctor for help. It is equally okay to reach out to a counsellor when you are experiencing emotional pain. Counsellors can support students who struggle with anxiety, depression, suicidal thoughts and self-harm behaviour. Counselling is also a great preventive resource to help deal with worries, lack of motivation, feeling lonely and relationship challenges. Counselling is not intended to eliminate all your problems or "fix" you. You are not broken! Once you start seeing a counsellor, it does not mean you need to keep seeing the counsellor for a long time - many students are surprised by the positive impact of just one session. What to Expect When you reach out to schedule your first appointment, you get to decide if you would like to meet with the counsellor in person, over the telephone or virtually.

What to Expect When you reach out to schedule your first appointment, you get to decide if you would like to meet with the counsellor in person, over the telephone or virtually. You can also indicate if you prefer to meet with a male or female counsellor. During the appointment, you can expect a conversation where you and the counsellor discuss what has prompted you to reach out at this time. The counsellor will ask questions about your strengths, things that you have tried in the past, what you hope will change, or what needs to change to reduce your current stress level. The counsellor will help you set realistic goals for change and then work with you on how to make those changes happen.
