During Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      are expected to follow direction of Test Centre staff. Students      can only communicate with Testing Centre staff. Staff cannot give any      guidance or answer questions regarding test/exam content. Faculty      will not be present in the Test Centre; however, students can request that      Test Centre staff to attempt to contact their faculty for clarifying      questions. Students      can request the use of blank scrap paper from Test Centre staff. All      testing materials must be returned to Test Centre staff at the end of the      test. It      is recommended that students use the washroom before their assessment. Washroom breaks during assessments will only be permitted if a Test Centre      staff member is available (approved accommodations excepted). In      case of emergency (fire alarm, lockdown), students are to follow the      instructions of the Test Centre staff.

On Wednesday, January 22nd join Student Success to break down the stigma related to mental health as part of Bell Let's Talk Day [LINK: https://letstalk.bell.ca/] . What Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP) am I eligible for if my program is a two-year program completed in sixteen months? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/faq/4064375] For a two-year program completed in sixteen months, the program length is considered to be two years and, therefore, you should be eligible for a three-year PGWP. You can find your program length on the program webpage [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/programs-and-courses] or on your Letter of Acceptance (LOA). Assistive Software Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2866629] Assistive Software We have the following software available at all College campuses within the designated assistive technology space(s) [LINK: https://lib.collegec.on.ca/assistive-technology/hours-locations] . Read&Write For reading, writing, studying & research. Download links: Read&Write - Windows Set Up [LINK: https://fastdownloads2.texthelp.com/readwrite12/installers/ca/read&write.exe] Read&Write - Mac Setup [LINK: https://fastdownloads2.texthelp.com/readwritemac7/installers/read&write.dmg?_ga=2.10348597.1620579241.1571662788-848083162.1557423867] Read&Write - Chrome Browser Extension [LINK: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/readwrite-for-google-chro/inoeonmfapjbbkmdafoankkfajkcphgd] Read&Write - Edge Browser Extension [LINK: https://microsoftedge.microsoft.com/addons/detail/readwrite-for-microsoft-/bjglhpoliipklkfjcahfefdlfpifcinb]

Read&Write - Chrome Browser Extension [LINK: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/readwrite-for-google-chro/inoeonmfapjbbkmdafoankkfajkcphgd] Read&Write - Edge Browser Extension [LINK: https://microsoftedge.microsoft.com/addons/detail/readwrite-for-microsoft-/bjglhpoliipklkfjcahfefdlfpifcinb] Choose the Microsoft Account option when logging in and use your College email and password. Read&Write is a literacy toolbar with text-to-speech as well as learning tools to support reading, writing, studying and research within common computer applications. The full version of Read&Write is available for all current College students and employees to download using the links above. For Read&Write for Chromebooks, iPad, or Android tablets, please email us [LINK: mailto:at@collegec.on.ca] . Training Resources: Quick Reference Guide [LINK: https://www.texthelp.com/Uploads/MediaLibrary/texthelp/US-Training-Documents/Read-Write-for-Windows-Quick-Reference-Guide-11-2F2018.pdf]

Training Resources: Quick Reference Guide [LINK: https://www.texthelp.com/Uploads/MediaLibrary/texthelp/US-Training-Documents/Read-Write-for-Windows-Quick-Reference-Guide-11-2F2018.pdf] Training Guide [LINK: https://www.texthelp.com/Uploads/MediaLibrary/texthelp/US-Training-Documents/Read-Write-for-Windows-Quick-Start-Guide-USA-Jan-2019-(1).pdf] Read&Write for Windows Tutorials [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLvSZbmGbKpCQEi1OB-nu-wA5KexHppO9C] Read&Write Study Skills for Use in University (20 minute course) [LINK: https://training.texthelp.com/course/view.php?id=77] (Choose 'Login with Microsoft' and use your College email address and password) Dragon NaturallySpeaking Dragon NaturallySpeaking is a speech-to-text software program that allows you to turn your voice into text by speaking naturally. College provides access to the Windows version, but a mobile version is also available for you to purchase [LINK: https://www.nuance.com/dragon.html] . Quick links:

. Quick links: Get started using Dragon with these user guides [LINK: https://www.nuance.com/dragon/support/dragon-naturallyspeaking.html] Video - Dragon in action [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ImlKOA1MhlI] Mindomo Mindomo is a mind-mapping tool that can be used for: Brainstorming Capturing ideas and concepts Organizing written assignments and presentations Time and task management Users can access Mindomo online, as desktop software for Windows & Mac, as well as on Android, Chrome and iOS devices Access to Mindomo is available to students registered with Accessible Learning Services. Please reach out to AT@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:AT@collegec.on.ca] or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Quick links: Video - How to build a simple mind map with Mindomo [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DSnCEXpqi50] Video - How to create a mind map from your learning material [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=83JXkIrc4wM] ZoomText

Video - How to create a mind map from your learning material [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=83JXkIrc4wM] ZoomText ZoomText Magnifier/Reader is a fully integrated magnification and reading program tailored for low-vision users. Magnifier/Reader enlarges and enhances everything on your computer screen, echoes your typing and essential program activity, and automatically reads documents, web pages, and email. Quick links: Get Started using ZoomText with these user guides [LINK: https://zoomtext.zendesk.com/hc/en-us?_ga=2.264405452.2125255696.1531494935-161026172.1531494935] Video - Introducing ZoomText 11 [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fhLV6ydGqWg] JAWS JAWS (Job Access With Speech) is a screen reader that allows students who are blind or visually impaired to navigate the Internet and most Windows-based applications with a text-to-speech output or by a Refreshable Braille display. Quick links:

JAWS (Job Access With Speech) is a screen reader that allows students who are blind or visually impaired to navigate the Internet and most Windows-based applications with a text-to-speech output or by a Refreshable Braille display. Quick links: Get started using JAWS with these user guides [LINK: https://www.freedomscientific.com/products/blindness/jawsdocumentation] Video - Navigating Websites with JAWS [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3MUEyYoKwx0] Genio Notes Genio Notes is a recording and notetaking tool. Features: Record your lectures in class and online Add labels and notes Transcribe Compatibility: Chrome browser, Android, and iOS mobile devices Access to Genio Notes is available to students registered with Accessible Learning Services. Please reach out AT@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:AT@collegec.on.ca] or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Built-in Accessibility Features

or your Accessible Learning Advisor for more information. Built-in Accessibility Features Most devices have powerful accessibility features already built into their operating systems. Our staff can help provide you with support to use your devices more effectively. Mac OS-X and iOS Accessibility Features On an Apple product, go to the "Accessibility" icon under the Settings icon to access the following tools: VoiceOver: screen reader Zoom: magnifier Display Accommodations like Dark mode Assistive Touch Text to Speech Quick links: Learn more about Mac OS-X and iOS Accessibility Features [LINK: https://www.apple.com/ca/accessibility/mac/] Video Playlist - Apple Accessibility [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLIl2EzNYri0cLtSlZowttih25VnSvWITu] Windows Accessibility Features On a Microsoft product, go to the "Ease of Access Center" in the computer's control panel. The Ease of Access Center provides access to the following tools: Magnifier Narrator: screen reader

Magnifier Narrator: screen reader Windows Speech Recognition On- Screen Keyboard Quick links: Learn more about Windows Accessibility Features [LINK: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/products/windows-accessibility?os=windows-10] Video - How to Customize Ease of Access Settings in Windows 10 [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xQMCMPbqeq8lity?os=windows-10] Featured Info Page After Your Assessment [LINK: /students/InfoPages/detail/44/after-your-assessment] What to expect after an assessment in the Test Centre × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Academic Discontinuance Save Send Feedback If you are discontinued, this means you will be de-registered from your program and cannot continue your studies for a defined period of time. Academic discontinuance decisions are made when students fail to meet their program's academic standards as published in the Academic Advancement and Achievement Policy [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-advancement-and-achievement-policy.pdf] or in your Academic School Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/index] . Continuing as a College Student If you are interested in continuing your studies in the same program, you can apply for readmission after your discontinuance period has concluded or apply for a new program. The terms of your discontinuance, including the length of time, in the original discontinuance email you received from your Program Coordinator. For more information, please review the

The terms of your discontinuance, including the length of time, in the original discontinuance email you received from your Program Coordinator. For more information, please review the Readmission Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/readmission-procedure.pdf] . Selecting a New Program For help with which programs are available, the application process, or admission requirements, use one of these contacts: International Students: InternationalAdmissions@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:InternationalAdmissions@collegec.on.ca] Domestic Students: admissions@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:admissions@collegec.on.ca] For help with career goals, use one of these contacts: International Students: CareerServices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:CareerServices@collegec.on.ca] Domestic Students: SRA@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:SRA@collegec.on.ca] Appeal Options

SRA@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:SRA@collegec.on.ca] Appeal Options If a policy has been applied incorrectly, or if you had a significant medical event, then it may be possible to request an appeal. There are specific criteria that must be met and your appeal must usually be received within five business days of when you received the notification from your Program Coordinator. Please see the College's Academic Dispute Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] for more information. You may also wish to learn more about support from the CSI Student Advocates [LINK: https://www.collegestudents.com/representation/academicappeals/] . College Consent Culture Save Kitchener,
 Canada https://www.collegec.on.ca/student-engagement [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/student-engagement] Industry 1 [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/search?industry=5202] About College Consent Culture is a series of workshops, events, and courses that help the College community in its pursuit to end gender-based violence (GBV). A series of workshops teach participants to ask for consent each time, stand up against norms that uphold rape culture and supports students by directing them to appropriate college and community resources. Have questions or looking for more information? College's Sexual and Gender-Based Violence Prevention and Support Office provides help based on your individual needs. There is no timeframe for when an incident occurred for someone to access support, and you do not need to disclose what happened in order to get help. Please email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca]

Please email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca] for appointments and information. View College Consent Culture jobs [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/jobs/2198852/college-consent-culture] Events College Consent Culture: Bystander Intervention [LINK: /s/student-engagement/events/Detail/5266298/college-consent-culture-byst] This workshop provides participants with a foundational knowledge of what sexual violence is and discusses what effective bystander intervention looks like. There will be an opportunity to explore how you can intervene, and what the effects are of different intervention tactics. 6 Aug 2025, 12:30 pm View all College Consent Culture events [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/events/2198852/college-consent-culture]

What are assistive technologies? Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /students/experiences/add/from/infopage/2859407] Assistive Technology Overview Students registered with Accessible Learning [LINK: https://studentsuccess.collegec.on.ca/myLearning/AcademicAndTestingAccommodations] have access to many different assistive technologies to support their learning. What is Assistive Technology? Assistive Technology (AT) is any equipment used to increase efficiency, maintain function, or improve the capability of individuals with disabilities. Students use Assistive Technology to research, write, and study more effectively. Examples Text-to-Speech Software: speaks everything on a computer screen, including alternative format textbooks, website text etc. Speech-to-text Software: allows the user to say commands and to enter text using their voice Recording devices: allows the user to capture information presented verbally (i.e.lectures) to review at a later time

Speech-to-text Software: allows the user to say commands and to enter text using their voice Recording devices: allows the user to capture information presented verbally (i.e.lectures) to review at a later time Frequency Modulation (FM) Systems: transmits an instructor’s voice directly to the student at a constant level, ensuring that the instructor’s voice is heard above the level of background noise Mind-mapping software: allows the user to organize their ideas through web-diagrams and create visual linkages between concepts Word Prediction: predicts words on the basis of the first few letters typed, which allows users to select the required word from a drop down menu Adapted from College [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Committee on Disability Issues (CCDI): LD Resource Guide, 2008 [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Assistive Technology Available

Committee on Disability Issues (CCDI): LD Resource Guide, 2008 [LINK: http://www.disabilityissues.ca/english/Link_docs/LDResour.pdf] Assistive Technology Available Our labs are equipped with computers, height-adjustable desks, printers, scanners, software programs and devices to support a wide variety of learning needs. AT available at all College campuses: Text-to-speech software: Read&Write Speech-to-text: Dragon Naturally Speaking Screen Magnifier: ZoomText Screen reader: JAWS Mind-mapping software: Mindomo Note taking support: Glean, Digital recorders, Smart Pens Alternative keyboards and mice × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Winter 2025: Interim Semester for Discontinued Students Save Send Feedback Join the General Arts and Science (GAS) Interim Semester (0791), which allows you to maintain full-time status (on probation). Courses available during the Interim Semester: COMM 2210 (or 1085 if you were not successful in this course) MDIA1070 – Information, Data and Current Events (GenEd) SOC1140 Canada in the Future (GenEd) Two Program Electives that can be selected from your original program or the GAS electives list. After the Interim Semester If you clear probation, you can register for your original program using an Advanced Standing application for any level beyond Level 1. If you need to start in Level 1, you must reapply through OCAS. If you are unsuccessful in the interim semester, you will be discontinued and must apply for another program. The Interim Semester is not an option for two consecutive terms. Important Notes

The Interim Semester is not an option for two consecutive terms. Important Notes The interim semester does not replace or override the "discontinuance requirement" from your current program. Students must still meet the waiting period for discontinuance as indicated in the notice from your academic area before being able to continue in your original program. Not all elective courses taken in the interim semester will work towards your desired program of study. Please speak with your Student Success Advisor or Program Coordinator when choosing electives. International Students must remain in compliance with requirements set out by Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) to be eligible for a post-graduate work permit (PGWP). Please speak with an International Student Immigration Advisor (ISIA) for clarification about these rules. Here are some questions you might ask them:

Please speak with an International Student Immigration Advisor (ISIA) for clarification about these rules. Here are some questions you might ask them: "Since I started my studies at College College before the changes to IRCC policy, am I able to change my two-year diploma program to a 1-year certificate and still be eligible for a PGWP?" "Can I combine two different 1-year certificates to be eligible for a PGWP that will be up to 3 years long?" "How will taking a whole term of online courses through the interim semester affect my eligibility for PGWP?" Students receiving OSAP funding for their program will need to check with their funding agency to confirm that their tuition can be applied towards the interim semester. Please contact the Registrar's Office for questions about tuition and fees. Continuing Education courses are not a part of the GAS Interim Semester and are subject to additional fees. Next Steps Please

Next Steps Please see your SSA [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/student-success-advising] to explore whether the interim semester is right for you, and for assistance with the process of getting registered. Retaking a Course Save Send Feedback To retake a course (when it is offered), log into the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] , go to the "My Courses" tab, and add the course you wish to retake. Alternatively, you can submit a Course Change Request Form under the "Services" tab. After your request is approved, you will need to make payment within 72 hours (about 3 days) to finalize your enrollment. Contact your Program Coordinator (contact information in the Academic Handbooks [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] ) or the Registrar's Office [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/] for additional information. Note: beginning in 2024-25, students may attempt a course twice. For a third attempt, special permission may be required. Students who fail a course three times will not be allowed to repeat it, and if it is a program requirement, will not be eligible to complete the program.

For a third attempt, special permission may be required. Students who fail a course three times will not be allowed to repeat it, and if it is a program requirement, will not be eligible to complete the program. In such cases, you may consider changing to a different program. ​Terminology: Grade Point Averages Save Send Feedback College commonly uses two types of Grade Point Averages (GPAs): Term Weighted Average (TWA): Represents your average grade for a specific term (or semester). Program Weighted Average (PWA): Reflects your cumulative average across your entire program. Definitions of these GPAs and details on how they are calculated are available on the Registrar’s Grading and Transcripts [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts] webpage. Below, you will find a general overview as well as an explanation of older terminology that is gradually being phased out. Term Weighted Average The TWA represents the average grade achieved across all courses in a specific term (commonly referred to as a “semester”). This metric is used to assess your academic standing and progression in your program at the end of each term. There are three possible outcomes based on your TWA: Promotion with Good Academic Standing:

There are three possible outcomes based on your TWA: Promotion with Good Academic Standing: Your TWA meets or exceeds the minimum average to graduate from your program. Note that this is often higher than the minimum grade required to earn a credit in a specific course. For example, the minimum grade to pass a course might be 55% but you could be required to have an average of at least 60% to graduate. Promotion on Probation: Your TWA is below the minimum average required to graduate from your program. Typically, the range is within 5%, though it is important to confirm this by reviewing the academic handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] for your school. Important: If you are on probation for two consecutive terms (excluding scheduled breaks), you will be discontinued from the program. Program Discontinuance: You may need to pause your studies for at least one term. During this time, you can explore part-time courses or other program options.

You may need to pause your studies for at least one term. During this time, you can explore part-time courses or other program options. When to Use Term Weighted Average The TWA is particularly useful at the end of one term and the start of the next, as it helps determine your academic standing and next steps. Where to Find It You can view your TWA once all final grades are posted to your record by accessing your Achievement Report through the Grades tab in your Student Portal. Program Weighted Average The PWA represents the average of all your course grades throughout your entire program. Sometimes it is also called a “Cohort Weighted Average”. It plays a critical role in determining your eligibility to graduate. Meeting the graduation requirements involves more than simply passing your courses; you must also achieve a minimum overall average: Certificates and Diplomas: Typically, a minimum PWA of 60% is required. Degree Programs: Generally, a minimum PWA of 65% is needed.

Certificates and Diplomas: Typically, a minimum PWA of 60% is required. Degree Programs: Generally, a minimum PWA of 65% is needed. Specialized Programs: Some programs may have higher requirements to comply with external accreditation standards. Progression Requirements Guides for each school are available here: College College Academic Handbooks [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook] . When to Use Program Weighted Average The PWA is particularly useful if you are struggling in one or more courses. Mid-semester, it is important to evaluate how your current grades will impact your overall average and your ability to graduate in the future. Where to Find It Your PWA can be found in the “Achievement Report” section of the Student Portal. Older Terminology To improve clarity and usability, we have updated some key terms, and you will see this reflected in College policies: "Term Weighted Average" (TWA) replaces the older "Session Weighted Average"

(TWA) replaces the older "Session Weighted Average" when referring to your average grade for a specific term (or semester). "Program Weighted Average" (PWA) is now used instead of "Cohort Weighted Average" to describe the average grade across your entire program. These updates aim to make the terminology more intuitive and reflective of their specific purposes. Leaves & Absences: International Students Save Send Feedback Short-Term Leave If the time you will be away from your studies is not more than two academic weeks (10 days), you will not need to fill out any additional forms to proceed with the break. To start the leave process, your first step is to set up a meeting with your International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/internationalstudentimmigrationadvising] (ISIA). This meeting is very important to ensure the break you want aligns with the rules of your study permit. Before you go, you must also email your program coordinator, and each of your professors to let them know the days you will be absent ahead of time. Please note that you are responsible for keeping up with your studies and assignments during this time. If you miss any assignments, tests, or exams during a short-term leave, you may not be eligible to submit your missed work.

Please note that you are responsible for keeping up with your studies and assignments during this time. If you miss any assignments, tests, or exams during a short-term leave, you may not be eligible to submit your missed work. That decision lies with your professors, who must follow college policies. Reviewing your Academic Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] for more information. Emergency Absence If you need to leave Canada due to an emergency, and it will be longer than two weeks, you should first review the refund and withdrawal policies and decide whether to withdraw from your program temporarily. You will need to submit a "Withdrawal Form" through the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] and consult with your International Student Immigration Advisor (link above) regarding the impact on your study permit and re-entry into Canada. Authorized Leave

and consult with your International Student Immigration Advisor (link above) regarding the impact on your study permit and re-entry into Canada. Authorized Leave For longer absences, International students can take an "authorized leave" from their studies for up to 150 days with the College's approval. Reasons for a leave may include medical, personal, or academic reasons. Authorization by the college is required to remain compliant with your study permit conditions. You will need to discuss your leave with program staff and your International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/internationalstudentimmigrationadvising] (ISIA) and complete a 'Return to Studies Plan.' Credit Transfer Save Send Feedback The credit transfer process begins once you have confirmed your acceptance into a College program. If you believe you have completed equivalent courses elsewhere, you can request individual credit transfers. You may also be interested in this resource information [LINK: https://stucollegecon.sharepoint.com.mcas.ms/sites/registrar/SitePages/Student-Resources.aspx] from the Registrar's Office. Here is an overview of the process: Transfers within College: Courses with matching codes and names will transfer over if you're moving to a new program within College. After enrollment, you can view the transferred courses on your Student Portal's Progress Report. Requesting Credit Transfers: Visit the

Requesting Credit Transfers: Visit the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx?_gl=1*djzb5y*_gcl_aw*R0NMLjE2OTU4MzAwNTEuQ2owS0NRandwYy1vQmhDR0FSSXNBSDZvdGU5clNHTnlGT0dSMnk2bDluNEpVeVN4NmxFTnBSWU9wZjlKcWpTMnpVNFJ1NlNHM3gzOVhBZ2FBcnFIRUFMd193Y0I.*_gcl_au*MTMzMzQ1NzY1OS4xNjkwOTA4OTQ3] > My Courses > My Credit Transfer. Follow the instructions to submit your credit transfer request. Upload course outlines for the relevant completed courses. Outlines should include course title, number/code, description, learning objectives, topics covered, textbooks, assignments, and evaluation scheme. They should correspond to the term you successfully completed the course. Note: You may find course outlines at ontransfer.ca [LINK: http://ontransfer.ca/] . Transcript Submission: Provide official transcripts from previous post-secondary institutions. Electronic transcripts are accepted if directly sent by the source institution via email to

Provide official transcripts from previous post-secondary institutions. Electronic transcripts are accepted if directly sent by the source institution via email to credittransfer@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:credittransfer@collegec.on.ca] , through MyCreds [LINK: https://mycreds.ca/] , or with your Ontario Colleges application. Physical transcripts must be in sealed envelopes from the source institution. Copies, prints, scans, or opened envelopes won't be accepted. International transcripts require assessment by ICAS or WES. Official assessment reports should be sent electronically or in sealed envelopes. Additional Information: Monitor your credit transfer request's progress on the Student Portal. Requests should ideally be submitted before the start of a term to avoid delays. Credit transfers may impact your OSAP funding or international student status. Full-time student fees are unaffected unless you switch to part-time status.

Credit transfers may impact your OSAP funding or international student status. Full-time student fees are unaffected unless you switch to part-time status. Timely requests are necessary for possible tuition refunds, subject to refund deadlines. If you have significant life/work experience, explore the Prior Learning Assessment and Recognition (PLAR) process for earning credits. To understand all the details, please review the Credit Transfer Policy [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/about/corporate-information/policies#academicadministration] . Contact and Support: If you require assistance or need guidance, please watch the " Credit Transfer Request - Instructions [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WFrwtfz2ZZw] " video. Additionally, you can reach out to the Credit Transfer Office at credittransfer@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:credittransfer@collegec.on.ca] . For submitting physical transcripts, mail them to: Attn: Credit Transfer Office College College ITAL

Attn: Credit Transfer Office College College ITAL Office of the Registrar 299 Doon Valley Drive Kitchener, ON N2G 4M4 Featured FAQ Academic Probation [LINK: /s/student-success-advising/Faqs/detail/87/academic-probation] There are two levels of probation: Probation 1 (P1) and Probation 2 (P2). Students are placed on probation if they have a Term Weighted Average between 55 - 59.99% (unless otherwise stated in the Academic School Handbook). Request a Letter: Accepted, Enrolled, Graduated Save Send Feedback Do you need a letter stating that you have been accepted, enrolled or that you have graduated? Do you need a verification of enrolment letter for your Registered Education Savings Plan (RESP)? Do you need a special or customized letter for an employer, day care or insurance company? Do you have a document that requires an official College seal or stamp? Read the information below to access the letter you need and the process and fee associated with it. Online (Free of Charge) To generate a letter free of charge, log on to the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx] and select the ‘Services’ tab then select “Print A Letter’. You will be presented with a drop down box with the four letter types: Accepted and Confirmed Letter program title, start/end date, and session start/end date. Currently Enrolled Letter

program title, start/end date, and session start/end date. Currently Enrolled Letter program title, start date, full time status, program start/end date, session start/end date Proof of Program Completion Letter program title, program start date/completion date RESP – Verification of Enrolment program title, start date, co-op program, current start date, full-time status, program length, level entering and credential type Do not submit this letter to College, it must be submitted to the institution (e.g. bank) administering your RESP. NOTE: Online standard letters above cannot be modified to include additional or different information. Important Note Regarding Canada Pension Plan Canada Pension Plan (CPP) will accept the ‘Currently Enrolled’ letter. The letter must be dated after the start of the academic year. You must: Generate the letter after the start of the academic year/semester. Write “see attached" in Section B of the Declaration of Attendance at School or University.

Generate the letter after the start of the academic year/semester. Write “see attached" in Section B of the Declaration of Attendance at School or University. The ‘Currently Enrolled Letter” replaces the signature required on the form. Submit both the form and the online letter to the government. Specialized or Custom Letter (Charges Apply) If the online letter service does not suffice, you may request a special or customized letter by completing and submitting the Completion of Letter Form with payment to the Registrar’s Office. You may request to have the letter mailed to you or pick it up in person. Please allow a minimum 24-48 hours for processing and be prepared to provide photo identification for your request. In Person or by Fax (Charges Apply) You may request a letter by completing and submitting the Completion of Letter Form with payment to the Registrar’s Office in person or send by fax to (519) 895-1097.

In Person or by Fax (Charges Apply) You may request a letter by completing and submitting the Completion of Letter Form with payment to the Registrar’s Office in person or send by fax to (519) 895-1097. Please allow a minimum 24-48 hours for processing and be prepared to provide photo identification for your request. Letter and Documentation Verification Request Form If you require a letter or form to be verified with the College stamp or seal, you must bring the document(s) to the Registrar’s Office in person for verification and for the stamp or seal to be affixed. Please allow a minimum 24-48 hours for processing and be prepared to provide photo identification for your request. Attention International Students: Select the ‘Currently Enrolled’ letter for applications related to study permit extensions, Temporary Resident Visa’s, U.S. Visas etc. Once you have downloaded the letter, please email internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca]

Once you have downloaded the letter, please email internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca] with your student number to request instructions related to Citizenship and Immigration Canada applications. Please Note: If you need a letter related to working in Canada (off-campus, co-op, on-campus) and other Citizenship and Immigration Canada applications and information, please contact internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:internationaloffice@collegec.on.ca] Featured FAQ Convocation [LINK: /s/student-success-advising/Faqs/detail/84/convocation] Note: there are steps you need to complete at least 5 weeks ahead of your convocation date in order for your graduation to be in good standing. Adding a Course Save Send Feedback Below are the steps for adding a course to your timetable. Log in to the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx] with your Student Network Login ID and password. Go to the "Browse Continuing Education" tab Type the course code or course name into the search bar and click "Search" Select the desired course from the search bar "View Availability" to ensure the course is available and open. Select the "Section" you wish to add by clicking the check box mark beside the section and clicking "add to cart." If you cannot click the box, it typically means that the section is full. Choose "Add to Cart." Find the course in your cart and click "Checkout and Enroll." Confirm the address and then select 'Save' at the bottom of the Contact Information page. Provide payment Confirm registration. Please verify that you are enrolled in the course under "My Courses" on the Student Portal.

Confirm registration. Please verify that you are enrolled in the course under "My Courses" on the Student Portal. You can check your registration status in the course list. If you cannot register for the course(s) through the "Browsing Continuing Education" tab, you must complete a Part-time Course Registration Form. The Form opens for submission on December 30, 2024. How to Use the Part-Time Day Studies Registration Form in Laserfiche: This is how you can register for courses that will be taken while your student status is part-time. You may be a part-time student on a scheduled break in your program or to make up failed or missed courses after your last scheduled level. To complete the form: Go to your Student Portal Select the 'Services' tab Select the second 'My Forms' tab (for part-time students) Select the 'Part-time Studies Course Registration Form' Complete the form in full and submit Download your confirmation or email it to yourself for your records

Complete the form in full and submit Download your confirmation or email it to yourself for your records Once complete, the request will be sent to your Program Coordinator for approval How to Pay for Your Part-Time Day Studies Course: Once your form is approved and you are enrolled in the course, you will receive an email notification requesting payment. To make the payment: Log onto your Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx?ReturnUrl=%2fStudentPortal%2f] Select ‘Financial Tab’ Select the ‘Payment for Held Courses’ sub-tab (right below the 'My Courses' tab) Complete payment IMPORTANT: Course enrolment will be canceled after 72 hours if payment is not received. Submit your form early to secure a spot on your desired course, as availability is limited. Be patient and watch your College email address for updates. Payment is expected within 72 hours (about 3 days) to finalize your registration, or you will lose your seat in the course. Student Rights & Responsibilities FAQs Save Send Feedback Who do I contact if I have an emergency or safety concern? If you feel unsafe or need immediate attention on-campus, contact Safety and Security [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/safety-and-security/contact] . If you are off campus, contact emergency services by calling 911. If you are in crisis and need urgent mental health support, the following resources can help: Suicide Crisis Helpline (all of Canada): 988 HERE 24/7 (Kitchener, Waterloo, Cambridge, Guelph):1-844-437-3247 Good 2 Talk (Post-secondary student helpline): 1-866-925-5454 or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868 Crisis Support Peel (Mississauga, Brampton, Peel areas): 1-888-811-2222 Who can report a Student Rights and Responsibilities Violation? College students, employees, faculty, and members of the public may submit reports or reach out to our email. Can I make a report anonymously? Yes, we accept anonymous reports. Note that this can limit our responses available.

Yes, we accept anonymous reports. Note that this can limit our responses available. If we do not know who you are, we will be unable to follow-up with any updates or next steps on our process. To submit an anonymous report, complete the report form leaving the reporter name and contact information blank. If you would like some follow-up, you can provide an anonymous email address for us to contact. In some cases, we can keep reporters anonymous to other parties involved. If at any point in our process you choose to be anonymous after contacting our office, let us know. We will provide guidance on what that will look like moving forward. What are my options when making a report? The options we will provide you will depend on what the report or concerns are about. We will provide you with the most appropriate information and policies related to your concerns. In some cases, we may connect you with other departments better suited to support you. How do I schedule a meeting with you?

In some cases, we may connect you with other departments better suited to support you. How do I schedule a meeting with you? We ask that you first reach out to us via email or the report form with additional information on your concerns. This helps us better determine if we are the most appropriate resource for your inquiry. If we can provide further support, we will then share arrange a meeting with a member of our team via email. I’ve received an email from SRR about an incident, what happens next? Follow the instructions outlined in the emails from our office; there may be action items for you to follow. We recommend that you address it as soon as possible. Respond to the email with any questions or concerns you may have. If you received an email with a request to meet, its because we want to hear from you to gather your perspective. A meeting with our office is your opportunity to share your side of events and work on finding a resolution. How do I prepare for a meeting?

A meeting with our office is your opportunity to share your side of events and work on finding a resolution. How do I prepare for a meeting? We understand that connecting with our office can be overwhelming. Here’s some tips to help you feel ready: Review our policies and procedures so you know what to expect. Collect any important documentation like emails, text messages, screen captures, etc. You can send these to us before the meeting or bring them with you. If applicable, write down the names and contact information of any witnesses or other people involved. Make a timeline of events pr notes to help you remember details during the meeting. Consider if you want to bring a support person such as a family member, peer, or advisor. They can take notes and help be there as a moral support. Prepare any questions you have about the policies, procedures, outcome, etc. How do I challenge a decision made by SRR? The challenge process is outlined on page 6 of the

How do I challenge a decision made by SRR? The challenge process is outlined on page 6 of the Student Rights and Responsibilities Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-rights-and-responsibilities-procedure.pdf] If you want to challenge a decision that does not affect your academic status, email srr@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:srr@collegec.on.ca] and outline your grounds for appeal. The Director of Student Rights and Responsibilities will review it. Appropriate grounds for submitting a challenge are personal bias, unfair treatment or new information. Attach any documents any supporting documentation. If the decision does affect your academic status, submit a formal appeal form as outlined in Step 4 of the Academic Dispute and Appeal Resolution Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] (pdf).

Academic Dispute and Appeal Resolution Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] (pdf). You can find the form on the student portal under the Services tab, then click "Forms" in the Students in Full-time Programs section. Complete the Student Appeals Form on Laserfiche. Are my conversations with the SRRO confidential? Your conversations with the SRRO are private unless we believe you or someone else is at risk of harm. We won't act on your concerns without your permission unless there's an immediate risk. If we contact you because of a report, we may share some information with involved parties. All records are kept secure according to privacy laws. Exceptions [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/document/freedom-information-and-protection-privacy-manual/chapter-5-exemptions-and-exclusions] are records under statutes that expressly state that they prevail over FIPPA.

Exceptions [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/document/freedom-information-and-protection-privacy-manual/chapter-5-exemptions-and-exclusions] are records under statutes that expressly state that they prevail over FIPPA. Will SRR violations be visible on my permanent academic record? SRRO decisions and sanctions do not form part of a student's academic record except in cases of long-term suspension or discontinuance from the college. How long does it take to resolve an issue? We typically respond within 2 business days. Time to resolve an issue will depend on the concern, but we will try to move as quickly as possible and will keep you updated on timelines. Before Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      should arrive 15-minutes before their test start time to secure personal      items and complete check-in. Testing      appointments may be cancelled if students arrive more than 20-minutes late      from the indicated start time. Present      a non-expired physical photo ID (OneCard or government-issued      ID). Only      items required for the assessment will be permitted in the testing      room. All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre.

All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre. To      maintain a quiet and controlled testing environment for all test takers,      children are not permitted within the Test Centre and cannot be left      unattended while any student is writing. All      computer-based tests at the Test Centre will be conducted on assigned      desktop computers. Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test.

Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test. Please      note the Test Centres may not have power outlets for laptops. To      ensure a comfortable and healthy environment for everyone, Test Centres      are a designated scent-free zone. We kindly request that all individuals      refrain from wearing or using scented products. Only      water is permitted in the testing room (approved accommodations      excepted). Featured Info Page Before Your Assessment [LINK: /s/testing-services/InfoPages/detail/42/before-your-assessment] Tips of what to do before writing in the Test Centre × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

After Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Test      Centre staff will submit all completed papers to your faculty. Any      concerns regarding the outcome of an assessment should be discussed with      the student’s faculty. If      applicable, return the locker key to the designated area after gathering your      belongings. Featured Info Page Before Your Assessment [LINK: /s/testing-services/InfoPages/detail/42/before-your-assessment] Tips of what to do before writing in the Test Centre × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

During Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      are expected to follow direction of Test Centre staff. Students      can only communicate with Testing Centre staff. Staff cannot give any      guidance or answer questions regarding test/exam content. Faculty      will not be present in the Test Centre; however, students can request that      Test Centre staff to attempt to contact their faculty for clarifying      questions. Students      can request the use of blank scrap paper from Test Centre staff. All      testing materials must be returned to Test Centre staff at the end of the      test. It      is recommended that students use the washroom before their assessment. Washroom breaks during assessments will only be permitted if a Test Centre      staff member is available (approved accommodations excepted). In      case of emergency (fire alarm, lockdown), students are to follow the      instructions of the Test Centre staff.

Washroom breaks during assessments will only be permitted if a Test Centre      staff member is available (approved accommodations excepted). In      case of emergency (fire alarm, lockdown), students are to follow the      instructions of the Test Centre staff. The      Test Centre staff will adhere to the guidelines established by the Academic      Integrity [LINK: https://library.collegec.on.ca/academic-integrity] department in the event of an academic integrity      breach. Mental Health Support: Non-Emergency (College Specific) Save Send Feedback Counselling Services [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/counselling] : Confidential, one-to-one appointments with counsellors are available to help students work through issues affecting their mental health. There is no cost to meet with a counsellor, and appointments can be in-person, virtual, or by telephone at all campuses. Dialogue Virtual Care [LINK: https://studentcare.ca/rte/en/IHaveAPlan_CSI_Dialogue_Dialogue] : This service is provided by the student health benefits plan and offers virtual care options for your mental health needs. The CARE Team [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/careteam] : The College College CARE Team helps ensure that the students most in need of elevated support levels are identified early. As a member of the College community, you can share concerns for students by using the referral form below. Please submit a report when you:

As a member of the College community, you can share concerns for students by using the referral form below. Please submit a report when you: Have a concern about a student’s wellbeing You believe a student could benefit from elevated support from the College You have become aware of threatening, concerning or distressing student behavior. Submit a CARE Team Referral [LINK: https://collegec-advocate.symplicity.com/care_report/index.php/] In life-threatening situations or emergencies, call 911 or Campus Security ( 519-748-5220, ext. 3357) for help. Emergency Room Information Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /s/medicalclinic/experiences/add/from/infopage/3400236] You should only go to an emergency room if you have a life-threatening medical emergency. There may be longer wait times, especially if your concern is not a life-threatening medical emergency. When you go to an emergency department, you need to bring your College International Health Insurance Plan card (for international students) or your OHIP card (for Ontario residents). If you live in Waterloo, Kitchener, Cambridge or Guelph, here is a list of the local emergency departments. 1. Grand River Hospital Emergency Room [LINK: https://www.grhosp.on.ca/care/services-departments/emergency/current-emergency-wait] 835 King St. W Kitchener, ON 2. St. Mary’s General Hospital: Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.smgh.ca/patients-visitors/emergency-department-wait-times] 911 Queen’s Blvd Kitchener, ON 3.

Kitchener, ON 3. Cambridge Memorial Hospital: Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.cmh.org/programs/department-emergency-medicine] 700 Coronation Blvd Cambridge, ON 4. Guelph General Hospital Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.gghorg.ca/emergency-department/] 115 Delhi St Guelph, ON 5. Halton Healthcare [LINK: https://www.haltonhealthcare.on.ca/services_/28763/t28425-emergency-department] Emergency care is available at all three hospitals located in Oakville, Milton and Georgetown If you live outside of these cities, you can find your nearest emergency department by searching “emergency department near me” on your preferred internet browser. Walk-in Clinics Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /s/medicalclinic/experiences/add/from/infopage/3461120] Walk-in clinics and urgent care centers provide medical care for people who do not have a primary care health provider, or have one but are unable to reach them. You can see a nurse or doctor without an appointment for minor illness and injuries, but often there is a line or longer wait times. When you go to a walk-in clinic or urgent care center, you need to bring your College International Health Insurance Plan card (for international students) or your OHIP card (for Ontario residents). If you live in Waterloo or Kitchener, here is a list of walk-in clinics that you can visit: 1. Benton Medical Centre [LINK: http://www.bentonmedicalclinic.com] 51 Benton St, Kitchener 226-240-3014 2. KW Healthy Living Family Practice [LINK: http://www.kwmedicalcentre.com] 1360 Weber St E, Kitchener 519-893-6060 3. KW Urgent Care Clinics [LINK: http://www.kwurgentcare.ca/]

Kitchener Walk-In Clinic [LINK: https://www.kitchenerwalkin.ca/] 5 Manitou Drive, Kitchener 519-904-4200 6. Laurentian Walk-in Clinic [LINK: https://www.wwhealthline.ca/displayservice.aspx?id=101690] 750 Ottawa St S, Kitchener (Zehrs) 519-570-3174 7. Onyx Urgent Care [LINK: https://onyxurgentcare.com/] 580 Lancaster St W, Kitchener 519-896-6699 8. Review my preferences [LINK: /s/student-engagement/Settings] Description This workshop provides participants with a foundational knowledge of what sexual violence is and discusses what effective bystander intervention looks like. There will be an opportunity to explore how you can intervene, and what the effects are of different intervention tactics. This workshop is part of the College Consent Culture series and will be presented by the Sexual Assault Support Centre of Waterloo Region [LINK: https://www.sascwr.org/] (SASC). Past workshop participants have said: "I truly enjoyed this workshop, and especially loved working through the scenarios at the end in order to apply the information in a practical manner” “This workshop was very helpful in terms of understanding the best strategies”. This workshop is eligible for CCR recognition. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/16] Endorsements CCR ENDORSED Co-Curricular Record Other information Email:

Bell Let's Talk Day 2025 Save Send Feedback Your mental health matters! On Wednesday, January 22nd join Student Success to break down the stigma related to mental health as part of Bell Let's Talk Day [LINK: https://letstalk.bell.ca/] . At each campus there will be a resource table as well as an opportunity for you to share your ideas on how you take care of yourself or share an uplifting message on the Talk Bubbles. Bell Let's Talk Events at College Campus Time Location Brantford Campus 10am - 2pm Student Lounge/Cafeteria Cambridge Campus 10am - 2pm Atrium Doon Campus 10am - 2pm 12pm - 1pm Therapy Dogs E-Wing Hallway Downtown Kitchener Campus 10am - 12pm Welcome Desk Area Guelph Campus 10am - 2pm Cafeteria Milton Campus 10am - 2pm Parkhill Lobby Reuter Campus 10am - 2pm Main Entrance Waterloo Campus 10am - 2pm Welcome Desk Area College College Resources Counselling Services [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/counselling]

College College Resources Counselling Services [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/counselling] Free, confidential services for students to meet with a professional Counsellor to address social, emotional and/or academic conerns. Call 519-748-5220 ext. 3679 or email counselling@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:counselling@collegec.on.ca] to make an appointment. Medical Clinic [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/medicalclinic] Offers a variety of health and wellness services to support your well-being. Call 519-748-5220 ext. 3679 or email medicalclinic@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:medicalclinic@collegec.on.ca] to book an appointment. CARE Team [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/careteam] Provide students with an elevated level of support. Any member of the College community can make a referral by completing a Public CARE Referral Form. [LINK: https://collegec-advocate.symplicity.com/care_report/index.php/pid634929?]

Public CARE Referral Form. Call or text 9-8-8. Good2Talk [LINK: https://good2talk.ca/] Provide free, confidential support services 24/7 for Ontario post-secondary students. Call 1-866-925-5454 or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868. CMHA Waterloo Wellington [LINK: https://cmhaww.ca/] Provide a full care system for those with mental health, substance-use, or developmental needs. COAST Crisis Line [LINK: https://halton.cmha.ca/our-programs-and-services/#crisis-services] 24/7 crisis line to support individuals requiring crisis support. Call 1-877-825-9011. Description Learning the content of a class is one thing – showing that knowledge on a test is another. Studying efficiently and taking tests effectively are two mega skill sets that all successful students need to master. In this session we will look at how to make a study plan, how to handle different kinds of tests, and ways to remember more and get it down on the page when it matters. This workshop is eligible for CCR recognition. Review my preferences [LINK: /s/student-engagement/Settings] Description A free festival where light, art, and tech meet happening on Saturday, September 20, 2025 from 6 p.m. to 11 p.m. in uptown Waterloo. Find more information on the Lumen website [LINK: https://www.lumenfestival.ca/] , launching early September 2025. Lumen is an annual, free, all-ages festival that is open to the public and run by the City of Waterloo’s Arts and Creative Industries team (Create Waterloo). The event features the work of artists as they explore the interplay of light, art, and technology in installations located throughout uptown Waterloo. The event hosts 30+ visual, interactive, new media, and performance-based installations.

uptown Waterloo. The event hosts 30+ visual, interactive, new media, and performance-based installations. Description The Community of Health Care Research, facilitated by the Centre for Health Care Research & Innovation [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fresearch.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fcentre-for-health-care-research-and-innovation%3F%3FMcasTsid%3D20893&McasCSRF=887c92582d448243e9ea20c5e0372c52b0266ab73ba7eb418cabc140c5eefb2a] , aims to explore and discuss topics and questions about research in health care. The final Community meeting for the Spring term will be held from 1:00-2:00pm on Wednesday, August 6 . All are welcome to join (faculty, staff, students) and all levels of experience with research are welcome! Students who attend and participate in at least two Community meetings in a term are eligible to receive Co-Curricular Record (CCR) recognition. Victorian Order of Nurses (VON) Volunteer Every day, VON volunteers help make Canadian communities healthier. If you want to give back to your community by sharing your time and caring for others, we have a role for you. Volunteer Opportunities VON Brantford Site: 446 Grey St. Suite 204, Brantford, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Make a lasting difference in your community- Volunteer with VON  today! Every day, VON volunteers help make Canadian communities healthier. If you want to give back to your community by sharing your time and caring for others, we have a role for you. When you become a VON Volunteer we will match your interests and availability to a volunteer role that’s right for you. We offer the training you need and ensure you are supported through frequent communication – support is always a call away. VOLUNTEER VISITOR

We offer the training you need and ensure you are supported through frequent communication – support is always a call away. VOLUNTEER VISITOR Offers support and social interaction to an isolated individual through regular friendly visits at the client’s home or out in the community, encouraging active and independent living. Visits are usually 1 time a week and anywhere from 1-3 hours long. Requirements: 1.Complete application 2.Interview 3.Vulnerable Sector Check (VON reimburses you if there is a fee) 4.Provide two references HOSPICE VISITOR Make a lasting difference in your community- Volunteer with VON  today! Every day, VON volunteers help make Canadian communities healthier. If you want to give back to your community by sharing your time and caring for others, we have a role for you. When you become a VON Volunteer we will match your interests and availability to a volunteer role that’s right for you.

If you want to give back to your community by sharing your time and caring for others, we have a role for you. When you become a VON Volunteer we will match your interests and availability to a volunteer role that’s right for you. We offer the training you need and ensure you are supported through frequent communication – support is always a call away. A Hospice Volunteer will provide emotional support, practical assistance within the bounds of the role as a volunteer and respite help as clients and caregivers face a life-threatening illness, death and bereavement. Hospice Volunteers will provide this support at the client’s home or out in the community. Visits are usually 1 time a week and anywhere from 1-3 hours long. Requirements: 1.Complete application 2.Interview 3.Vulnerable Sector Check (VON reimburses you if there is a fee) 4.Provide two references 5.Must complete the “Fundamentals of Palliative Hospice Care Education” training course (VON registers for you and covers the fee)

Volunteer with the Alzheimer Society The Alzheimer Society offers a multitude of roles to support persons living with dementia and their care partners. Volunteer Opportunities Alzheimer Society, Various Cities, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details The Alzheimer Society offers a multitude of roles to support persons living with dementia and their care partners. Overview of role: The Milton Community is looking to connect volunteers with Persons Living with Dementia. Volunteers are matched with clients and attend social visits within the clients’ home or retirement home. We also offer opportunities for volunteers in an administrative capacity, for events, for programs like Teleconnect, Public Education, and more. Once the Volunteer Coordinator in your region receives your application, they will reach out to schedule a virtual interview. Interviews are 30 minutes long.

interview. Interviews are 30 minutes long. We will then provide a reference form, and volunteers should have two references fill this form out. Once we receive your references, you will be invited to attend a Volunteer Orientation. Finally, upon completion of the Orientation, you will begin your training (i.e., Dementia education, role specific training, etc.) At this stage, we will also match you with your volunteer position. Contact: For any Halton volunteers (Milton, Georgetown, Burlington, and Oakville) applicants can reach out to Sabanta Noor at 289-837-2310 ext. 320. Reading Rocks: A one on one tutoring program to help youth who need literacy support. The LDAWC is looking for enthusiastic, committed, motivated people who would like to be positive role models. You must also have excellent oral and written English language skills, as Reading Rocks is a reading/literacy program. Volunteer with Scouts Canada (Cambridge) Volunteering with ​Scouts Canada is fun, flexible and fulfilling Volunteer Opportunities Scouts Canada, Cambridge, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Volunteer Role Overview Volunteering with Scouts Canada [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VqvIkK96XbY] is fun, flexible and fulfilling. You will be supported by a team of dynamic volunteers who get as much fun out of Scouting adventures as the youth they support. We provide the training and adventure. You provide the enthusiasm. There are multiple ways in which you can contribute as a volunteer, whether you would prefer a more administrative role, to share a specific skill you have or to support youth more directly. The commitment in time may also vary depending on your schedule and your role. The Perks Of Volunteering Develop valuable skills that help you achieve personal and professional goals while challenging yourself.

The Perks Of Volunteering Develop valuable skills that help you achieve personal and professional goals while challenging yourself. Complete thorough online and experiential learning in understanding youth, program planning, leadership and safety training. Allow more young people to experience all the benefits that Scouting has to offer. Scouts Canada Background Our Mission [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JEgw7A-RqAo&t=4s] : To help develop well-rounded youth, better prepared for success in the world. Scouts Canada is the country’s leading co-ed youth organization, offering programming for children and youth aged 5-26. With over 50,000 youth participating across the country, in multiple languages and reflecting Canada’s multicultural landscape, kids and youth in Scouts chart their own path of discovery. Through a variety of fun experiences, outdoor adventures and contributions to their community, Scouts builds resilience and skills that set them up for life.

With over 50,000 youth participating across the country, in multiple languages and reflecting Canada’s multicultural landscape, kids and youth in Scouts chart their own path of discovery. Through a variety of fun experiences, outdoor adventures and contributions to their community, Scouts builds resilience and skills that set them up for life. Youth in Scouts are supported by a dedicated team of over 12,000 volunteers who collectively donate over two million hours of their time, providing youth with the opportunity to grow, to challenge themselves and to experience countless firsts. Our volunteers help us bring our vision of youth making meaningful contributions to creating a better world to life by lifting people, communities and neighbourhoods. Scouts Canada is part of the World Organization of the Scout Movement (WOSM) which has over 40 million members in 167 National Scout Organizations around the world. Overview of the Application Process

Scouts Canada is part of the World Organization of the Scout Movement (WOSM) which has over 40 million members in 167 National Scout Organizations around the world. Overview of the Application Process Youth safety is at the core of everything we do. As Canada’s largest youth organization, Scouts Canada places great importance on creating a fun and safe environment for all our members, especially children and youth. We truly believe we have a responsibility to help make Canada safer for our children and youth. This is why adults appointed to positions of authority over youth undergo a vetting process which includes; an application form, interview, police record checks (including vulnerable sector searches), references and youth protection training with Respect in Sport.

We truly believe we have a responsibility to help make Canada safer for our children and youth. This is why adults appointed to positions of authority over youth undergo a vetting process which includes; an application form, interview, police record checks (including vulnerable sector searches), references and youth protection training with Respect in Sport. This process is designed to ensure that Scouters are suitable to occupy a position of trust, and to support this we have a detailed code of conduct as well as our Two Scouter rule which requires for two registered Scouters to be with youth at all times. How to get involved How to get involved To Volunteer or With Questions Contact local (Cambridge) Scouter James Miniotas at james.miniotas@scouts.ca [LINK: mailto:james.miniotas@scouts.ca] or by phone 226-581-1474. Volunteer with Grand River Community Health Centre Community based primary health care and offers a range of services to support the emotional, physical and social needs of individuals and communities Volunteer Opportunities Grand River Community Health Centre, Brantford, Ontario, Canada Save activity Details Grand River Community Health Centre provides community based primary health care and offers a range of services to support the emotional, physical and social needs of individuals and communities. The Centre opens channels between the health sector and the broader community. GRCHC creates opportunities to work together to achieve equity, a sense of belonging, health and wellbeing for all. Grand River Community Health Centre is proud to serve Brantford and the County of Brant since the beginning vision in 2005! Vision A community where we work together to achieve equity, belonging, health and wellbeing for all. Mission

A community where we work together to achieve equity, belonging, health and wellbeing for all. Mission We promote healthy communities by providing primary health care, health promotion and community development, to ensure that no one faces barriers to health and well-being. Values Inclusive - We champion inclusivity through acceptance, welcoming of diversity and fostering a sense of belonging. Collaborative - We work as a team with our clients and partners to provide coordinated care for our community. Accessible - We strive to address the wide range of barriers to accessing services, which clients may face. Respectful - We are inclusive, non-judgmental, compassionate and caring. Equitable - We strive to ensure that people in our community are treated fairly. Opportunities Greeter-Refreshment volunteer positions This opportunity will provide helpful, supportive and friendly assistance to the visitors and clients at Grand River Community Health Centre (GRCHC). Responsibilities Include:

This opportunity will provide helpful, supportive and friendly assistance to the visitors and clients at Grand River Community Health Centre (GRCHC). Responsibilities Include: Stock refreshment cart with the supplies provided      and set up front screening desk Greet and welcome visitors and clients in a      friendly manner Screen all clients and ensure infection prevention      and control procedures are being followed Direct visitors and clients as needed Meet visitors at front door and bring refreshments      (soup/baked goods/oatmeal/hot beverage) or snack bag Collect visitor/contractor information and track      refreshments distributed Provide information on local resources (aka food      bank) and provide conversation if time permits Escort visitors if requested to the needed services      within the health centre Clean up area around cart and return to the kitchen Stock the cart for the next day Administrative Volunteer

Stock the cart for the next day Administrative Volunteer This opportunity will give the chance to enhance your administrative skills and allow you to expand your knowledge while helping complete essential office tasks. Responsibilities: The Administrative Support Volunteer will: Scan documents File documents Complete data entry Make client phone calls Other project based opportunities as required Gender Journey Brant Peer Facilitators The successful candidate will facilitate the Gender Journey Brant peer support group. The role of the peer facilitator is to provide peer support to Trans and gender non-confirming identified adults in the Brantford, Brant area. This position is an opportunity to become more engaged in and support the Trans, and gender non-conforming community in Brantford/Brant. Responsibilities Include: The Gender Journey Brant Peer Facilitator will: Organize      bi-monthly peer support groups Ensure      the group norms are adhered to at all times

Organize      bi-monthly peer support groups Ensure      the group norms are adhered to at all times Provide      peer support to members of the trans community of Brantford/Brant Attend      volunteer orientation and role specific training Opportunity      for other duties 2SLGBTQ+ Community Connections Peer Facilitators The successful candidate will facilitate the 2SLGBTQ+ Community Connections Group. The role of the peer facilitator is to provide leadership and support to the 2SLGBTQ+ community in the Brantford, Brant area. This position is an opportunity to become more engaged in and support the 2SLGBTQ+ community in Brantford/Brant. Description This workshop provides participants with a foundational knowledge of what sexual violence is and discusses what effective bystander intervention looks like. There will be an opportunity to explore how you can intervene, and what the effects are of different intervention tactics. This workshop is part of the College Consent Culture series and will be presented by the Sexual Assault Support Centre of Waterloo Region [LINK: https://www.sascwr.org/] (SASC). Past workshop participants have said: "I truly enjoyed this workshop, and especially loved working through the scenarios at the end in order to apply the information in a practical manner” “This workshop was very helpful in terms of understanding the best strategies”. This workshop is eligible for CCR recognition. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/16] Endorsements CCR ENDORSED Co-Curricular Record Other information Email:

 Canada Industry 1 [LINK: /students/organisations/search?industry=5202] College College [LINK: https://linkedin.com/company/College College] About International Transition Coordinators (ITCs) provide specialized service to international students to support their smooth transition to Canada and College College. We engage students at the pre-arrival stage and continue to provide guidance throughout their College journey. We offer important resources and information, relevant referrals, comprehensive webinar programming, student-focused campus outreach booths, and individualized one-on-one advising. Our extensive service includes supporting students with settlement and acculturation, including early college onboarding, travel to Canada, housing, accessing college and community resources, and more!

Description The Community of Health Care Research, facilitated by the Centre for Health Care Research & Innovation [LINK: https://mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms/certificate-checker?login=false&originalUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fresearch.collegec.on.ca.mcas.ms%2Fcentre-for-health-care-research-and-innovation%3F%3FMcasTsid%3D20893&McasCSRF=887c92582d448243e9ea20c5e0372c52b0266ab73ba7eb418cabc140c5eefb2a] , aims to explore and discuss topics and questions about research in health care. The final Community meeting for the Spring term will be held from 1:00-2:00pm on Wednesday, August 6 . All are welcome to join (faculty, staff, students) and all levels of experience with research are welcome! Students who attend and participate in at least two Community meetings in a term are eligible to receive Co-Curricular Record (CCR) recognition. Review my preferences [LINK: /students/Settings] Description Ready to turn your food business idea into reality?

Description Ready to turn your food business idea into reality? Join us for an inspiring and practical session tailored for aspiring culinary and food entrepreneurs. Whether you’re dreaming of starting a bakery, food truck, catering service, or packaged goods brand, this event will walk you through the first steps—especially how to fund your venture. You’ll hear from successful entrepreneur Lenore Johnson , owner of LenJo Bakes , as she shares how she started her business, the funding options she explored, and what she learned along the way. We’ll also cover a range of funding pathways—from grants and loans to alternative models—so you can find the right fit for your idea. Whether you’re still shaping your concept or ready to get started, this session will give you the tools and confidence to move forward. Discover what’s possible—and how to pay for it. Review my preferences [LINK: /students/Settings] Description Snack & Chats allow students to come together to practice their social skills in a group setting while also providing the opportunity to practice English speaking and listening skills. Students in attendance are from a variety of programs, countries and cultures. Room number: 2E33 Snacks will only be given to Snack and Chat participants while supplies last. Note: Snack and Chat has the capacity to welcome approximately 20 students each week (first to arrive). Students who participate in four or more sessions are eligible to receive CCR recognition. Review my preferences [LINK: /s/student-engagement/Settings] Description This workshop provides participants with a foundational knowledge of what sexual violence is and discusses what effective bystander intervention looks like. There will be an opportunity to explore how you can intervene, and what the effects are of different intervention tactics. This workshop is part of the College Consent Culture series and will be presented by the Sexual Assault Support Centre of Waterloo Region [LINK: https://www.sascwr.org/] (SASC). Past workshop participants have said: "I truly enjoyed this workshop, and especially loved working through the scenarios at the end in order to apply the information in a practical manner” “This workshop was very helpful in terms of understanding the best strategies”. This workshop is eligible for CCR recognition. [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/students/infopages/detail/16] Endorsements CCR ENDORSED Co-Curricular Record Other information Email:
