Appealing a Course Grade Save Send Feedback Course grade appeals should be based on procedural errors, technical issues, or medical/compassionate grounds, not on dissatisfaction with the grade itself. For more details, review the Academic Dispute Resolution and Appeal Procedure under "Academic Administration" on the policies webpage [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/about/corporate-information/policies] . To appeal a course grade, you must email the faculty with the subject labeled ‘Course Appeal.’ In the email, you must describe the issues, including copies of emails, proof of work completed, and any other pertinent details. You must wait five business days for the faculty to respond to your email. If the faculty does not change their decision or respond, complete these steps in the Academic Appeal Request found on the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] under ‘My Services’ > ‘My Forms’. The

under ‘My Services’ > ‘My Forms’. The CSI also provides assistance [LINK: https://www.collegestudents.com/representation/academicappeals/] to students who are seeking an academic appeal. Course Grade Appeal Procedure Does your concern meet the scope and criteria for an appeal? Consult the Academic Dispute Resolution and Appeal Procedure (see the policies link above). If your concern does not meet the scope or criteria identified in the procedure, you cannot submit an appeal. Step 1: Faculty Contact your professor or program coordinator to discuss your issue. If your concerns are not addressed or resolved within 5 days, move to step 2. *Please note, the deadline to begin Step 1 is within five working days of receipt of the grade or academic decision. Step 2: Submit Appeal Form (Appeal to Chair) Submit an appeal form and attach supporting documentation from Step 1. Your Chair will review the appeal request and make a decision within 5 working days.

Submit an appeal form and attach supporting documentation from Step 1. Your Chair will review the appeal request and make a decision within 5 working days. To submit an appeal form, sign onto the Student Portal, select the ‘Service’ tab, click the ‘My Forms’ button. Step 3: Continue Appeal Form (Appeal to Dean) The appeal form will provide the option to continue to Step 3 if your Step 2 appeal is denied. Your Dean will review the appeal request and make a decision within 5 working days. Step 4: Continue Appeal Form (Appeal to Registrar) The appeal form will provide the option to continue to Step 4 if your Step 3 appeal is denied. The Registrar will review the appeal request and make a decision within 10 working days. Changing Programs Save Send Feedback You must first identify a new program that is 'open’ to students by reviewing the list on the Open Programs [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/fulltime/open-programs] webpage. If you need help deciding which program is the best match for your career goal, you can book an appointment with a Career Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/career] or email careerservices@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:CareerServices@collegec.on.ca] . Once you have confirmed the new program you would like to apply to, you must withdraw from your current program. You can find the Withdrawal Form on the student portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] click: SERVICES > MY FORMS > WITHDRAWAL FORM. Please be aware that you may choose to withdraw from your studies immediately or you may select the option to withdraw at the end of the current term. International Students

Please be aware that you may choose to withdraw from your studies immediately or you may select the option to withdraw at the end of the current term. International Students For international students, once you withdraw, you may not be eligible to work until you receive a new offer letter. International students are strongly encouraged to discuss any program changes with their International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/international/immigration-information/book-an-appointment] (ISIA) first . To apply to a new program, you will use the OCAS application portal and follow the steps you followed when you initially applied to college. You can have your original account re-opened by emailing the International Admissions team at internationaladmissions@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:internationaladmissions@collegec.on.ca] . After a successful acceptance into the new program, any balance in your student account will be applied to your new program.

. After a successful acceptance into the new program, any balance in your student account will be applied to your new program. Already Completed Courses If you wish to change your program after completing some courses, you must first withdraw from your current program (see above) and apply to the new one through an Advanced Standing Application Form (see the Registrar [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/student-forms] for more information). A $35 processing fee is charged during the submission. Ensure all required information is accurately completed to avoid delays. If you are an international student, consult your ISIA to understand how the change may affect your study permit. Academic Probation Save Send Feedback There are two levels of probation: Probation 1 (P1) and Probation 2 (P2). Students are placed on probation if they have a Term Weighted Average between 55 - 59.99% (unless otherwise stated in the Academic School Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/index] ). Students on P1 are encouraged (not required) to meet with an SSA or their Program Coordinator to develop a learning plan. A learning plan is a document designed to support your academic achievement. Students who have a term weighted average in the same range for a second consecutive term will be placed on P2. Note: a scheduled break is ignored when determining consecutive semesters. When on P2, students are required to connect with an SSA or their program coordinator to develop a learning contract. This is a formal agreement that outlines the requirement for academic achievement.

When on P2, students are required to connect with an SSA or their program coordinator to develop a learning contract. This is a formal agreement that outlines the requirement for academic achievement. If a student's term weighted average remains in the same range after being on P2, they will be discontinued from their program. Important Notes Term Weighted Average is calculated using the grades for each course and adjusted for the number of credits associated with the course in which it was received. If a student is registered through part-time studies their course performance will be reflected in their cumulative weighted average. There is no term weighted average calculation for part-time studies unless they are registered in a program cohort. All students can attempt a course 2 times. For any subsequent attempts, the student must get approval from an academic administrator in the program in which they are registered.

All students can attempt a course 2 times. For any subsequent attempts, the student must get approval from an academic administrator in the program in which they are registered. Failed courses before September 1, 2024 will not be counted towards the maximum number of attempts. ​Terminology: Grade Point Averages Save Send Feedback College commonly uses two types of Grade Point Averages (GPAs): Term Weighted Average (TWA): Represents your average grade for a specific term (or semester). Program Weighted Average (PWA): Reflects your cumulative average across your entire program. Definitions of these GPAs and details on how they are calculated are available on the Registrar’s Grading and Transcripts [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/admissions/registrar-office/grading-transcripts] webpage. Below, you will find a general overview as well as an explanation of older terminology that is gradually being phased out. Term Weighted Average The TWA represents the average grade achieved across all courses in a specific term (commonly referred to as a “semester”). This metric is used to assess your academic standing and progression in your program at the end of each term. There are three possible outcomes based on your TWA: Promotion with Good Academic Standing:

There are three possible outcomes based on your TWA: Promotion with Good Academic Standing: Your TWA meets or exceeds the minimum average to graduate from your program. Note that this is often higher than the minimum grade required to earn a credit in a specific course. For example, the minimum grade to pass a course might be 55% but you could be required to have an average of at least 60% to graduate. Promotion on Probation: Your TWA is below the minimum average required to graduate from your program. Typically, the range is within 5%, though it is important to confirm this by reviewing the academic handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] for your school. Important: If you are on probation for two consecutive terms (excluding scheduled breaks), you will be discontinued from the program. Program Discontinuance: You may need to pause your studies for at least one term. During this time, you can explore part-time courses or other program options.

You may need to pause your studies for at least one term. During this time, you can explore part-time courses or other program options. When to Use Term Weighted Average The TWA is particularly useful at the end of one term and the start of the next, as it helps determine your academic standing and next steps. Where to Find It You can view your TWA once all final grades are posted to your record by accessing your Achievement Report through the Grades tab in your Student Portal. Program Weighted Average The PWA represents the average of all your course grades throughout your entire program. Sometimes it is also called a “Cohort Weighted Average”. It plays a critical role in determining your eligibility to graduate. Meeting the graduation requirements involves more than simply passing your courses; you must also achieve a minimum overall average: Certificates and Diplomas: Typically, a minimum PWA of 60% is required. Degree Programs: Generally, a minimum PWA of 65% is needed.

Certificates and Diplomas: Typically, a minimum PWA of 60% is required. Degree Programs: Generally, a minimum PWA of 65% is needed. Specialized Programs: Some programs may have higher requirements to comply with external accreditation standards. Progression Requirements Guides for each school are available here: College College Academic Handbooks [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook] . When to Use Program Weighted Average The PWA is particularly useful if you are struggling in one or more courses. Mid-semester, it is important to evaluate how your current grades will impact your overall average and your ability to graduate in the future. Where to Find It Your PWA can be found in the “Achievement Report” section of the Student Portal. Older Terminology To improve clarity and usability, we have updated some key terms, and you will see this reflected in College policies: "Term Weighted Average" (TWA) replaces the older "Session Weighted Average"

(TWA) replaces the older "Session Weighted Average" when referring to your average grade for a specific term (or semester). "Program Weighted Average" (PWA) is now used instead of "Cohort Weighted Average" to describe the average grade across your entire program. These updates aim to make the terminology more intuitive and reflective of their specific purposes. Featured FAQ Is Counselling for Me? [LINK: /s/student-success-advising/Faqs/detail/85/is-counselling-for-me] Many students find they struggle to cope with various pressures they experience at times. It can be hard to live on your own for the first time or adjust to living in a new country. You may be worried about your academic performance or have test-taking anxiety. You may be simply overwhelmed with... Credit Transfer Save Send Feedback The credit transfer process begins once you have confirmed your acceptance into a College program. If you believe you have completed equivalent courses elsewhere, you can request individual credit transfers. You may also be interested in this resource information [LINK: https://stucollegecon.sharepoint.com.mcas.ms/sites/registrar/SitePages/Student-Resources.aspx] from the Registrar's Office. Here is an overview of the process: Transfers within College: Courses with matching codes and names will transfer over if you're moving to a new program within College. After enrollment, you can view the transferred courses on your Student Portal's Progress Report. Requesting Credit Transfers: Visit the

Requesting Credit Transfers: Visit the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/StudentPortal/Default.aspx?_gl=1*djzb5y*_gcl_aw*R0NMLjE2OTU4MzAwNTEuQ2owS0NRandwYy1vQmhDR0FSSXNBSDZvdGU5clNHTnlGT0dSMnk2bDluNEpVeVN4NmxFTnBSWU9wZjlKcWpTMnpVNFJ1NlNHM3gzOVhBZ2FBcnFIRUFMd193Y0I.*_gcl_au*MTMzMzQ1NzY1OS4xNjkwOTA4OTQ3] > My Courses > My Credit Transfer. Follow the instructions to submit your credit transfer request. Upload course outlines for the relevant completed courses. Outlines should include course title, number/code, description, learning objectives, topics covered, textbooks, assignments, and evaluation scheme. They should correspond to the term you successfully completed the course. Note: You may find course outlines at ontransfer.ca [LINK: http://ontransfer.ca/] . Transcript Submission: Provide official transcripts from previous post-secondary institutions. Electronic transcripts are accepted if directly sent by the source institution via email to

Provide official transcripts from previous post-secondary institutions. Electronic transcripts are accepted if directly sent by the source institution via email to credittransfer@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:credittransfer@collegec.on.ca] , through MyCreds [LINK: https://mycreds.ca/] , or with your Ontario Colleges application. Physical transcripts must be in sealed envelopes from the source institution. Copies, prints, scans, or opened envelopes won't be accepted. International transcripts require assessment by ICAS or WES. Official assessment reports should be sent electronically or in sealed envelopes. Additional Information: Monitor your credit transfer request's progress on the Student Portal. Requests should ideally be submitted before the start of a term to avoid delays. Credit transfers may impact your OSAP funding or international student status. Full-time student fees are unaffected unless you switch to part-time status.

Credit transfers may impact your OSAP funding or international student status. Full-time student fees are unaffected unless you switch to part-time status. Timely requests are necessary for possible tuition refunds, subject to refund deadlines. If you have significant life/work experience, explore the Prior Learning Assessment and Recognition (PLAR) process for earning credits. To understand all the details, please review the Credit Transfer Policy [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/about/corporate-information/policies#academicadministration] . Contact and Support: If you require assistance or need guidance, please watch the " Credit Transfer Request - Instructions [LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WFrwtfz2ZZw] " video. Additionally, you can reach out to the Credit Transfer Office at credittransfer@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:credittransfer@collegec.on.ca] . For submitting physical transcripts, mail them to: Attn: Credit Transfer Office College College ITAL

Attn: Credit Transfer Office College College ITAL Office of the Registrar 299 Doon Valley Drive Kitchener, ON N2G 4M4 Featured FAQ Paying Tuition & Fees [LINK: /s/student-success-advising/Faqs/detail/3/paying-tuition-and-fees] Information on how to pay your fees can be found at the Office of the Registrar. All students, including those applying for OSAP, are required to pay a non-refundable tuition deposit for each academic year. This deposit secures your place in the program. Student Rights & Responsibilities FAQs Save Send Feedback Who do I contact if I have an emergency or safety concern? If you feel unsafe or need immediate attention on-campus, contact Safety and Security [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/safety-and-security/contact] . If you are off campus, contact emergency services by calling 911. If you are in crisis and need urgent mental health support, the following resources can help: Suicide Crisis Helpline (all of Canada): 988 HERE 24/7 (Kitchener, Waterloo, Cambridge, Guelph):1-844-437-3247 Good 2 Talk (Post-secondary student helpline): 1-866-925-5454 or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868 Crisis Support Peel (Mississauga, Brampton, Peel areas): 1-888-811-2222 Who can report a Student Rights and Responsibilities Violation? College students, employees, faculty, and members of the public may submit reports or reach out to our email. Can I make a report anonymously? Yes, we accept anonymous reports. Note that this can limit our responses available.

Yes, we accept anonymous reports. Note that this can limit our responses available. If we do not know who you are, we will be unable to follow-up with any updates or next steps on our process. To submit an anonymous report, complete the report form leaving the reporter name and contact information blank. If you would like some follow-up, you can provide an anonymous email address for us to contact. In some cases, we can keep reporters anonymous to other parties involved. If at any point in our process you choose to be anonymous after contacting our office, let us know. We will provide guidance on what that will look like moving forward. What are my options when making a report? The options we will provide you will depend on what the report or concerns are about. We will provide you with the most appropriate information and policies related to your concerns. In some cases, we may connect you with other departments better suited to support you. How do I schedule a meeting with you?

In some cases, we may connect you with other departments better suited to support you. How do I schedule a meeting with you? We ask that you first reach out to us via email or the report form with additional information on your concerns. This helps us better determine if we are the most appropriate resource for your inquiry. If we can provide further support, we will then share arrange a meeting with a member of our team via email. I’ve received an email from SRR about an incident, what happens next? Follow the instructions outlined in the emails from our office; there may be action items for you to follow. We recommend that you address it as soon as possible. Respond to the email with any questions or concerns you may have. If you received an email with a request to meet, its because we want to hear from you to gather your perspective. A meeting with our office is your opportunity to share your side of events and work on finding a resolution. How do I prepare for a meeting?

A meeting with our office is your opportunity to share your side of events and work on finding a resolution. How do I prepare for a meeting? We understand that connecting with our office can be overwhelming. Here’s some tips to help you feel ready: Review our policies and procedures so you know what to expect. Collect any important documentation like emails, text messages, screen captures, etc. You can send these to us before the meeting or bring them with you. If applicable, write down the names and contact information of any witnesses or other people involved. Make a timeline of events pr notes to help you remember details during the meeting. Consider if you want to bring a support person such as a family member, peer, or advisor. They can take notes and help be there as a moral support. Prepare any questions you have about the policies, procedures, outcome, etc. How do I challenge a decision made by SRR? The challenge process is outlined on page 6 of the

How do I challenge a decision made by SRR? The challenge process is outlined on page 6 of the Student Rights and Responsibilities Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/student-affairs/student-rights-and-responsibilities-procedure.pdf] If you want to challenge a decision that does not affect your academic status, email srr@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:srr@collegec.on.ca] and outline your grounds for appeal. The Director of Student Rights and Responsibilities will review it. Appropriate grounds for submitting a challenge are personal bias, unfair treatment or new information. Attach any documents any supporting documentation. If the decision does affect your academic status, submit a formal appeal form as outlined in Step 4 of the Academic Dispute and Appeal Resolution Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] (pdf).

Academic Dispute and Appeal Resolution Procedure [LINK: https://www-assets.collegec.on.ca/documents/www/about/policies/academic-administration/academic-dispute-resolution-and-appeal-procedure.pdf] (pdf). You can find the form on the student portal under the Services tab, then click "Forms" in the Students in Full-time Programs section. Complete the Student Appeals Form on Laserfiche. Are my conversations with the SRRO confidential? Your conversations with the SRRO are private unless we believe you or someone else is at risk of harm. We won't act on your concerns without your permission unless there's an immediate risk. If we contact you because of a report, we may share some information with involved parties. All records are kept secure according to privacy laws. Exceptions [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/document/freedom-information-and-protection-privacy-manual/chapter-5-exemptions-and-exclusions] are records under statutes that expressly state that they prevail over FIPPA.

Exceptions [LINK: https://www.ontario.ca/document/freedom-information-and-protection-privacy-manual/chapter-5-exemptions-and-exclusions] are records under statutes that expressly state that they prevail over FIPPA. Will SRR violations be visible on my permanent academic record? SRRO decisions and sanctions do not form part of a student's academic record except in cases of long-term suspension or discontinuance from the college. How long does it take to resolve an issue? We typically respond within 2 business days. Time to resolve an issue will depend on the concern, but we will try to move as quickly as possible and will keep you updated on timelines. Before Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Students      should arrive 15-minutes before their test start time to secure personal      items and complete check-in. Testing      appointments may be cancelled if students arrive more than 20-minutes late      from the indicated start time. Present      a non-expired physical photo ID (OneCard or government-issued      ID). Only      items required for the assessment will be permitted in the testing      room. All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre.

All      electronical devices not required for the assessment (smart devices,      phones, tablets) must be turned off and placed in a locker or designated      area provided by the Test Centre (approved accommodations excepted). All      personal items (coats, hats, bags) are to be secured in a locker or      designated area provided by the Test Centre. To      maintain a quiet and controlled testing environment for all test takers,      children are not permitted within the Test Centre and cannot be left      unattended while any student is writing. All      computer-based tests at the Test Centre will be conducted on assigned      desktop computers. Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test.

Students may use their personal laptops only if the      Test Centre desktop computers do not meet the test requirements or if      specified by the faculty. It is recommended to have your laptop on campus      and fully charged in case it is needed to complete the test. Please      note the Test Centres may not have power outlets for laptops. To      ensure a comfortable and healthy environment for everyone, Test Centres      are a designated scent-free zone. We kindly request that all individuals      refrain from wearing or using scented products. Only      water is permitted in the testing room (approved accommodations      excepted). After Your Assessment Save Send Feedback Test      Centre staff will submit all completed papers to your faculty. Any      concerns regarding the outcome of an assessment should be discussed with      the student’s faculty. If      applicable, return the locker key to the designated area after gathering your      belongings. Emergency Room Information Save Send Feedback Add experience [LINK: /s/medicalclinic/experiences/add/from/infopage/3400236] You should only go to an emergency room if you have a life-threatening medical emergency. There may be longer wait times, especially if your concern is not a life-threatening medical emergency. When you go to an emergency department, you need to bring your College International Health Insurance Plan card (for international students) or your OHIP card (for Ontario residents). If you live in Waterloo, Kitchener, Cambridge or Guelph, here is a list of the local emergency departments. 1. Grand River Hospital Emergency Room [LINK: https://www.grhosp.on.ca/care/services-departments/emergency/current-emergency-wait] 835 King St. W Kitchener, ON 2. St. Mary’s General Hospital: Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.smgh.ca/patients-visitors/emergency-department-wait-times] 911 Queen’s Blvd Kitchener, ON 3.

Kitchener, ON 3. Cambridge Memorial Hospital: Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.cmh.org/programs/department-emergency-medicine] 700 Coronation Blvd Cambridge, ON 4. Guelph General Hospital Emergency Department [LINK: https://www.gghorg.ca/emergency-department/] 115 Delhi St Guelph, ON 5. Halton Healthcare [LINK: https://www.haltonhealthcare.on.ca/services_/28763/t28425-emergency-department] Emergency care is available at all three hospitals located in Oakville, Milton and Georgetown If you live outside of these cities, you can find your nearest emergency department by searching “emergency department near me” on your preferred internet browser. Featured Info Page Emergency Room Information [LINK: /s/medicalclinic/InfoPages/detail/25/emergency-room-information] Information on Emergency Rooms in Waterloo, Kitchener, Cambridge, Guelph and Halton. × Feedback Comments Send Feedback Close

Bell Let's Talk Day 2025 Save Send Feedback Your mental health matters! On Wednesday, January 22nd join Student Success to break down the stigma related to mental health as part of Bell Let's Talk Day [LINK: https://letstalk.bell.ca/] . At each campus there will be a resource table as well as an opportunity for you to share your ideas on how you take care of yourself or share an uplifting message on the Talk Bubbles. Bell Let's Talk Events at College Campus Time Location Brantford Campus 10am - 2pm Student Lounge/Cafeteria Cambridge Campus 10am - 2pm Atrium Doon Campus 10am - 2pm 12pm - 1pm Therapy Dogs E-Wing Hallway Downtown Kitchener Campus 10am - 12pm Welcome Desk Area Guelph Campus 10am - 2pm Cafeteria Milton Campus 10am - 2pm Parkhill Lobby Reuter Campus 10am - 2pm Main Entrance Waterloo Campus 10am - 2pm Welcome Desk Area College College Resources Counselling Services [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/counselling]

College College Resources Counselling Services [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/counselling] Free, confidential services for students to meet with a professional Counsellor to address social, emotional and/or academic conerns. Call 519-748-5220 ext. 3679 or email counselling@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:counselling@collegec.on.ca] to make an appointment. Medical Clinic [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/medicalclinic] Offers a variety of health and wellness services to support your well-being. Call 519-748-5220 ext. 3679 or email medicalclinic@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:mailto:medicalclinic@collegec.on.ca] to book an appointment. CARE Team [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/careteam] Provide students with an elevated level of support. Any member of the College community can make a referral by completing a Public CARE Referral Form. [LINK: https://collegec-advocate.symplicity.com/care_report/index.php/pid634929?]

Public CARE Referral Form. [LINK: https://collegec-advocate.symplicity.com/care_report/index.php/pid634929?] Community Resources 988 Suicide Crisis Hotline [LINK: https://988.ca/] A safe space to talk 24 hours a day, every day of the year. Call or text 9-8-8. Good2Talk [LINK: https://good2talk.ca/] Provide free, confidential support services 24/7 for Ontario post-secondary students. Call 1-866-925-5454 or text GOOD2TALKON to 686868. CMHA Waterloo Wellington [LINK: https://cmhaww.ca/] Provide a full care system for those with mental health, substance-use, or developmental needs. COAST Crisis Line [LINK: https://halton.cmha.ca/our-programs-and-services/#crisis-services] 24/7 crisis line to support individuals requiring crisis support. Call 1-877-825-9011. CMHA Brantford Haldimand Norfolk [LINK: https://bhn.cmha.ca/] Support the Brantford area community through education and support services for mental illness and mental disorders in a safe, discrimination-free environment.

CMHA Brantford Haldimand Norfolk [LINK: https://bhn.cmha.ca/] Support the Brantford area community through education and support services for mental illness and mental disorders in a safe, discrimination-free environment. Athletics and Recreation - Student Success Save Kitchener,
 Canada https://www.collegecondors.ca/landing/index [LINK: https://www.collegecondors.ca/landing/index] Industry 1 [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/search?industry=5202] Industry 2 [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/search?industry=5203] Industry 3 [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/search?industry=5204] About We are proud to provide students with a full range of programs and services aimed at enhancing the College student experience. Our state of the art Student Recreation Centre enables students to access premium facilities and engage in quality programs including; fitness classes, intramural sport, drop in programs, extramural teams and intercollegiate programs. As a department we strive to provide the College Community with opportunities to live a healthy and active lifestyle.

Our state of the art Student Recreation Centre enables students to access premium facilities and engage in quality programs including; fitness classes, intramural sport, drop in programs, extramural teams and intercollegiate programs. As a department we strive to provide the College Community with opportunities to live a healthy and active lifestyle. College Consent Culture Save Kitchener,
 Canada https://www.collegec.on.ca/student-engagement [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/student-engagement] Industry 1 [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/search?industry=5202] About College Consent Culture is a series of workshops, events, and courses that help the College community in its pursuit to end gender-based violence (GBV). A series of workshops teach participants to ask for consent each time, stand up against norms that uphold rape culture and supports students by directing them to appropriate college and community resources. Have questions or looking for more information? College's Sexual and Gender-Based Violence Prevention and Support Office provides help based on your individual needs. There is no timeframe for when an incident occurred for someone to access support, and you do not need to disclose what happened in order to get help. Please email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca]

Please email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca] for appointments and information. Indigenous Services Save Kitchener,
 Canada https://www.collegec.on.ca/indigenous/services [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/indigenous/services] Industry 1 [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/search?industry=5202] bedahbingamik [LINK: https://facebook.com/bedahbingamik] bedahbingamik [LINK: https://instagram.com/bedahbingamik] About With the support of Elders, we named Indigenous Services Be-Dah-Bin Gamik. This Anishinaabek phrase translates to a Place of New Beginnings, representing the physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual work we do to embody the teachings that come with holding space for new beginnings. We provide academic and cultural services and support for Indigenous students at College, including First Nations (status and non-status), Métis, and Inuit. Students reconnecting to their Indigenous identities can attend our events and access Be-Dah-Bin Gamik services.

We provide academic and cultural services and support for Indigenous students at College, including First Nations (status and non-status), Métis, and Inuit. Students reconnecting to their Indigenous identities can attend our events and access Be-Dah-Bin Gamik services. Non-Indigenous students are welcome to attend our campus-wide community events and workshops in collaboration with various departments. International Student Support Services - International Transition Save Kitchener,
 Canada Industry 1 [LINK: /s/student-engagement/organisations/search?industry=5202] College College [LINK: https://linkedin.com/company/College College] About International Transition Coordinators (ITCs) provide specialized service to international students to support their smooth transition to Canada and College College. We engage students at the pre-arrival stage and continue to provide guidance throughout their College journey. We offer important resources and information, relevant referrals, comprehensive webinar programming, student-focused campus outreach booths, and individualized one-on-one advising. Our extensive service includes supporting students with settlement and acculturation, including early college onboarding, travel to Canada, housing, accessing college and community resources, and more!

Review my preferences [LINK: /s/student-engagement/Settings] Description A free festival where light, art, and tech meet happening on Saturday, September 20, 2025 from 6 p.m. to 11 p.m. in uptown Waterloo. Find more information on the Lumen website [LINK: https://www.lumenfestival.ca/] , launching early September 2025. Lumen is an annual, free, all-ages festival that is open to the public and run by the City of Waterloo’s Arts and Creative Industries team (Create Waterloo). The event features the work of artists as they explore the interplay of light, art, and technology in installations located throughout uptown Waterloo. The event hosts 30+ visual, interactive, new media, and performance-based installations.

uptown Waterloo. The event hosts 30+ visual, interactive, new media, and performance-based installations. Residents and community members are invited to enjoy this free festival in uptown Waterloo and get thinking about our community’s public spaces and how they transform our shared experiences. *Student Engagement shares information with students about off-campus co-curricular opportunities to support their social and professional development. College Consent Culture Save Kitchener,
 Canada https://www.collegec.on.ca/student-engagement [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/student-engagement] Industry 1 [LINK: /students/organisations/search?industry=5202] About College Consent Culture is a series of workshops, events, and courses that help the College community in its pursuit to end gender-based violence (GBV). A series of workshops teach participants to ask for consent each time, stand up against norms that uphold rape culture and supports students by directing them to appropriate college and community resources. Have questions or looking for more information? College's Sexual and Gender-Based Violence Prevention and Support Office provides help based on your individual needs. There is no timeframe for when an incident occurred for someone to access support, and you do not need to disclose what happened in order to get help. Please email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca]

Please email sgbv@collegec.on.ca [LINK: mailto:sgbv@collegec.on.ca] for appointments and information. Indigenous Services Save Kitchener,
 Canada https://www.collegec.on.ca/indigenous/services [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/indigenous/services] Industry 1 [LINK: /students/organisations/search?industry=5202] bedahbingamik [LINK: https://facebook.com/bedahbingamik] bedahbingamik [LINK: https://instagram.com/bedahbingamik] About With the support of Elders, we named Indigenous Services Be-Dah-Bin Gamik. This Anishinaabek phrase translates to a Place of New Beginnings, representing the physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual work we do to embody the teachings that come with holding space for new beginnings. We provide academic and cultural services and support for Indigenous students at College, including First Nations (status and non-status), Métis, and Inuit. Students reconnecting to their Indigenous identities can attend our events and access Be-Dah-Bin Gamik services.

We provide academic and cultural services and support for Indigenous students at College, including First Nations (status and non-status), Métis, and Inuit. Students reconnecting to their Indigenous identities can attend our events and access Be-Dah-Bin Gamik services. Non-Indigenous students are welcome to attend our campus-wide community events and workshops in collaboration with various departments.  Canada Industry 1 [LINK: /students/organisations/search?industry=5202] College College [LINK: https://linkedin.com/company/College College] About International Transition Coordinators (ITCs) provide specialized service to international students to support their smooth transition to Canada and College College. We engage students at the pre-arrival stage and continue to provide guidance throughout their College journey. We offer important resources and information, relevant referrals, comprehensive webinar programming, student-focused campus outreach booths, and individualized one-on-one advising. Our extensive service includes supporting students with settlement and acculturation, including early college onboarding, travel to Canada, housing, accessing college and community resources, and more!

Leaves & Absences: International Students Save Send Feedback Short-Term Leave If the time you will be away from your studies is not more than two academic weeks (10 days), you will not need to fill out any additional forms to proceed with the break. To start the leave process, your first step is to set up a meeting with your International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/internationalstudentimmigrationadvising] (ISIA). This meeting is very important to ensure the break you want aligns with the rules of your study permit. Before you go, you must also email your program coordinator, and each of your professors to let them know the days you will be absent ahead of time. Please note that you are responsible for keeping up with your studies and assignments during this time. If you miss any assignments, tests, or exams during a short-term leave, you may not be eligible to submit your missed work.

Please note that you are responsible for keeping up with your studies and assignments during this time. If you miss any assignments, tests, or exams during a short-term leave, you may not be eligible to submit your missed work. That decision lies with your professors, who must follow college policies. Reviewing your Academic Handbook [LINK: https://www.collegec.on.ca/handbook/student-guide] for more information. Emergency Absence If you need to leave Canada due to an emergency, and it will be longer than two weeks, you should first review the refund and withdrawal policies and decide whether to withdraw from your program temporarily. You will need to submit a "Withdrawal Form" through the Student Portal [LINK: https://studentportal.collegec.on.ca/] and consult with your International Student Immigration Advisor (link above) regarding the impact on your study permit and re-entry into Canada. Authorized Leave

and consult with your International Student Immigration Advisor (link above) regarding the impact on your study permit and re-entry into Canada. Authorized Leave For longer absences, International students can take an "authorized leave" from their studies for up to 150 days with the College's approval. Reasons for a leave may include medical, personal, or academic reasons. Authorization by the college is required to remain compliant with your study permit conditions. You will need to discuss your leave with program staff and your International Student Immigration Advisor [LINK: https://successportal.collegec.on.ca/s/internationalstudentimmigrationadvising] (ISIA) and complete a 'Return to Studies Plan.' Review my preferences [LINK: /students/Settings] Description A free festival where light, art, and tech meet happening on Saturday, September 20, 2025 from 6 p.m. to 11 p.m. in uptown Waterloo. Find more information on the Lumen website [LINK: https://www.lumenfestival.ca/] , launching early September 2025. Lumen is an annual, free, all-ages festival that is open to the public and run by the City of Waterloo’s Arts and Creative Industries team (Create Waterloo). The event features the work of artists as they explore the interplay of light, art, and technology in installations located throughout uptown Waterloo. The event hosts 30+ visual, interactive, new media, and performance-based installations. Residents and community members are invited to enjoy this free festival in uptown Waterloo and get thinking about our community’s public spaces and how they transform our shared experiences.
